hom.sense: The fourth letter of the alphabet: called vaMCN and vaA [respecting which latter see the letter b]: the pl. [of the former] is vaMCaAtN; and [of the latter,] OavowaMCN and OavoyaMCN. (TA in bAb AlAlf All-ynp.) It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice], and of those termed livawiy-ap [or gingival], which are v and c and Z. (TA at the commencement of f.)
It is sometimes substituted for f as in the instance of HuvaAlapN and HufaAlapN; and for s as in the instance of juvomaAnN and jusomaAnN; and for other letters. (TA in the latter place.)
[As a numeral, it denotes Five hundred.]

entry.sense: vaA and vaMCN: see the letter v, and arts. vwO and vI.

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. vaOovaOa He watered camels to their satisfaction: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ; but in some copies of the Ṣ, the verb is made trans. by means of bi:) or he watered them (T, M) so as to quench their thirst, (T,) but not so as to satisfy them. (T, M.)
Also, contr., He kept camels thirsty; i. e. he did not water them at all; or he watered them little, so that they were not satisfied. (Ḳ,* TA.)
He extinguished fire. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
He stilled another's anger. (TA.) And vaOovaOa Eanohu gaDabahu He quenched his anger. (M.) [Or this may be rendered He dispelled from him his anger: agreeably with what follows.]
He removed (IDrd, M, Ḳ) a thing (M) from its place. (IDrd, M, Ḳ.)
vaOovaOa Eani Alqawomi He repelled from, or defended, the people, or company of men, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and rendered them reciprocal aid. (Aṣ, TA.)
vaOovaOa, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. vaOovaOapN, (T,) also signifies He restrained, or withheld, (T, M, Ḳ,) a man (T, M,) from (Eano) another man, (T,) or from (Eano) a thing, or an affair. (M.)
vaOovaOati AlUibilu The camels drank to their satisfaction: (M, Ḳ:) or drank, but not so as to satisfy themselves. (M.)
And, contr., The camels thirsted. (Ḳ.)
And vaOovaOa It became stilled; (Ḳ;) said of anger. (TA.)
See also R. Q. 2.
vaOotaOa biAlt-ayosi, (AA, AZ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. vaOovaMCN, (Ḳ,) like taOotaMCN, (TA,) He called the he-goat (AA, AZ, M, Ḳ) to copulate. (AA, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tavaOovaOa He deemed it right that he should abide, or remain, where he was, (AZ, T, Ḳ,) and abstain, (AZ, TA,) after he had desired to make a journey (AZ, T, Ḳ) to a country, or land. (AZ, TA.) And tvO Eani AlOamori, (M,) or vOvO↓ Eani AlX-aIoCi, (TA,) He deemed it right that he should abstain from the affair, or thing, (M, TA,) or that he should pause at it, (M,) after he had desired it. (M, TA.)
laqiytu fulaAnFA fatavaOovaOotu minohu I met such a one, and feared him. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

1. vuYiba, (ʼEyn, T, M, Ḳ,) like EuniIa, (Ḳ,) and vaYiba, (IḲooṭ, L, and so in a copy of the A,) inf. n. vaOobN, (Ḳ,) or vaOabN, (M,) He became relaxed and sluggish; said of a man: (A:) or he became affected with sluggishness and languor; (M;) as also tvMCb↓: (M, A:) or he became affected with sluggishness and languor like the languor of drowsiness; as also tvMCb↓ and tvO-b↓; (Ḳ;) which last is approved by IDrd and Thábit Es-Sara- kustee, who disallow tvMCb↓, though this is the form commonly known and approved, and is the most chaste form: (TA:) or he became affected with languor like the heaviness of drowsiness, in consequence of something that he had eaten or drunk, without becoming insensible; (T;) as also tvMCb↓: (L:) or ↓this last signifies he yawned, or opened his mouth, (Mgh, Mṣb,) by reason, (Mgh,) or on the occasion, (Mṣb,) of languor (Mgh, Mṣb,) like the heaviness of drowsiness; (Mgh;) or he yawned, or opened his mouth, and stretched himself, on being affected by sluggishness or drowsiness or anxiety; (MF, TA, on the authority of IDrst;) or he yawned, or opened his mouth, and emitted wind from his stomach, by reason of some affection thereof: (TA on the authority of Et-Tedmuree:) Alt-avaAWubu is from Alv-uWabaMCu; (AZ, T, Ṣ, Mgh;) and is on the occasion of one's stretching himself, and being languid: (Lth, T:) one should not say tavaAwaba; (AZ, T, Ṣ, O, Mgh;) [for] this is vulgar. (Mṣb.) Hence, UicaA tavaOaCaba↓ OaHadukumo faloyugaT-i faAhu [When any one of you yawns, he should cover his mouth with the back of his left hand; for it is believed that the devil leaps into the uncovered yawning mouth]. (Mgh.)
5: see 1.
6: see 1, in six places.

vuWabaMCu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) as also vuWobaMC, accord. to Ibn-Mis-hal, but this is strange, (TA,) is a subst. derived from Alt-avaAWubu, like muTuwaMCu from Alt-amaT-iI; (T;) or from vaYiba; and means A state of relaxation and sluggishness: (A:) or sluggishness and languor (M, Ḳ) like the languor of drowsiness: (Ḳ:) or languor like the heaviness of drowsiness, in consequence of something that one has eaten or drunk, not attended by insensibility: (T, L:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, by reason of languor like the heaviness of drowsiness: (Mgh:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, and stretching oneself, on being affected by sluggishness or drowsiness or anxiety: (IDrst, MF, TA:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, and emitting wind from the stomach, by reason of some affection thereof. (Et-Tedmuree, TA.) Hence the prov., OaEodaI mina Alv-uWabaMCi, (Ṣ, A, TA,) and [Alv-uwabaMCi,] without C, as some say; (MF;) or the pronunciation without C is vulgar, (IDrst, TA,) or erroneous; (TA;) [More catching than yawning;] for when a man yawns (AcA tvACb) in the presence of others, they become affected as he is. (TA.)
mavoWuwbN Affected with sluggishness and languor like the languor of drowsiness: from vuYiba, q. v. (Ḳ.)

1. vaOarahu, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and vaOara bihi, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) aor. _a {yavoOaru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. vaOorN and vuWorapN, (Ṣ,) or the latter is a simple subst., as is also vuWuwrapN, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) He revenged, or avenged, his blood, by retaliating his slaughter; he slew his slayer. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence, vuYira maqotuwluhu and bimaqotuwlihi The blood of his slain relation was revenged, or avenged, by retaliation of his slaughter: see 10.]
[Hence also,] laA vaOarato fulaAnFA yadaAhu, (Ḳ,) or EalaI fulaAnK, (A,) ‡ May his arms, or hands, not profit such a one. (A, Ḳ.)

Also vaOarahu, and vaOara bihi, (M, Ḳ,) and vaOara Alqawoma, inf. n. vaOorN, (T,) He sought to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, (T, M, Ḳ,) his blood, (M, Ḳ,) and the blood of the people, or party. (T.) It is said in a prov., laA yanaAmu mano vaOara [He will not sleep who seeks to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood]: in the Kámil of Mbr, [and in some copies of Meyd,] mani Qv-aOari↓ [which seems to signify the same]. (TA.)
[And vaOarahu and vaOara bihi signify also He slew him in blood-revenge, or in retaliation of the blood of a relation: see mavoWuwrN.]
vaOarotuka bikacaA I have obtained my bloodrevenge, or retaliation, of thee by such [a deed, or person]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4: see 8.

8. Aiv-aOara originally AivotaOara He obtained his bloodrevenge, or retaliation; syn. Oadorak vaOorahu; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) minohu from him; (T, Ṣ;) as also OavoOara↓: (M, Ḳ:) and Aiv-aOara minohu he slew the slayer of his relation. (T.) Lebeed says,
waAln-iybu Uino taEoru min-iI rim-apF xalaqFA
baEoda AlmamaAti faUin-iI kunotu Oav-aYiru
[And the old she-camels, if they seek to obtain benefit from a worn rotten bone of me after death, I used to retaliate upon them by anticipation]: (T, Ṣ:) i. e., I used to slaughter [some of] them for guests, and so I have retaliated upon them during my life for their nibbling my rotten bones after my death:
for when camels do not find herbage of the kind called HamoD, they eat the bones of dead men and of camels instead thereof. (T.)
See also 1.

10. AstvOr He (a relation of a slain man, A) sought, or asked, aid, in order that the blood of his slain [relation] might be revenged, or avenged, by retaliation of his slaughter (luyivoOara bimaqotuwlihi), (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in order that he might take, or seek, revenge, or vengeance, for his slain [relation]. (A.)

hom.sense: vaOorN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which may be also pronounced vaArN, i. e., with the C suppressed, (Mṣb,) and vaOorapN↓, (A,) and vuWorapN↓, (Ṣ,) which last is a subst. [from vaOara], as also vuWuwrapN↓, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) Blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide: or a seeking to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood: [see 1, of which vaOorN is an inf. n.:] or a desire, or seeking, for retaliation of a crime or of enmity: or retention of enmity in the heart, with watchfulness for an opportunity to indulge it: syn. caHolN: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) or Talaba biAld-ami: (M, Ḳ:) or HiqodN: (Mgh:) or (so accord. to the M; but accord. to the Ḳ, “and”) blood (M, Ḳ) itself: (M:) pl. OavoMrN and MvaArN; the latter formed by transposition. (Yaạḳoob, M.) You say, Oadoraka vaOorahu (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and vuWoratahu↓ (Aṣ, T, Ṣ) [He obtained, or attained, or took, his bloodrevenge, or retaliation: or] he attained the object of his pursuit [for blood-revenge, or retaliation]; from vaOarahu: (Aṣ, T:) or he slew the slayer of his relation. (Mgh.) And Talaba bivaOorihi He sought to obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation; syn. Talaba bicaHolihi. (Ṣ and Mṣb in art. cHl.) And OanaA OaTolubu vaOoriI Einodahu I seek my blood-revenge of him; syn. caHoliI. (A.) And vaOoriI Einoda fulaAnK My blood-revenge is a debt owed to me by such a one; syn. caHoliI: meaning such a one is the slayer of my relation. (A.)

vaOorN also signifies, (A,) or vaAYirN↓, (T,) One who seeks blood-revenge, or retaliation of the slaughter of his relation: and one of whom is sought blood-revenge, or retaliation of the slaughter of a relation: (T, A:) the latter primarily signifies a slayer; and hence, a slayer of a person's relation in vengeance, or retribution: (Ḥam p. 637:) and the former, one who is sought, or pursued, for blood-revenge; an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Ḥam p. 87:) the slayer of a person's relation; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also vaAYirN↓: (A:) pl. of the former OavoMrN and MvaArN [as above] (Ḳ) and vaOoraAtN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) the first of which three is [also] pl. of vaAYirN. (T.) You say, huwa vaOoruhu He is the slayer of his relation. (Ṣ.) And yaA vaOoraAti fulaAnK O slayers of such a one. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) yaA vaOoraAti EuvomaAna, occurring in a trad., which is also related with the substitution of taAraAt for vOrAt, may be explained in the same manner; or it may mean O ye seekers of the blood-revenge of ʼOthmán, aid me to obtain it; the prefixed noun TaAlibiI, or Oahol, being understood. (Nh, TA. [See also taArapN in art. twr.]) vaOorN muniymN [A slayer of one's relation who causes his slayer to sleep,] means one with whom the seeker [of blood-revenge or retaliation] is contented, if he find him [and slay him], so that he sleeps after; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) one who, if slain, causes the pursuer of blood-revenge to cease from the pursuit: (Ḥam p. 87:) or a person who is an equivalent for the blood of one's relation [and who therefore, by his being slain in retaliation, makes the avenger to sleep]: (T:) or a person of rank, or note, in whom [i. e. by the slaughter of whom] one has his full desire accomplished. (A.) In a trad. of Moḥammad Ibn-Selemeh, relating to the day of Kheyber, occur the words, OanaA lahu yaA rasuwlu Qll-ehi Almawotuwru lilv-aAYiri↓, meaning [I am for him, i. e. I am he who should slay him, O Apostle of God:] the seeker of blood-revenge [is for him of whom blood-revenge is sought]. (L. [The explanation there given is clearly shown to relate to Almwtwr.])

vaOorN signifies also An enemy: pl. OavoMrN: so explained as occurring in the following words of a trad.; laA tugomiduwA suyuwfakumo Eano OaHodaAvikumo fatuwtiruwA OavoMrakumo Do not sheathe your swords from your young ones, [neglecting to teach them the use thereof,] and so make your enemies to attain their desire of blood-revenge. (TA.)

entry.sense: vaOorapN: see vaOorN.
vuWuwrapN: see vaOorN.
vaAYirN: see vaOorN, in three places.
Also One who does not pity anything (laA yuboqiI EalaI XaIoCK) so that he may obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

mavoWuwrN and mavoWuwrN bihi [Revenged, or avenged, by the retaliation of his slaughter; by the slaughter of his slayer: and also slain in blood-revenge, or in retaliation for the blood of a relation of the slayer]: these two expressions [thus] apply to one's enemy as well as to one's relation. (A.)
Also, the latter, [simply,] Slain. (T, and Ḥam p. 87. [But retaliation is generally meant to be understood.])
Q. Q. 1. vuWolila He (a man, M, Mgh) had vaMliyl [i. e. warts] come forth upon him. (M, Mgh, Ḳ.)
Q. Q. 2. tavaOolala jasaduhu (T, M, Ḳ) biAlv-aMliyli (T, TA) His person had vaMliyl [or warts] come forth upon it. (T, M, Ḳ.)

vuWoluwlN, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) which may also be pronounced with the C suppressed, [vuwluwlN,] (Mṣb,) [A wart; thus called in the present day;] a certain excrescence (M, Mgh, Ḳ) on the person of a man, (Mgh,) small, (Ḳ,) hard, and round, (Mgh, Ḳ,) and of various forms; one description being inverted; another, cracked and scabrous; another, pendent; another, nail-shaped, large in the head and slender at the root; another, long, and bent backward; another, opened; all arising from a thick, tough humour, phlegmatic, or bilious, or a compound of both these kinds: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. vaMliylu. (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Also, (as being likened to the excrescence above mentioned, TA,) The nipple of the breast. (Kr, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. vabata, (Ṣ, M, A, &c.,) aor. _u {yavobutu}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. vubuwtN (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vabaAtN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) or this latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) [unexplained in the Ṣ and M and A and Ḳ, as being well known,] It (a thing, Ṣ, M, Mṣb) continued, subsisted, lasted, endured, remained, remained fixed or stationary, stood, or rested; it was, or became, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: it obtained, or held: syn. daAma: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and Aisotaqar-a: (Mṣb:) [it stood, as a fact or truth; it stood, or held, good; it was, or became, a fact or truth, or a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] it was, or became, or proved, sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper; syn. SaH-a. (Mṣb.)
vabata biAlmakaAni, inf. n. vuburtN, He continued, remained, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (T.)
vabata AljaraAdu, and v-bt↓, and Avbt↓, The locusts stuck their tails into the ground to lay their eggs. (T.)
vabat-u EalaI AlOamori [I kept constantly, firmly, steadily, steadfastly, or fixedly, to the affair]. (Ḳ in art. zmE.)
vabata liboduka ‡ May thy case, or state, or condition, be permanent. (A, TA.)

[vabata Einodahu kacaA Such a thing was, or became, a settled, or an established, fact, or truth, with him, or in his opinion; it became established, substantiated, made good, or verified, in his opinion or estimation: like SaH-a. And vabata Ealayohi It was, or became, established against him. Hence, vabata lahu Ealayohi kacaA Such a thing became established, or verified, as due to him from him: like SaH-a. And hence,] vabata is also syn. with wajaba [as meaning It was, or became, or proved to be, binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due: and it was, or became, necessitated, necessary, or requisite: so that vabata Ealayohi means also it was, or became, or proved to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on him; or it rested, or lay, on him; as a debt, or a duty: and it (a sentence, &c.) became necessitated to take effect upon him: and vabata lahu it was, or became, or proved to be, due to him, or owing to him]. (Telweeh, TA in art. wjb.)
[vabata lahu also signifies It belonged, or appertained, as an attribute, or a quality, or a property, to him, or it; it was affirmable, or predicable, of him, or it.]

vabuta, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavobutu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. vabaAtapN (M, A, Ḳ) and vubuwtapN, (M, Ḳ,) He was, or became, firm in intellect, understanding, or mind: (Ṣ:) or firm, or steady, in fight, or in speech, or discourse: (M:) or intelligent, and possessing self-restraint: or seldom erring or making a mistake or committing a fault: (A:) or firm of heart in war: (Mṣb:) or courageous as a horseman, (Ḳ, TA,) earnest in the charge. (TA.)
2. vab-ata AljaraAdu: see 1.
vb-thu: see 4, in two places.
vb-thu Eani AlOamori i. q. vab-aTahu [He hindered him, withheld him, or prevented him,, &c., from doing the affair, or thing]. (M.)

entry.sense: 3. muvaAbatapN i. q. mumaAwatapN [meaning The vying with another in firmness, or steadiness, or the like]. (TA in art. mwt.)
See also 4.

hom.sense: 4. Avbt AljaraAdu: see 1.

Avbthu trans. of vabata, as also vb-thu↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) signifying He made it to continue, subsist, last, endure, remain, remain fixed or stationary, stand, or rest; to be, or become, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: he made it to obtain, or hold: [he made it to stand, as a fact or truth; to stand, or hold, good; to be or become, a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] he made it, or rendered it, sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper. (Mṣb.)
TaEanahu faOavobata fiyhi Alr-umoHi He thrust him, and made the spear to penetrate into him so that the extremity protruded while part remained within him; syn. Oanofacahu (M.)
Avbthu biwivaAqK [He made him fast with a bond, or ligature]. (TA.)

liyuvobituwka, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or liyuvab-ituwka↓, (CK,) in the Ḳur [viii. 30], means ‡ That they might inflict upon thee a wound by reason of which thou shouldst not be able to rise: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA:) or that they might confine thee [to thy place]. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, TaEanotuhu faOavobat-uhu ‡ I thrust him, or pierced him, and confined him to his place, so that he could not quit it. (TA from a trad.) And Darabuwhu Hat-aI Oavobatuwhu ‡ They smote him, or beat him, so that they enervated him [and rendered him motionless]. (A, TA.) And Oavobata AljariyHa † He weakened the wounded man so that he was unable to move. (Mgh.) And Oavobatatohu jiraAHapN ‡ A wound rendered him unable to move: (T,* A:) and in like manner one says of a malady. (A.) And Ouvobita † His malady became violent, or a wound affected him, so that he did not [or could not] move. (T, TA.)
Avbt HuH-atahu He established his evidence, or proof, and made it clear, plain, or manifest. (M.)

Avbthu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UivobaAtN, (TA,) also signifies ‡ He knew him, or it, certainly, or assuredly; and so vAbthu↓, (M, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muvaAbatapN. (TA.) And you say, naZarotu Uilayohi famaA Oavobat-uhu bibaSariI ‡ [I looked at him, or it, but I did not know him, or it, surely with my eye]. (A, TA.) And Avbt AlX-aIoCa maEorifapF ‡ [He knew the thing certainly, completely, or thoroughly]. (A. [Explained in a copy of that work, followed in the TA, by qabilahu; but this is undoubtedly a mistranscription for qatalahu, q. v.])
Also, (i. e. Avbthu alone,) He verified it. (Ḥar p. 175.)
And ‡ He wrote it, [set it down, registered it, or recorded it,] i. e., a man's name, (A, Mṣb, TA,) fiI Ald-iywaAni [in the register of soldiers or pensioners or accounts]. (A, TA.)

[And i. q. Oawojabahu as meaning He made it, or declared it to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, (Ealayohi on him,) or due (lahu to him): and, said of a sentence, &c., as meaning he necessitated it to take effect, or necessitated its taking effect, Ealayohi upon him: see Haq-ahu.]

[And He affirmed it; he averred it; i. q. Oawojabahu as contr. of nafaAhu. And hence, Avbthu lahu signifies also He made it, or declared it, or asserted it, to belong, or appertain, as an attribute, or a quality, or a property, to him, or it; he affirmed it, or predicated it, of him, or it.]
[And He authorized it; namely a word, a signification, &c.]
Avbt fulaAnFA He kept, clave, or held fast, to such a one; scarcely, or never, quitting him. (Mṣb.) And Avbthu Als-aqamu, i. e. [The malady clave to him;] did not quit him. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 5. tvb-t fiI AlOamori, (T, Ṣ, M, A, TA,) and Alr-aOoIi; (T, TA;) and Astvbt↓; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, TA;) He acted, or proceeded, [firmly, steadily,] deliberately, or leisurely, (T, M, A, Ḳ, TA,) in the affair, (T, M, A, TA,) and the opinion, judgment, or counsel; (T, TA;) not hastily: (T, M, TA:) both signify the same: (Ṣ:) [or] Astvbt↓ fiI Oamorihi he consulted respecting his affair, and sought for information respecting it, or investigated it. (T, TA.) [In the KL, tavab-utN is explained by the words drnG krdn w bhjAI Mwrdn, perhaps meaning The delaying in an affair and ( then) executing or performing.]

hom.sense: 10. Astvbt: see 5, in two places.
[Also He sought, or desired, or demanded, confirmation, evidence, proof, demonstration, verification, assurance, or positive or certain information, Eanohu respecting him, or it.]
[And He desired, or meant, an affirmation: see a remark on a verse cited voce bayoda.]

Astvbthu He found it to be sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper: (Ḥar p. 175:) and he assured, or certified, himself of the true state of his case. (Idem, p. 426.) You say, Sag-ara Eayonahu liyasotavobita Aln-aZara † [He contracted his eye in order to assure himself of the correctness of the view; i. e., to obtain a sure view]. (M in art. wS.)
It is also said to mean He made him, or asserted him to be, firm of heart: but Er-Rázee says, I have not met with this verb used as one that is immediately transitive. (Ḥar p. 426.)

entry.sense: vabotN: see vaAbitN.

Also A man firm, or steady, of heart; (Ṣ;) and so vabotu AljanaAni; (A, Mṣb, TA;) pl. vubotN: (TA:) or a man who acts, or proceeds, [firmly, steadily,] deliberately, or leisurely, (A, Mṣb,) in his affairs: (Mṣb:) and a courageous horseman, (M, Ḳ, TA,) earnest in the charge; (TA;) as also vabiytN↓: (M, Ḳ, TA:) both of which signify also intelligent, and possessing self-restraint; or seldom erring or making a mistake or committing a fault. (A, TA.) And vabotu AlmaqaAmi A man who does not quit his station, or abode. (M.) And vabotu Alqadami [Firm-footed;] one who makes no slip in contention, or in fight. (A, TA.) And vabotu Algadari A man firm, or steady, in fight, or in speech, or discourse: (M, L, TA:) or whose tongue makes no slip in contentions. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also vabatN:
and vabiytN.

vabatN Firmness of heart in war. (Mṣb, TA.) You say, lahu vabatN Einoda AlHamolapi He has firmness, or steadiness, on the occasion of the charge, or assault. (Ṣ, A.) And lahu vabatN Einoda AlHimaAmi He has firmness on the occasion of death. (L.) [See also vabaAtN.]

Hence, (Mṣb,) A proof, and evidence, or a voucher. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) You say, laA OaHokumu bikacaA Uil-aA bivabatK I will not decide so unless on the ground of proof, or evidence. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the day of doubt, [i. e. the day of which one doubts whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán,] vum-a jaMCa Alv-abatu Oan-ahu mino ramaDaAna Then came the proof, or evidence, or voucher, that it was of Ramadán. (TA.)

And hence, (Mgh,) applied to a man, (A, Mgh, [in which latter it is said to be tropical when thus applied, but not so in the A,]) and sometimes written vabotN↓, (TA,) † One who is an authoritative evidence, or voucher, by reason of his trustworthiness in that which he relates: (A, TA:) or ‡ one who is trustworthy (Mgh, Ḳ *) in that which he relates: (Mgh: [in the Ḳ, only the pl. is mentioned:]) or † one who is just, or equitable, [in that which he relates,] and exact, or honest: (Mṣb:) pl. OavobaAtN. (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also † An index, or a table of contents, in which a relater of traditions collects a list of what he has related from others, and of his sheykhs [who are his authorities]: said by some to be a conventional term of the relaters of traditions: perhaps tropical. (TA.)

vabaAtN, a subst. from vabata, [or an inf. n., like vubuwtN↓, used as a simple subst.,] Continuance, subsistency, lastingness, permanence, endurance, remanence, remanence in a fixed or stationary state, a state of standing or resting, constancy, firmness, steadiness, steadfastness, stableness or stability, fixedness, fastness, settledness, establishment or a state of being established:, &c.: and soundness, validness or validity, substantiality or substantialness, reality, sureness, certainty, trueness or truth,, &c. (Mṣb.) [See also vabatN.]
vubaAtN, (A,) or daMCN vubaAtN, (Ḳ, TA,) ‡ A disease that renders one unable to move. (A,* Ḳ, TA.)

vibaAtN The two threads or strings, or each of the two threads or strings, of [the kind of face-veil called] a buroquE by which the woman [draws and] binds [the two upper corners of] it to the back of her head. (Ḳ.)
And A strap, or thong, with which a camel's saddle (raHol) is bound: (M, Ḳ:) pl. OavobitapN. (M.)
vubuwtN: see vabaAtN.
vabiytN: see vaAbitN.
Also Firm in intellect, understanding, or mind: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and firm in strength and intellect: (TA:) or firm of heart in war: (Mṣb:) see also vabotN.
And, applied to a horse, Sharp, and light, or active, in his running; (M, Ḳ;) as also vabotN↓. (TA.)

vaAbitN part. n. of vabata; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also vabotN↓ (M, A, Ḳ) and vabiytN↓; (Ḳ;) Continuing, subsisting, lasting, enduring, remaining, remaining fixed or stationary, standing, or resting, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: obtaining, or holding: [standing, as a fact or truth; standing, or holding, good; having the quality of a fact or truth, or a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper: (Mṣb: see 1:)
dim., when it is used as an epithet, vuwayobitN; but when it is a proper name, its dim. is vubayotN. (T.)
vaAbitN bimakaAnK Continuing, remaining, dwelling, or abiding, in a place. (TA.)
AlkawaAkibu Alv-aAbitapu [and Alv-awaAbitu] The fixed stars. (Ḳzw, &c.)
sinuwna vaAbitapN Years lasting long. (TA in art. qEs.)
qawolN vaAbitN A sound, valid, true, right, correct, just, or proper, saying. (M.) biAlqawoli Alv-aAbiti in the Ḳur xiv. 32 means By the assertion of the unity of God. (Jel.)
muvobtN Bound with the strap, or thong, called vibaAt; applied to a camel's saddle (raHol). (M, Ḳ.)

‡ Motionless by reason of disease (T, Ḳ, TA) that has become violent, or by reason of a wound: (T, TA:) or the same, (M,) or in this sense muvobitN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) ‡ heavy (M, Ḳ, TA) by reason of old age or some other cause, (TA,) and not quitting the bed. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
[kalaAmN muvobatN lit. An affirmed sentence; i. q. muwjabN as contr. of manofiI-N; virtually the same as kalaAmu muvobitN↓ an affirming, or affirmative, sentence.]
muvobitN: see muvobatN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. vabaja, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yavobiju}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. vubuwjN, (Ṣ,) He sat with his but tocks against his heels, resting upon the extremities of his feet, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as one does in performing the act termed AisotinojaMCN. (TA.)
[vabija: see the next paragraph {2}.]

2. vb-j biAlEaSaA, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tavobiyjN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and tvb-j↓ bihaA; (A, Ḳ;) He (a pastor, Ṣ, A) put the staff, or stick, upon, or against, his back, and put his arms, or hands, behind it: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) thus he does when he is fatigued. (TA.)

vb-jhu, (Ṣ, A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made it obscure; (Ḳ;) he did not make it distinct, or plain; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) namely, writing, (Ṣ,) [i. e.] handwriting; (A, Ḳ;) and speech, or language: (Ṣ:) he did not express it in the proper mode, or manner, namely, speech, or language. (A.) And vub-ija, inf. n. as above; [and app. vabija↓, aor. _a {yavobaju}, inf. n. vabajN, q. v. infrà;] said of writing; [and of speech, or language;] It was, or was made, confused [&c.]. (Lth, TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 2.

hom.sense: vabajN The part between the kaAhil [app. here signifying the base of the neck] and the back: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the circuit of the upper part of the kAhl, extending to the breast; as is shown by the phrase OavobaAju AlqaTaA: [see what follows:] (Aboo-Málik, TA:) or the part between the shoulderblades and the kAhl: and the main part of the back, and the part in which are the places of curvature of the ribs: or the part between the buttocks and the base of the neck: accord. to AO, the part from the rump-bone, or root of the tail, to the hair of the withers [of a horse]: (TA:) also the breast of the bird called AlqaTaA: (Ḳ:) or the middle part of that bird: pl. OavobaAjN. (A, TA.)

† The middle (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a thing, (Ḳ,) of anything: (Ṣ:) and the main part thereof; (Ḳ;) so of a heap, or tract, of sand: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) and the higher, or highest, part of a thing:pl. [of pauc.] OavobaAjN and [of mult.] vubuwjN. (TA.) ‡ The middle of the sea: the main part thereof; and of the night: (A,* TA:) the height of the middle of the sea, where the waves meet one another: the higher, or highest, parts of the waves. (TA.) mino vabaji Almusolimiyna † Of the middle class of the Muslims: or of the higher, or highest, or chief, class of them. (TA from a trad.)
The quality denoted by the epithet Oavobaju, q. v.; as also vabajapN↓. (L.)
Incongruity and confusion of speech, or language: and obscurity, or indistinctness, of handwriting. (Ḳ. [App. an inf. n.: see 2, last sentence.])

vabajapN A thing of the middling sort, between good and bad: (Ḳ, TA:) the fem. p is affixed because the word is changed from a subst. to an epithet: it occurs in this sense applied to the contribution termed Sadaqap. (TA.)
See also vabajN.

entry.sense: Oavobaju Broad, or wide, in the part called the vabaj; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb, TA;) and large in the jawof [i. e. chest, or belly]: (TA:) or protuberant, or prominent, in the vabaj: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or humpbacked: (TA in this art., and in art. Ejr on the authority of Fr:) and having a projecting, or prominent, breast, or chest: (L:) dim. Ouvayobiju↓, occurring in a trad. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ.)
Ouvayobiju: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. vabarahu, (M, TA,) aor. _i {yavobiru}, (M,) or _u, (TA,) inf. n. vaborN, (M, Ḳ,) He confined him; or restrained, withheld, hindered, or prevented, him; (M, Ḳ;) as also vb-rhu↓, (M,) inf. n. tavobiyrN. (Ḳ.) You say, vabarahu biAlX-aIoCi, aor. _u {yavoburu}, inf. n. as above, He confined, restricted, or limited, him (a man) to the thing. (Mṣb.) And vabarahu Eanohu, (T, Ṣ, M,) aor. _i {yavobiru}, (T,) or _u, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. as above; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and vb-rhu↓; (IAạr, TA;) He, or it, restrained, withheld, hindered, or prevented, him from it; (IAạr, T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) turned him away, or back, from it, (AZ, IAạr, T, M, Ḳ.) And maA vabaraka Eano HaAjatika What restrained, withhold, hindered, or prevented, thee, (T,* Ṣ, A,) or retarded thee, (A,) or diverted thee, (T, A,) from [accomplishing, or attaining,] thy want? (Ṣ, A.) And maA vab-ara↓ Aln-aAsi What hath turned the people away, or back, and withheld, or prevented, them, from obeying God? or what hath retarded them therefrom? (TA from a trad.)

Also, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He denied him, or refused him, or prohibited him from attaining, or debarred him from, what he desired or sought; he disappointed him, or caused him to fail of attaining his desire; rendered him unsuccessful; disappointed, or frustrated, his desire, or hope. (Ḳ.)
He drove him away, expelled him, or banished him. (Ḳ.)
He cursed him. (Ḳ.)
Also, (M, A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yavoburu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. vubuwrN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He (God, M, A, Mṣb) destroyed him (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ *) with a destruction from which he should not rise again. (M, A.)
vabara, aor. _u {yavoburu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. vubuwrN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He perished: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he suffered loss; erred, or went astray; or became lost. (Ṣ.) [See also vubuwrN below.]
Also, (M,) inf. n. vaborN, (Ḳ,) It (the sea) ebbed. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in three places.

3. vAbr Ealayohi, (T, M, A, Ḳ,*) inf. n. muvaAbarapN, (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to it, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) namely, a thing, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) or an affair, (TA,) as, for instance, learning: (A:) he was eager to say it, or to do it, and kept to it constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously. (IAth.)
6. tavaAbaraA, (Ḳ,) or tavaAbarati Alr-ijaAlu, (M,) They two, (Ḳ,) or the men, (M,) leaped, or sprang, (M, Ḳ,) each upon, or at, the other, (Ḳ,) or one upon, or at, another, in war, or fight. (M.)
11. AivobaArarotu Eanohu I was heavy, or sluggish, and held back from it. (Ḳ.)

vubuwrN Perdition: (Ḳatádeh, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) loss; a going astray; or becoming lost: (Ṣ:) woe: (Ḳatádeh, T, M, Ḳ:) destruction (M, A, Ḳ) from which there is no rising again. (M, A.) Hence it is said that the people of Hell will call out, waAvubuwraAho Alas for destruction from which there is no rising again! (M, A.) In the Ḳur xxv. 14 and 15, vubuwrFA is in the accus. case as an inf. n., as though they said, vabaronaA vubuwrFA; and, being an inf. n., it is used as a sing. and pl. (Fr, Zj, T.)

vaAbirN Suffering loss; erring, or going astray; or becoming lost, or perishing; syn. xaAsirN: so in the saying of El-Kumeyt,
waraOato quDaAEapu fiI AlOayaA
mino raOoIa mavobuwrK wavaAbiro
And Ḳuḍáʼah, in asserting their relationship to El-Yemen, formed the opinion of one who is made to suffer loss, or to err,, &c., and one who is suffering loss, or erring,, &c.; mvbwr here meaning maxosuwr. (Ṣ.)

mavobuwrN, as used in the Ḳur xvii. 104, Overcome; withheld, or prevented, from attaining what is good: (Fr, T:) driven away; expelled; banished; outcast: punished; chastised: (IAạr, T:) cursed; accursed: (Fr, IAạr, T:) made to lose, or suffer loss; to err, or go astray; or to become lost, or to perish: so in the saying of El-Kumeyt cited above, voce vaAbirN: (Ṣ:) in a state of destruction. (Mujáhid, T.)

hom.sense: 1. vabiTa, aor. _a {yavobaTu} [inf. n., accord. to rule, vaboTN,] (Ḳ,) or, as Ṣgh says, [judging from the part. n. vabiTN,] thus analogy requires that it should be, (TA,) He was, or became, stupid in his work, or action; and weak: and he (a man, and a horse, Ḳ and TA, said of a horse with respect to covering, TA) was, or became, heavy, sluggish, or slow. (Ḳ,* TA.)
See also 2, in two places.

entry.sense: 2. vb-Thu Eani AlOamori, (Lth, IDrd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or AlX-aIoCi, (TA,) inf. n. tavobiyTN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He hindered him, withheld him, or prevented him, (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and retarded him, (IDrd, Ḳ, TA,) from doing the affair, or thing; (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also vabaTahu↓: (IDrd, Ḳ:) he diverted him from it, by occupying him otherwise: (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or he prevented him from doing it by inducing him to be cowardly and weak-hearted: (Mṣb:) or tvbyT signifies one's turning a man back, or away, from a thing that he would do: (Aboo-Is- hák:) or one's intervening as an obstacle between a man and a thing that he desires. (TA.) The verb occurs in the Ḳur ix. 46. (TA.)

vb-Thu EalaI AlOamori, inf. n. as above, He made him to pause, or wait, at the thing, or affair; (TA;) as also vabaTahu↓ Ealayohi, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. vaboTN; (TA;) syn. waq-afahu Ealayohi [which here has the meaning assigned to it above, as is shown by the explanation of the quasi-pass. tavab-aTa immediately following in the Ḳ: in the CK, we find, erroneously, waqafa Elyh]. (Ḳ, TA.)
4. AvbThu AlmaraDu The disease scarcely, or never, quitted him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5. tvb-T [quasi-pass. of 2, He became hindered, withheld, or prevented,, &c.; Eani AlOamori from the affair, or thing. This signification and that next following are well known.]
He paused, or waited; [EalaI AlOamori at the thing, or affair; as is implied in the Ḳ and TA;] syn. tawaq-afa. (Ḳ, TA.)
Q. Q. 3. AivobaOoTaTotu Eani AlOamori I held back, or hung back, from the affair, or thing, relinquishing it. (TA.)

vabiTN Stupid in his work, or action; and weak: heavy, sluggish, or slow; applied to a man, and to a horse; (Ḳ;) to the latter, with respect to covering: (TA:) and a man who will not move from his place: (TA:) fem. with p {vabiTapN}: (Ḳ:) and pl. [of pauc.] OavobaATN and [of mult.] vibaATN, (Ḳ,) and, applied to men, vabiTuwna also. (TA.)

1. vabana Alv-awoba, aor. _i {yavobinu}, inf. n. vabonN and vibaAnN, He folded the extremity of the garment, and sewed it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [he made a tuck in the garment, to shorten it;] like xabanahu: (Ṣ:) or, (Ḳ,) i. e. vabana, (TA,) he put a thing into the receptacle [thereof] and carried it before him; as also tvb-n↓: and in like manner, he folded and sewed over a thing the doubled upper border of his trousers in front: (Ḳ,* TA:) or tvb-n↓ XayoYFA has this last meaning; and signifies also he put a thing into a vibaAn [q. v.] and carried it before him: (Ṣ:) and vabana fiI vawobihi, aor. and inf. ns. as above; (M;) and Avbn↓ fiyhi, (M, Ḳ, as in the CK,) accord. to [some of] the copies of the Ḳ Avtbn, but the former is the right reading; (TA;) and vb-n↓; (M;) he put a thing into the receptacle [thereof] and carried it before him [in his garment]: (M, Ḳ:*) [see also Oaxobana:] or you say, vb-nhu↓ fiI vawobihi he made it a vibaAn (or thing carried [before him]) in his garment: (T:) and tvb-n↓ vibaAnFA he made a receptacle in which he [so] carried a thing before him. (T.)
2: see 1, in two places.
4: see 1.
5: see 1, in three places.
vubonapN: see what next follows, in four places.

vibaAnN A receptacle, such as when one folds the skirt of his shirt and puts in it a thing and carries it before him: (Ṣ:) or the part, of the garment, which is the place wherein one carries, when he wraps it around his body, or puts a portion thereof under his right shoulder and another portion over his left shoulder, then folds before him a part of it, and puts a thing in it; as also vubonapN↓: (M:) or the part, of one's garment, which is the place wherein he carries; folding its extremity, and sewing it, before him, and then putting in it some dates or other things: as also vabiynN↓ and vubonapN↓: (Ḳ:) and the extremity of the [garment called] ridaMC when one folds it before him and sews it [and puts a thing in it to carry]: (M:) or a receptacle in which one carries a thing before him; (T:) and vubonapN↓, of which the pl. is vubaAnN, (T,) or its pl. is vubanN, like as the pl of xubonapN [which has a similar meaning] is xubanN, (Ḥar p. 427,) the doubled upper border of the trousers or waist-wrapper, in which one carries [before him] fruit and other things: [see also xubonapN:] or, as some say, vibaAnN does not signify a receptacle, but dates that are put and carried in a receptacle or some other thing: and sometimes what a man carries in his sleeve; and vubonapN↓ signifies only what one carries before him, that is little in quantity: and what is great is not called vibaAnN. (T.) It is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, UicaA mar-a OaHadukumo biHaAYiTK faloyaOokulo minohu walaA yat-axico vibaAnFA [When any one of you passes by a garden of palm-trees, let him eat thereof, but not take for himself, or make, a vbAn]: i. e., when a necessitous hungry person passes by a man's garden of palm-trees, he may eat of their dates what will repel his hunger. (T. [See also another reading voce xubonapN.]) And one says, qadima fulaAnN bivibaAnK fiI vawobihi maA OadoriI maA huwa [Such a one came with a vbAn in his garment: I know not what it was]. (T.)
vabiynN: see vibaAnN.
mavobanapN A bag in which a woman puts her mirror and apparatus: (M, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (M.)
1. vabawotu lahu xayorFA baEoda xayorK, or Xar-FA, I sent him good after good, or evil [after evil]. (TA.) [See also 2.]

hom.sense: 2. tavobiyapN, [inf. n. of vb-I, mentioned in the T and Ḳ, in all its senses, in art. vbI, and so in the M, except in the first of the following senses, which is there mentioned in art. vbI and also in art. vbw,] The act of collecting (Ḳ, TA) in successive assemblages (vubapF vubapF↓). (TA.) You say, vb-Ahu He collected it, namely, a thing, (M,) and water: (M * and TA in art. vbw:) and he added to it, and collected it. (M, TA.)
The collecting what is good: and also, what is bad, or evil: thus bearing two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)

[And hence,] The praising a man in his life-time: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or praising him time after time in his life-time: (TA:) or praising him much; as though relating to him collections (vubaAt↓) of praise: (Z, TA;) or the mentioning of the sundry good qualities or actions: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and the magnifying [a person]; or honouring [him]. (T,* Ḳ.) You say, vb-I Alr-ajula, (M,) or vb-I EalaI Alr-ajuli, (T,) He praised the man in his life-time: (T, M:) because the doing so implies the collecting his good qualities or actions. (T,* M.)

[Hence also the contr. signification,] The blaming, or censuring, much; collecting blame, or censure, from this and that source. (TA. [The act. part. n. is rendered in the M agreeably with this explanation.])

The act of completing [and augmenting a thing]. (Ḳ.) You say, vab-i maEoruwfaka Complete and augment [thy beneficence, or bounty, or favour]. (T.) And vb-I Qll-ehu laka Aln-iEama [May God complete and augment to thee benefits, or blessings: or] may God send to thee benefits, or blessings. (TA.) [See also 1.]
The putting a thing into a good, right, or sound, state, and augmenting it. (T, Ḳ.*)
vb-I AlmaAla He kept, preserved, guarded, or took care of, the property. (Kr, M.)
vab-ayotu EalaI AlX-aIoCi, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) inf. n. tavobiyapN, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) I kept constantly, or perseveringly, to the thing. (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
The inf. n. signifies also The keeping, (T,) or pursuing, (Ḳ,) the way, course, mode of acting, or the like, of one's father: (T, Ḳ:) or the doing, or acting, like one's father. (M.)

Also The complaining of one's state, or case, and of one's want; and asking aid, or assistance, and vengeance, or avengement. (Ḳ.) [One of the meanings assigned to the verb by Golius, as on the authority of the Ḳ, and by Freytag after him, is Disposuit paravitque se:” app. from the former's having found AlAisotiEodaAdu written in a copy of the Ḳ for AlAisotiEodaMCu.]
OanaA OaEorifuhu tavobiyapF I know him, or it, with a seeming, not a certain, knowledge. (T, TA.)

entry.sense:
A company (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of men; (T, M;) as also Ouvobiy-apN↓; (M, Ḳ; [in the CK erroneously written Aavobiyap;]) and OuvoYiy-apN: (TA:) a company in a state of separation or dispersion; or a distinct body, or company, of men: (T:) and a troop of horsemen; such as is termed EuSobap: (M, Ḳ: [in the CK, AlEaSabapu is erroneously put for AlEuSobapu:]) the pl. is vubaAtN and vubuwna (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and vibuwna (Ṣ, M) and ( the pl. of Ouvobiy-apN, TA) OavaAbiI-u and OavaAbiyapN, in which last the p is a substitute for the last I [of OavaAbiI-u]: (M, TA:) or [accord. to some,] OavaAbiI-u, which signifies companies, has no sing.; but, as some say, its sing. is Oavobiy-apN↓, of the measure OufoEuwlapN, [originally OuvobuwyapN,] which means a numerous company: (Ḥam p. 796:)
[it is also said that] vubFI is a pl. of vubapN as meaning a company; (L in art. vwb, and Ḥam p. 271;) and hence the phrase Alv-ubaI AlEaAliI, for Alv-ubaI AlEaAliyapu, [the high, or exalted, companies,] the former word being made masc. because it is like zulamN [which is sing. and masc.]; but some say that this word here means the assemblies of the nobles: (Ḥam ubi suprá:) IAạr says, Alv-ubaI AlEaAliI mino majaAlisi AlOaXoraAfi; but [ISd observes,] this is extraordinary, and I have not heard it except in the poetry of El-Find Ez-Zimmánee. (M.) Accord. to some, it is from vaAba, being originally vuwbapN; and its dim. is vuwayobapN: (T:) or it is originally vubaIN: (Ṣ:) accord. to Er-Rághib, the letter elided from vubapN as meaning “a company,” but not as relating to a wateringtrough or tank, is I; and ISd holds it to be I: and [if so,] its dim. is vubay-apN↓: (TA:) [but ISd adds,] IJ says that the elided letter is w, because it is this in most cases, as in OabN and OaxN and sanapN and EiDapN, &c. (M in arts. vbw and vbI.) [See also art. vwb. It seems to signify also An assemblage, or a collection, of things of any kind:] see 2, in two places.

Also The middle of a wateringtrough or tank, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) to which the water returns [when it has been emptied], (Ṣ,) or to which what remains of the water returns: (T:) and the place where the water collects in a valley or low ground: (Aboo-Kheyreh, T:) but this is from vaAba; (T, Ṣ;*) the p is a substitute for the w, the medial radical, which is suppressed; for it is originally vuwabN: (Ṣ:) or it is originally vuwbapN: (T:) or it may be from vab-ayotu “I collected:” but Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ makes it to be from vaAba AlmaMCu, aor. yavuwbu; and this he infers to be the case from their saying that the dim. is vuwayobapN. (M.) [See also art. vwb.]
vabiI-N One who praises men much [while they are living: see 2]. (TA.)
vubay-apN: see vubapN, of which it is said to be the dim.
Ouvobiy-apN: see vubapN, in two places.
muvab-FI Property collected together. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1. vayotala, (Ḳ and TA, in the CK tavayotala,) He feigned himself stupid after feigning himself intelligent: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to some copies, after feigning himself negligent, or inadvertent: (tagaAful being put in the place of taEaAqul:) [app. from the subst. below:] but the word as mentioned by IAạr is tntl [app. a mistranscription for vanotala]. (TA.)

vayotalN The waEil [or mountain-goat], (M, Ḳ,) as a general term: (M:) [in the present day, but vulgarly pronounced tayotal, applied to the wild goat of the Arabian and Egyptian deserts and mountains; the capra jaela of Hamilton Smith; called by some an ibex; as is also badan:] or an old wEl: (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ:) or the male of the OarowaI: (Sh, T, M, Ḳ: [this is the same as the first explanation:]) En-Naḍr says that it has small horns: (T:) Aboo-Kheyreh, that it is of the wuEuwl, does not quit the mountain, and its horns have branches: (T, Mgh:*) he says that the wEwl are dusky, or dingy, or of a hue inclining to black and dust-colour, with whiteness in their lower parts; and the vayaAtil [pl. of vayotal] are like them in their colours, and only distinguished from them by the horns; the wEl having long horns, which extend backwards until they meet over his tail: (T:) also a species of [the bovine antelope called] baqaru AlwaHoXi, (M, Ḳ,) that abides in the mountains. (M.)
A man who sits with women. (TA.)
Incapable of going in to women; or not desirous of women. (Ḳ.)
A bulky, or corpulent, man, in whom one thinks there is good (AA, Ḳ, TA) when there is no good in him: (AA, TA:) but, as mentioned by Aṣ, it is tytl. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. vaj-a, (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yavojiju}, (A, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. vaj-N, (L, Mṣb, TA,) or vajiyjN, (A, TA,) or vujuwjN, (TA,) It (water) flowed: (Ḳ:) or poured forth vehemently, (A, Mṣb, TA,) or much: or, as some say, it (much water) poured forth: (L, TA:) and Anvj-↓ and tavajovaja↓ signify the same. (Ḳ.) vaj-N also signifies The flowing of the blood of a victim brought for sacrifice to the sacred territory of Mekkeh. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

vaj-ahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yavojuju}, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. vaj-N, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He made it to flow; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb Ḳ;) poured it forth; (Mṣb;) namely, water, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and blood (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb) of a victim for sacrifice; (Mgh, Mṣb;) as also vajovajahu↓; and Avj-hu↓ may also be used in the same sense. (TA.) Hence, (Mgh, Mṣb,) OafoDalu AlHaj-i AlEaj-u wAlv-aj-u, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) a saying of Moḥammad, (TA,) meaning The most excellent of the actions of the pilgrimage are (Mgh) the raising of the voice in the talobiyap [see 2 in art. lbI] and the shedding of the blood of the victims brought for sacrifice to the sacred territory. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
7: see 1.
R. Q. 1: see 1.
R. Q. 2: see 1.
Halaba fiyhi vaj-FA He milked into it milk abundantly flowing. (TA from a trad.)
vajuwjN A source yielding abundance of water. (TA.)
See also vaj-aAjN.
vajiyjN [originally an inf. n. (see 1)] A torrent, or flow. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the saying, OataAnaA AlwaAdiI bivajiyjihi [The valley brought us its torrent, or flow]. (Ṣ.)
The sound of the pouring forth of water. (TA.)
See also vaj-aAjN.

vaj-aAjN Water pouring forth vehemently: (Mṣb:) or poured forth; as also vajuwjN↓: (TA:) or flowing: (Ḥar p. 138:) or flowing much: (Id. p. 393:) and rain pouring forth vehemently; (Ṣ, TA;) as also vajiyjN↓ and mivaj-N↓: (TA:) and blood poured forth: (TA:) and a cloud pouring forth. (A.) Applied to water [or rain, and to blood,] it may have the meaning of a pass. part. n., or, which is preferable, that of an act. part. n. (IDrd, M.)

[Hence,] fulaAnN gayovuhu wabaHoruhu Eaj-aAjN ‡ [lit. Such a one, his rain is such as pours forth vehemently, and his sea is noisy, or copious: meaning such a one is abundant in bounty or munificence]. (A.)
mivaj-N: see vaj-aAjN.
Also, (Ḳ,) or xaTiybN mivaj-N, (A,) ‡ An eloquent, or able, speaker or orator; (Ḳ, TA;) who pours forth a copious flow of words. (TA.)

1. vajara, aor. _u {yavojuru}, He mixed the vajiyr of dates [i. e. the dregs of pressed dates] with other [dates] in the beverage called nabiyc: (Ṣ:) or he mixed the dregs of pressed unripe dates with dried dates in making nbyc: (Mgh:) or vajara Alt-amora he mixed the dried dates with the dregs of pressed unripe dates. (Ḳ.) The doing so is forbidden in a trad. (Ṣ, Mgh.)

vajiyrN, an arabicized word, (Mṣb,) pronounced by the vulgar with t, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) The dregs of anything that is pressed; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb;) as of pressed unripe dates: (Ḳ:) or the dregs of pressed unripe dates, which are mixed with dried dates in making the beverage called nabiyc: (TA:) or the expressed juice of dates; or the dregs of pressed dates: (Aṣ, Mṣb:) or pressed grapes from which the juice has run, and of which the dregs remain. (Lth, TA.)

1. vaxuna, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavoxunu}; (Ḳ;) and vaxana, (El-Aḥmar, ISd, Mṣb, TA,) aor. _u {yavoxunu}; (TA;) inf. n. vaxaAnapN (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and vuxuwnapN (ISd, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vixanN (Z, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vuxonN; (TA;) It (a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb) was, or became, thick, big, gross, or coarse; and hard, firm, stiff, tough, or strong: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it was, or became, thick, dense, or compact: (M, TA:) [it (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was thick, or close, in texture: (see vaxiynN:)] it [a semiliquid of any kind] was, or became, thick, so that it did not flow, nor continue in its passing away. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
4. Avxnhu [in its primary sense, He, or it, rendered it vaxiyn, i. e. thick,, &c.]

[And hence,] ‡ He, or it, (a man, JK, T, Mgh, Mṣb, and a wound, Ṣ, Mgh, and disease, Bḍ in viii. 68,) rendered him heavy: (JK, T, Bḍ ubi suprà, TA:) or weakened him, rendered him languid, or enervated him. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) You say, Avxnhu DarobFA † He rendered him heavy by beating: (JK:) or he beat him much, or vehemently, or excessively. (TA.) And Oavoxanotuhu biAljirAHapi † I weakened him, rendered him languid, or enervated him, by the wound, or wounds. (Mṣb.)

UicaA Oavoxanotumuwhumo, in the Ḳur xlvii. 4, means † When ye have made much slaughter among them: (Jel:) or when ye have made a great and vehement slaughter of them: (Bḍ:) or when ye have overcome them, and wounded them much, or inflicted many wounds upon them, (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, Ḳ, TA,) so that they give with their hands. (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, TA.)
Avxn fiI AlEaduw-i ‡ He made a great, or vehement, slaughter, (A,) or a great, or vehement, wounding, (Ḳ,) among the enemy. (A, Ḳ.)

Avxn fiI AlOaroDi, † He made much slaughter in the earth, or land: (Bḍ in viii. 68, Mgh, TA: in the Ṣ, Avxn fiI AlOaroDi qatolFA, which means the same: TA:) or he went against the enemy, and made a wide, or large, slaughter of them [in the land]: (Mṣb:) or he fought vehemently in the earth, or land. (Jel in viii. 68.)
Avxn fiI AlOamori † He exceeded the usual, or the just, bounds, or degree, in the affair; strove, or exerted himself, vigorously, or strenuously, therein; or did his utmost therein. (TA.)
Avxnhu quwoluhu † His saying took, or had, an effect upon him; or distressed, or afflicted, him. (TA.)
Oavoxanotu fulaAnFA maEorifapF ‡ I knew such a one, or was acquainted with him, thoroughly, or very well. (TA.)

8. Av-xn, in the saying of El-Asshà,
tamah-ala fiI AlHarobi Hat-aI Qv-axana
[He acted deliberately in war until he became heavy, or weakened, or languid, or enervated, by wounds], is contracted by idghám from Avotaxana. (Ṣ, TA.)
10. Astvxn minohu Aln-awomu ‡ Sleep overcame him. (JK, Ḳ, TA.) Astvxn bayona AlmaraDi waAlUiEoyaMCi ‡ He became overcome by [lit. between] disease and fatigue. (A, TA.)
vuxonN an inf. n. of vaxuna: [commonly used as a simple subst., meaning Thickness,, &c.:] one says vuwobN lahu vuxonN [A garment, or piece of cloth, having thickness, or closeness, of texture]. (TA.)

vaxanN i. q. nqlp [app. a mistranscription for vaqolapN or vaqalapN, meaning † A heaviness in the chest or body, or a heaviness and langour, or a heaviness on the heart]; as also vaxanapN↓: El-ʼAjjáj says,
Hat-aI yaEij-a vaxanFA mano EajoEajaA [app. meaning So that he who cries out cries out by reason of heaviness,, &c.]: (TA: [this saying is also cited in the Ṣ, in art. Ej; but there, in one copy, I find vaxinFA; and in another, vixanFA; and in both, mino instead of mano:]) and hence he received the surname of AlEaj-aAj: (Ṣ and TA in art. Ej:) so says IDrd. (TA in that art.) [Golius explains vaxanN as meaning “crassities, spissitudo;” on the anthority of Ibn-Maạroof and Ibn-Beytár; but I suspect that he found vaxanN in their works written for vuxonN or vixanN, both inf. ns. of vaxuna.]
vaxanapN: see vaxunN.

vaxiynN part. n. of vaxuna; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) Thick, big, coarse, or gross; and hard, firm, stiff, tough, or strong: (Ṣ:) [thick, dense, or compact:, &c.: see 1: pl. vixaAnN.] You say vawobN vaxiynN A garment, or piece of cloth, thick, or close, or full, in texture, and, as Az adds, in warp. (TA.)
Applied to a man, Completely armed: (KL:) or vaxiynu Als-ilaAHi has this meaning. (Ṣ.)
Also (JK, TA) ‡ Forbearing, clement, grave, sedate, or calm: (JK, Ḳ,* TA: [in some copies of the Ḳ, AlHakiymu is erroneously put for AlHaliymu:]) in the M, heavy in his sitting-place. (TA.)
[muvoxanN pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. You say, tarakotuhu muvoxanFA waqiycFA [I left him weakened, languid, enervated, or much wounded; beaten until he was at the point of death]. (TA.)
† Forbearing, clement, grave, sedate, or calm, in mind, or intellect. (TA.) [See also vaxiynN.]
Metonymically applied by the people of Syria to ‡ One who causes laughter; who is quick, brisk, or lively, in his motions. (TA.)
muvoxinN † One who exceeds the usual, or the just, bounds, or who does his utmost, in narration, and in the rehearsal of sayings. (TA.)
And, with p {muvoxinapN}, ‡ A large, corpulent, fleshy, woman. (JK, A, Ḳ.)

vunoduWapN and vanoduWapN, (M,) or vanoduwapN, (Lth, T,) or vunoduwapN, of the measure funoEulapN, with damm to the f and E, or, accord. to some, the n is radical and the w augmentative, the measure being fuEoluwapN, (Mṣb in art. vdI,) or vunoduWapN and vanoduwapN, (ISk, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with damm to the v if with C, (ISk, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and of the measure fuEolulapN, (ISk, Ṣ,) and with fet-ḥ to the v if with w, without C, (ISk, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and in this case of the measure faEoluwapN, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) like qaronuwapN and EaroquwapN, (ISk, Ṣ,) [the n in both cases, accord. to ISk, being radical,] so in the Bári', (Mṣb,) and so says Ḳṭr, (TA,) but AʼObeyd says that the Arabs in general pronounced the word without C, (Mṣb,) The vadoI [which generally signifies the breast, or mamma, but sometimes the pap, or mamilla,] of a man: (Mgh:) or the part, of a man, that corresponds to the vadoI of a woman: (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the flesh of the vadoI: (Lth, T, M, Mgh:) or the flesh that is around the vadoI: (ISk, T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the base of the vadoI: (Aṣ, Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán,” Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL *:) or the portion of flesh that is at the base thereof: (Mṣb:) or i. q. vadoIN: (TA:) and the pap, or mamilla, of a woman and of a man: (KL:) accord. to the author of the Wáʼee, the pl. [of tndWp] is vanaAdihu, [with h substituted for C, unless the former be a mistranscription for the latter,] (TA,) and [that of vndwp is] vanaAdK. (Mṣb, TA.) The word vdI is used in relation to men in the Saheeh of Muslim, and vndWp in relation to women in the Sunan of Aboo-Dáwood; and many of the lexicologists incline to the opinion that vdI is common to men and women. (MF in art. vnd.)
vunoduWapu AlOanofi, occurring in a trad., The tip, or fore part, of the nose. (IAth, TA.)
1. vadaAhu, aor. _u {yavoduwu}: see art. vdI.

hom.sense: 1. vadiIa, aor. _a {yavodaIu}, It became moist or moistened. (T, Ḳ.) vadiyati AlOaroDu i. q. sadiyat [The land became moistened by much dew]: mentioned by Yaạḳoob, who asserts that the v in the former is a substitute for the s in the latter; but is not known. (M.)
vadaAhu, aor. _u {yavoduIu} (T, Ḳ) and _i {yavodiIu}, (T,) He moistened it. (T, Ḳ.)

And vdAhu [so in the TT, as form the T, without. teshdeed,] He fed him, or nourished him: (T, TT:) [or the verb in this sense is vd-Ahu↓, for its inf. n.] tavodiyapN signifies the act of feeding, or nourishing. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

vadoIN (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and vidoIN and vadFI: (Ḳ:) the first of these is the form most commonly obtaining: (TA:) [The breast, or mamma;] the part of the chest whereof the Halamap is the head; each of the two parts whereof the HalamataAni are the two heads: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) [and sometimes, but not properly, the Halamap alone; i. e., the pap, nipple, or mamilla:] you say vadoI muqoEadN a breast that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ, in art. qEd,) that fills the hand, (A in that art.,) and has not yet become folding: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, in that art.:) and raDaEa vadoIa Oum-ihi [he sucked the breast, meaning the pap, or nipple, of his mother]. (IḲṭṭ in TA, art. rDE:) it is peculiar to woman; (T, Ḳ;) or common to woman and man; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) being sometimes used in relation to a man; (Mṣb;) accord. to the opinion held to be most chaste and best known by the lexicologists [in general]: (TA:) and is masc.; (T, M, Mgh;) or masc. and fem.; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but most chastely masc.: (TA;) the pl. [of pauc.] is OavodK, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [originally OavoduIN,] of the measure OafoEulN, (Mṣb,) and [of mult.] vudiI-N, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [originally vuduwIN,] of the measure fuEuwlN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and vidiI-N, with kesr to the v because of the kesr to the letter following, (Ṣ,) and sometimes vidaMCN, [originally vidaAIN,] like sihaAmN; (Mṣb;) and a poet says,
waOaSobaHati Aln-isaMCu musal-ibaAtK
lahun-a Alwayolu yamodudona Alv-udiynaA
[And the women became widowed, or bereft of relations, and without their ornaments, or in mourning, having woe, pulling the breasts]; but this is something like a mistake; and it may be that he meant Alt-udiy-aA, and changed the [latter] I into n for the sake of the rhyme. (M.) It is said in a prov., tujaw-aEu AlHur-apu walaA taOokulu vadoyayohaA, meaning, Oujorapa vadoyayohaA, [i. e. The ingenuous woman will be made to hunger and will not eat the hire of her breasts,] the prefixed noun being suppressed; or, as some relate it, bivadoyayohaA, which is plain [as meaning, by means of her breasts]: it is applied in relation to a man's preserving himself from ignoble means of acquiring wealth. (Mgh.) And jud-a vadoIu Oum-ihi, May his mother's breast be cut off, is a form of imprecation against a man, and used to imply a wish for his separation. (Aṣ, L in art. jd.)
The saying of ʼAlee, on the day of his slaughter of the Khawárij, AunoZuruwA faUin-a fiyihmo rajulFA UiHodaI yadayohi mivolu vadoIi AlmaroOapi [Look ye, for among them is a man one of whose arms is like the breast of the woman], not AHdI vadoyayohi as some relate it, was applied to a man who had, in the place of one arm, a lump of flesh upon his shoulder-joint, which lump, when it was stretched, became equal in length to his other arm, and when it was left, returned [to its original form]. (Mgh.) Respecting vuday-apN↓, the dim., whence the surname caw Alv-uday-api, he who holds vadoIN to be masc. [only] says that the p is added because the word [virtually] means Alyad, [which is fem.,] for the man thus surnamed had a short arm, of the size of the vadoI, as is indicated by the fact that they also called him cuw Alyuday-api: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to Fr, (AʼObeyd, T,) p is added, in this instance, in the dim., though vadoIN is masc., because it applies to what resembled the remains (baqiy-ap) of a vadoI, the greater part of it having gone, so that it is like luHamoyapN and XuHayomapN [dims. of laHomapN and XaHomapN]: (T, M:) or the p is added because the word is regarded in this case as meaning AlbaDoEapu [the piece, or lump, of flesh]: (Mgh:) some say that it is the dim. of vanoduwapN; (Mgh, TA;) but this requires consideration. (Mgh.)
vuday-apN: see vadoIN.

Also A repository, or receptacle, (AA, Ḳ,) of the size of the fist, (AA,) in which the horseman carries the [sinews called] Eaqab [of which the bow-string is made, and which are bound round a bow, and round an arrow, to repair a fracture in it, (see EaqabN and Eaqaba,)] and the feathers [which he may require to attach to any of his arrows]. (AA, Ḳ.)
vud-aMCN A certain plant [growing] in the desert. (Ṣ.)
vadoyaMCu A woman large in the vadoyaAni [or breasts]: OavodaI, the masc. form, is not used. (Ṣ, M.)
vanoduwapN, [written by some vunoduwapN, as well as vanoduWapN and vanoduWapN,] mentioned here in the Ṣ, and in art. vdO: see the latter art.
1. varabahu, aor. _i {yavoribu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. varobN, (TḲ,) [probably, in its primary sense, He stripped it of its varob: see 2:]
[and hence,] † He stripped him of his garment; namely, a sick man. (Ḳ.)
See also 2, in three places.

hom.sense: 2. tavoriybN, in its primary sense, is The removing of the varob, i. e., the fat that forms the integument of the stomach of a ruminant: so says Z. (Ḥar p. 197.)

And hence, ‡ The act of blaming; reproving; and punishing, or chastising, for an offence, or a crime: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) or ‡ severe blaming or reproving, that rends reputations, and takes away the brightness of countenances: (Z in Ḥar ubi suprá:) which last meaning it has in the Ḳur xii. 92: (Bḍ:) or laA tavoriyba Ealayokumo there means † No evil, or mischief, shall come upon you: (Zj, T:) or † your offences, or crimes, shall not be mentioned: (Th, M:) tvryb signifies † the act of blaming, or reproving; (Ṣ, Mgh;) or doing so severely, or angrily; or, with the utmost severity or harshness: the act of upbraiding, or reproaching: and the going to the utmost length in blaming or reproving: one says, laA tavoriyba Ealayoka † [No blame,, &c., shall be laid on thee]: and it is from Alv-arobu [as explained above]. (Ṣ.) You say, vr-b and varaba↓ and Avrb↓, meaning † He blamed, or reproved; or did so severely, or with the utmost severity; or reproached, or upbraided: (T:) and vr-b Ealayohi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and v-rbhu; (A, Ḳ;) and varabahu↓, [and varaba Elyh,] aor. _i {yavoribu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. varobN; (TḲ;) and Avrbhu↓; (A, Ḳ;) † he blamed him, or reproved him; upbraided him, or reproached him, (M, A, Ḳ,) with, or for, his offence, or crime; (M, Ḳ;) and reminded him thereof; (M;) he showed him his deed to be foul, abominable, or bad: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or varaba↓ Elyh, aor. _i {yavoribu} signifies † he blamed him, or reproved him; and, as Suh says, vr-b Elyh, † he blamed him, or reproved him, much. (Mṣb.)
Also † The acting ill, or corruptly; doing evil, or mischief; creating confusion, or disorder. (TA.)
It is also said in the Ḳ to be syn. with TaI-N, which means The building [or casing a well] with stones: but [SM says,] I fear that this is a mistranscription for tavowiybN, with w. (TA.)
4. He (a ram) increased in his fatness: (Ḳ:) or acquired a varob, having increased in fatness. (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.

entry.sense: varobN A thin integument of fat that covers the stomach of a ruminant and the bowels or intestines; (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the fat that is spread over the bowels, or intestines: (T:) pl. (of mult., TA) vuruwbN (M, Ḳ) and (of pauc., TA) OavorubN, and pl. pl. OavaAribu. (Ḳ.) Hence, SaArati AlX-amosu kaQloOavaAribi The sun [upon the ground] became like the integuments above-mentioned: i. e., scattered; being upon one place and not upon another, towards sunset: a phrase occurring in a trad., in which it is said that when this is the case, it is forbidden to perform the afternoonprayer: and in another trad. occurs the phrase, SaArati AlX-amosu kavarobi Aln-aAqapi [The sun upon the ground became like the vrb of the she-camel]. (TA.)
And [hence,] † A land of which the stones are such as those of the Har-ap [q. v.], save that they are white. (L.)
varabaAtN, (Ḳ,) or varibaAtN [like taribaAtN, with which it is nearly, or perhaps exactly, syn.], (M,) The fingers. (M, Ḳ.)
Oavorabu, (TA,) fem. varobaMCu, (T, Ḳ,) A sheep having a large varob; (T, TA;) i. e. (TA) a fat sheep. (Ḳ, TA.)
muvoribN † One who gives little, (Ḳ, TA,) reproaching for that which he has given. (TA.)
muvar-ibN Upbraiding [&c.: see the verb, 2]: (M:) or acting ill, or corruptly; doing evil, or mischief; creating confusion, or disorder. (M, Ḳ.)

1. varada, aor. _u {yavorudu}, (M, L,) or _i, (so in one place in the TT,) inf. n. varodN, (T, M, Mgh, L,) He broke a dry or hollow thing: (T, Mgh, L:) he crumbled a thing, or broke it into small pieces, with his fingers. (M, L.) [Hence,] varada xubozFA, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavorudu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He crumbled bread, or broke it into small pieces, with his fingers, (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) then moistened it with broth, (A, Mṣb,) and then piled it up in the middle of a bowl: (A:) or he broke bread: (Ṣ:) and in like manner Ait-aradahu↓, originally Aivotaradahu; and Aiv-aradahu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and Av-rd↓ variydFA, and At-rdhu↓, he made, or prepared, vryd [i. e. bread crumbled, &c. as above described]. (M.)
He rubbed and pressed a testicle with the hand, in lieu of castrating; (Ḳ;) inf. n. as above. (Mgh.)
See also 2.
He dipped a garment, or piece of cloth, in dye: (Ḳ:) he dyed it with saffron [&c.]. (TA from a trad.)

vurida mina AlmaEorakapi, (so in a copy of the T, and in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the CK,) or vur-ida↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA,) He (a man, IAạr, T) was carried away from the place of fight wounded much but having life remaining in him. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

2. vr-d, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tavoriydN; (T, Ṣ, Mgh;) and varada↓; (Ḳ;) [ISd says,] I think that the latter is a dial. var. of the former; (M;) He killed an animal that should be slaughtered without cutting the OawodaAj [or external jugular veins] so as to make the blood flow; (M, Ḳ;) i. e., (TA,) he killed it with a blunt knife, so that he broke, [or tore, the flesh, &c.,] and did not cut so as to make the blood flow: (A, TA:) or he killed it by squeezing and pressing the AwdAj, without cutting, and making the blood to flow: (Mgh:) or he killed it with a thing that did not make the blood to flow freely: or he killed it without practising the method prescribed by the law: (T:) or tvryd in slaughtering is the breaking [the bones or joints, &c. of the animal] before it is cold; and this is forbidden. (Ṣ.) [See also muvar-idN.]
See also 1, last sentence.
And see varadN, below.
[4. It seems that Golius found Oavorada erroneously written in a copy of the Ṣ and in a copy of the Ḳ for Aiv-arada.]
8. Aiv-arada and Ait-arada: see 1, in four places.
varodN Weak rain. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.)
varadN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and tavoriydN↓ (A) ‡ A chapping in the lips. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
vurodapN: see what next follows.
variydN and mavoruwdN↓ Bread crumbled, or broken into small pieces, with the fingers, and then moistened with broth: (Mṣb:) or [simply] broken bread. (Ṣ.)

Also, the former, (T, A,) and variydapN↓ (T, M, A, Ḳ) and vurodapN↓ (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb) and varuwdapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and mavoruwdapN↓ (Ḳ accord. to the TA) and OuvorudaAnN↓, (Fr, M,* Ḳ,) Bread, itself, crumbled, or broken into small pieces, with the fingers, (T,* Ṣ,* M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) then moistened with broth (T, A, Mṣb), &c., (T,) and then piled up in the middle of a bowl; (A;) generally having some flesh-meat with it: (L:)
or variydapN↓ signifies a mess, or portion, of variyd [or bread crumbled or broken, &c.]; (T;) [and so varuwdapN↓, and mavoruwdapN↓:] that of Ghassán is said by common consent to have been prepared with marrow, and with eggs, or the yolks of eggs; and there was no kind more delicious than these two kinds. (TA.) The pl. of vrydp is varaAYidu and vurudN and vurodN; (A, and Ḥam p. 524;) the last of which is a contraction of that next preceding it. (Ḥam ubi suprà.) A poet, as cited by IAạr, says,
OalaA yaA xubozu yaA Qbonapa yavorudaAnK↓
OabaI AlHuloquwmu baEodaki laA yanaAmu
[Now surely, O bread, O daughter of two preparers of variyd, the throat refuses, after swallowing thee, to rest, by reason of desire for more]: he says that the poet calls the bread after two young men, or slaves, who were preparing vryd, and gives tenween to yvrdAn by a poetic license, instead of saying yavorudaAni, which, as it is [originally] a verbal phrase, he should have said by rule: but the word, as Fr relates it, is OuvorudaAnK↓; and [ISd says,] I think that this is a determinate subst., for Alv-ariyd or Almavoruwd, and therefore properly imperfectly decl., but here made perfectly decl. by a poetic license. (M.) It is said in a trad. that the excellence of ʼÁïsheh above other women is as the excellence of vryd above other kinds of food; but it is said that what is here meant is food prepared with flesh-meat, together with vryd, because this is generally prepared with flesh-meat, and it is said to be one of the two things called laHom. (TA.)
varuwdapN: see variydN; for each, in two places.
variydapN: see variydN; in two places.
OuvorudaAnN: see variydN; in two places.
mivoradapN A [bowl such as is called] qaSoEap [app. for variyd]. (TA.)

muvar-idN One who slaughters (an animal intended to be slaughtered, M) with a stone or a bone, (M, Ḳ,) or the like thereof; to do which is forbidden: (M:) or one whose iron instrument is not sharp, (IAạr, M, Ḳ,) so that he mangles the flesh. (IAạr, M.)
mivoraAdN A stone, or bone, or blunt iron instrument, with which an animal is slaughtered [in a bungling manner: see muvar-idN]. (M, Ḳ.)
mavoruwdN: see variydN.
Also A garment, or piece of cloth, dipped in dye. (ISh, T.)
mavoruwdapN: see variydN, in two places.
yavorudaAn: see variydN.

hom.sense: 1. varima, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yavoramu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. varamN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) He (a man, T, Ṣ, Mṣb) had one of his central incisors broken: (AZ, T, Mṣb:) or he had a central incisor fallen out: (Ṣ:) or he had a tooth broken out entirely; (M, Ḳ;) or one of his fore teeth, such as the central incisors and the teeth between the central incisors and the canine teeth; (M, Ḳ;*) or, peculiarly, a central incisor: as also Anvrm↓. (M, Ḳ.)

varamahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yavorimu}, (M, Ḳ,) or _u, (Mṣb,) inf. n. varomN; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) and Avrmhu↓; (T, M, Ḳ;) He (a man, T, Ṣ, Mṣb) broke one of his central incisors: (T, Mṣb:) or rendered him Oavoram: (M, Ḳ:) or the former, he struck him on his mouth, so that one of his central incisors fell out: and ↓the latter, He (God) rendered him Oavoram. (Ṣ.) And varamotu vaniy-atahu I broke his central incisor. (T, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.
7: see 1.
Also Anvrmt vaniy-atuhu His central incisor became broken. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb.)

Oavoramu, applied to a man, Having one of his central incisors broken: (T, Mṣb:) or having a central incisor fallen out, (Ṣ, and Ḥam p. 613,) so as to have a gap between two of his teeth: (Ḥam ib.:) or having a tooth broken out entirely; (M, Ḳ;) or one of his fore teeth, such as the central incisors and the teeth between the central incisors and the canine teeth; (M, Ḳ;*) or, peculiarly, a central incisor: (M, Ḳ:) fem. varomaMCu: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. vuromN. (Mṣb.)
AlOavoramaAni † Night and day: (M, Ḳ:) and † time, or fortune, and death. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. varaA Alqawomu, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavoruwu}; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) and variIa; (T, TT;) inf. n. varFA; (M;) The people, or company of men, became many, much, or great in number or quantity; and increased: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and in like manner, AlmaAlu, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) i. e., the cattle, or other property, became many, much, or great in number or quantity. (Aṣ, Ṣ, M.)

variIa, (T, M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yavorawu}, inf. n. varoIN [or varFA?] and varaMCN, (T, TA,) He (a man, T, Ḳ) was, or became, abundant in cattle, or other property; (T, M, Ḳ;) as also AvrI↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and OaforaI: (M:) or AvrI↓ signifies he was, or became, in a state of competence or sufficiency, in no need, or rich; syn. AstgnI: (Mṣb:) or it signifies more than AstgnI: (T:) and variytu bika, I became, or have become, abundant [in property] by means of thee: (T, Ṣ:) and variytu bifulaAnK I became in no need of other men by means of such a one. (T, Ṣ, M.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, El-Kumeyt, praising the Benoo-Umeiyeh,
lakumo masojidaA Qll-ehi AlmazuwraAni waAlHaSaI
lakumo qiboSuhu mino bayoni OavoraI↓ waOaqotaraA
[Ye have the two visited mosques of Mekkeh and El-Medeeneh, and ye have the number of the pebbles of such as are between him who is wealthy and him who is poor]: he means, mino bayoni mano OavoraI wamano Oaqotara; i.e., mino bayoni muvorK wamuqotirK. (Ṣ.)

variytu bika, (T,) or bihi, inf. n. varFA, (M,) also signifies I rejoiced (T, M) in thee, (T,) or in him, or it: (M:) and variIa bicelika, aor. _a {yavorawu}, He rejoiced in, or by reason of, that. (ISk, Ṣ.)
varawonaAhumo We were, or became, more than they: (AA, Ṣ, M:) or more in cattle, or other property. (Ḳ.)
varaA Alqawoma He (God) made the people, or company of men, to be many, or numerous; multiplied them. (AA, T, Ṣ.)
4: see 1, in three places.
laA yuvoriynaA AlEaduw-u The enemy will not say much respecting us. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: varFA; dual varawaAni: see varFI, in art. vrI.

hom.sense: varK: see variI-N.
OanaA varK bihi I am in no need of other men by means of him; (T, Ṣ, M;) as also variI-N↓. (M.)
See also art. vrI.

entry.sense: varowapN Many, or a great number, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of men; and of cattle, or other property: (M, Ḳ:) or much, or a great quantity, or property; (Mgh, Mṣb;) as also varaMCN↓: (Ṣ, M,* Mgh:) and farowapN signifies the same as varowapN; the f being a substitute for the v. (M.) One says, Uin-ahu lacuw varowapK wacuw varaMCK↓, (ISk, Ṣ,) or Uin-ahu lacuw varaMCK↓ wavarowapK, (T,) Verily he possesses a number [of men] and much property. (ISk, T, Ṣ.) Accord. to IAạr, one says vaworapN mino rijaAlK and varowapN, meaning A great number of men: but only varowapN mino maAlK. (TA.)
Also The night of the conjunction of the moon and Alv-uray-aA [or the Pleiades]. (M, Ḳ.)
varowaAnu, fem. varowaI: see variI-N.
varaMCN: see varowapN, in three places.
Also A state of competence or sufficiency; or richness. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: variI-N Many, or numerous; [applied to a company of men;] and so variy-apN applied to spears (rimaAHN): (TA:) also many, or much, cattle, or other property; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) and so varK↓. (T, TA.)

Also A man possessing many, or much, cattle, or other property; and so OavoraI↓; (M, Ḳ;) and muvorK↓: (T:) so too varowaAnu↓; (T, Ṣ, Mgh;) or abounding (M, Ḳ, TA) in cattle, or other property: (TA:) and [its fem.] varowaI↓, applied to a woman, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) likewise signifies possessing many, or much, cattle, or other property: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the dim. of this last is vuray-aA↓. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
See also varK.
And see art. vrI.

entry.sense: vuray-aA: see variI-N.

Alv-uray-aA [The Pleiades; the Third Mansion of the Moon: it is believed to be the most beneficial, in its influences on the weather, of all the Mansions of the Moon, on account of the period of its auroral setting, which, in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, began on the 12th of Nov., O. Ṣ.: (see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl; and see also nawoCN:) hence what is said of it in Job xxxviii. 31; and hence, as being the most excellent of all asterisms, it is called by the Arabs] Aln-ajomu [the Asterism]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the former appellation is given to it because it comprises, in appearance, many stars in a small space; (M, Ḳ;*) for it is said that amid its conspicuous stars are many obscure stars; (IAth, TA;) the number altogether being said to be four and twenty, agreeably with an assertion of the Prophet: some say that it is so called because of the abundance [of the rain] of its nawNC [here meaning auroral setting]: (TA:)
the word is thus applied only in the dim. form, which is used in this instance to denote magnification. (M, TA.)

[vuray-aA also signifies ‡ A cluster of lamps, generally resting in holes in the bottom of a lantern: see an engraving in my “Modern Egyptians,” ch. vi.] The vuray-aA of lamps is so called as being likened to the asterism above mentioned. (M.)

hom.sense: OavoraI: see variI-u:
and see also art. vrI.
muvorK: see variI-u:
and see also art. vrI.

entry.sense: muvoraApN A cause of multiplying, or rendering abundant; syn. makovarapN: so in the saying, hecaA mavoraApN lilomaAli [This is a cause of multiplying, or rendering abundant, cattle, or other property]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OanaA mavoriI-u bihi I am rejoiced in him. (ISk, TA in art. vrI.)
See also art. vrI.

1. variyati AlOaroDu, aor. _a {yavoraIu}, inf. n. varNI, The earth, or land, became moist and soft, after drought and dryness: (M, Ḳ:) or became watered by rain that penetrated to its moistness. (Mṣb.)
See also the same form of the verb in the first paragraph {1} of art. vrw, in six places.

2. vr-I, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tavoriyapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He moistened (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) a place, (T,) or earth, or the ground, or dust, (M, Ḳ,) and sawiyq [or meal of parched barley or wheat], (Ṣ, TA,) and any other thing: (TA:) he sprinkled a place: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he poured water upon, and then stirred about, and mixed up, [the preparation of milk termed] OaqiT, (M, Ḳ,) and sawiyq. (M.)
He made his hands to cleave to the ground (T, Ḳ) between the two prostrations in prayer, not separating them therefrom until he performed the second prostration. (T.)

entry.sense: 4. AvrI It (rain) moistened the earth. (Ṣ.)
Oavorati AlOaroDu The land, or earth, had much moisture; became abundant in moisture: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it became compact with moisture. (AḤn, M.) [See also muvorK.]

varFI Moisture; humidity; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) of the earth: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and moist earth; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) turaAb that is not moist is not called varFI; (Mṣb;) or such as, when moistened, does not become cohesive mud or clay; (M, Ḳ;) as also varoyaMCu↓ [an epithet used as a subst.]: (AO, T,* Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, varayAC:]) and the earth;; (M, Ḳ) maA taHota Alv-araI, in the Ḳur [xx. 5], being explained as meaning what is beneath the earth: (M:) Alv-araI and * OavoraI both signify the earth; and the latter, being thus used as a proper name, is imperfectly decl.: (Ḥam p. 351:) dual varayaAni (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and varawaAni: (Lḥ, M, Ḳ: [but the sing. of the latter should be written varFA:]) pl. OavoraMo. (M, Ḳ.) AilotaqaI Alv-arayaAni [The two moistures met, or have met,] is said when the rain has sunk into the ground so that it has met the moisture of the earth. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) Accord. to IAạr, it was also said by a man, (M,) or by an Arab of the desert, (Ḳ,) who, (M, Ḳ,) being naked, (Ḳ,) clad himself with a fur-garment, (M, Ḳ,) without a shirt; (M;) meaning the hair of the pubes and the soft hair of the fur-garment. (M, Ḳ.) And the Arabs say, XahorN varaI waXahorN taraI waXahorN maroEaI waXahorN QsotawaI, meaning A month [of moisture] in which the rain begins, and sinks into the ground, and moistens and softens the earth; for XahorN cuw varFI: and a month in which thou seest the heads of the herbage grown forth; for XahorN taraI fiyhi ruWuwsa Aln-abaAti: and a month in which the herbage is tall enough to be pastured upon by the cattle: (Aṣ, Ṣ,* M:) and a month in which it is full-grown and erect. (Aṣ, M.) One says also, badaA varaI AlmaMCi mina Alfarasi, meaning The sweat of the horse appeared. (Ṣ,* M.) And Uin-iI laOaraI varaI AlgaDabi fiI wajohi fulaAnK, meaning † Verily I see the effect of anger in the face of such a one. (T.) And huwaQbonu varaAhaA † He is the knowing with respect to it. (T in art. bnI.)
