[Hence, as being likened to moist earth,] i. q. xayorN † [Good; anything good;, &c.]. (M, Ḳ. [For xayor, Golius appears to have found, in a copy of the Ḳ, Hayoz; and this, which he has rendered “Terræ tractus,” he has given as a signification, not of varFI, but of varaMCN, which, like varFI, he also explains as meaning “terra.”]) So in the saying, fulaAnN qariybu Alv-araI [app. meaning † Such a one is a person from whom good is easy of attainment: or it may mean, a person from whom good seems to be easy of attainment: in either case likened to land of which the moist earth is near the surface: that the phrase may have the latter meaning appears from what here follows]. (M.) You say, Uin-a fulaAnFA laqariybu Alv-ariI baEiydu Aln-abaTi, meaning † Verily such a one is a person who promises but who does not fulfil. (IAạr, T.)

[Hence also, † Fresh and vigorous friendship.] You say, lamo yabobasi Alv-araI bayoniI wabayonahu † [The fresh and vigorous friendship between me and him has not withered]: whence the phrase, maA bayoniI wabayona fulaAnK * muvorK † [That friendship which is between me and such a one is fresh and vigorous]; i. e., it has not ceased, or become severed. (Ṣ,* M.) Jereer says,
falaA tuwbisuwA bayoniI wabayonakumu Alv-araI
faUin-a Al-acaI bayoniI wabayonakumu muvoriI↓
[And wither not the fresh and vigorous friendship between me and you; for that which is between me and you is fresh and vigorous]. (Ṣ, M.)

hom.sense: varK, [fem. variyapN, Moist; humid.] You say OaroDN variyapN, (M, Mṣb,) like EamiyapN, (Mṣb,) or variy-apN↓, like ganiy-apN, (Ḳ, [but this is anomalous, as part. n. of variyat,]) and varoyaMCu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) Earth, or land, that has become moist and soft, after drought and dryness: (M, Ḳ:) or watered by rain that has penetrated to its moistness: (Mṣb:) or the last, land of just, or moderate, moisture: (AḤn, M:) or moist land; (T, Ṣ, M;) and so the first. (M.) And makaAnN varoyaAnu↓ A place of which the earth has in it moisture. (TA.) And yawomN variI-N↓ A humid day. (TA.)
See also art. vrw.
variI-N, fem. variy-apN: see varK, in two places:
and see also art. vrw.

entry.sense: varoyaMCu: see varK:
and see also varFI.
varoyaAnu: see varK.
vuray-aA: see art. vrw.

hom.sense: OavoraI: see varFI:
and see also art. vrw.
[muvorK, fem. muvoriyapN, part. n. of 4, q. v.] OaroDN muvoriyapN [is explained as meaning] Land of which the earth has not become dry. (T, TA.)
See also varFI, last two sentences.
And see art. vrw.
mavoriI-u a pass. part. n. having no verb; used as an intensive epithet in the phrase varFI mavoriI-N [Very moist earth]. (M.)
See also art. vrw.

entry.sense: 1. vaT-a, aor. _a {yavoTaTu}; (Lth, TA;) [app. accord. to him who says rajulN OavaT-u; for Lth adds,] and, accord. to him who says rajulN vaTN, (Lth, TA,) vaT-a, aor. _i {yavoTiTu} and _u {yavoTuTu}; (Lth, Ḳ;) inf. n. [of vaT-a of which the aor. is _a {yavoTaTu},] vaTaTN, (Lth, IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and [of the verb of which the aor. is _i {yavoTiTu},] vaT-N, and [of that of which the aor. is _u {yavoTuTu}, the second pers. of the pret. being app. vaTuTota,] vaTaATapN and vuTuwTapN; (Lth, Ḳ;) or the last two, accord. to IDrd, are simple substs., and ISd approves of this distinction; (TA;) He (a man, Lth, Ṣ) was, or became, such as is termed vaT-N and OavaT-u [explained below]. (Lth, IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: vaT-N and OavaT-u↓, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) but the former is the more correct and the more common, (Lth,) or the former only, (IDrd, and IB on the authority of Ibn-El-Jawáleeḳee, and Ḳ,) the latter being vulgar, (IDrd, Ḳ,) but AZ asserted his having heard the latter, (AḤát, cited in the Jm,) [and the latter only is mentioned in the Mgh,] A man (Ṣ, Mgh) having no hair upon the sides of his face, but only upon his chin; syn. kawosajN: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or having a scanty beard: (IDrd:) or the former signifies having little hair in the beard, and in the eyebrows: (Ḳ:) or [when you mean the latter] you say rajulN vaT-u AlHaAjibayoni, (Ḳ,) a man having thin, or scanty, eyebrows; as also OavaT-u↓ AlHaAjibayoni; (TA;) the mention of the eyebrows being indispensable; (IAạr, Ḳ;) and AimoraOapN vaT-apu AlHaAjibayoni [a woman having thin, or scanty, eyebrows]: (Ṣ TA:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OavoTaATN (Kr, Ḳ) and (of mult., TA) vuT-aAnN and viTaTapN (AZ, Ḳ) and vuTuTN, (IAạr,) [all of which may be of either sing.,] and viTaATN, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is of the former sing., (Ṣ,) and vuT-N, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is of the latter. (Ṣ.) You say also AimoraOapN vaT-aMCu↓ A woman having no Uisob, (Lth, TA,) i. e. hair on the pubes; in the copies of the Ḳ incorrectly written Aisot. (TA.) And EaAriDN OavaT-u↓ A side of the cheek, or of the face, having the hair falling off. (Mgh.)
Also, the former, Heavy in the belly; (Ḳ, TA;) slow; applied to a man. (TA.)
The former also signifies Human excrement or ordure; or thin human excrement or ordure; syn. saloHN. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [See also valoTN.]

entry.sense: OavaT-u, and its fem. vaT-aMCu: see vaT-N, in four places.

Alv-aT-aMCu also signifies The spider: or another creeping thing, that stings, or bites, vehemently: (Ḳ:) this is from Lth, as in the O and L: but in the Tekmileh we find Alv-aT-aMCu, like Xaf-aMC, [app. a mistake for Alv-iTaMCu, like XifaMC,] a certain small creeping thing: or, as some say, it is Alv-aTaA, of the measure of qafFA. (TA.)

1. vaEabahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yavoEabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. vaEobN, (Ṣ,) He gave vent to it; or made it to flow forth, run, or stream; namely, water, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and blood, and the like. (Ḳ.) vEb damFA, [thought by MF to be vaEaba, but I see no reason why it should not be vaEaba,] said of a wound, means It flowed, or ran, with blood. (TA.)
7. AnvEb It (water) had vent; or it flowed forth, ran, or streamed; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) in, or through, a mavoEab: (Ṣ TA:) and in like manner, rain: (TA:) and blood from the nose. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence,] SaAHa bihi faQnovaEaba Uilayohi ‡ He called out to him and he sprang up and ran to him. (A, TA.)
vaEobN, applied to water, (Ḳ,) and to blood, (TA,) Flowing, running, or streaming; as also vaEabN↓ and OuvoEuwbN↓ and OuvoEubaAnN↓. (Ḳ, TA.) You say sayolN OuvoEuwbN↓ [A flowing torrent]. (A.)
And [hence,] Xar-N OuvoEuwbN↓ ‡ [Evil that takes its course like a stream]. (A.)
See also what next follows.

vaEabN, (so in the Ṣ, expressly said to be biAlt-aHoriyki,) or vaEobN↓, (so in the Ḳ,) in some copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, mavoEab, (TA,) A water-course of a valley; a channel in which water flows in a valley: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, the rubbish and scum that collect in the channel in which the rainwater flows; but Az disapproves of this explanation of the word, and says that it signifies, in his opinion, the channel itself: (TA:) the pl. is vuEobaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, saAlati Alv-uEobaAnu kamaA saAla Alv-uEobaAnu, i. e. The torrent [or rather the torrents ran like the serpent called vEbAn]. (A, TA.)
See also vaEobN.

vuEobaAnN A kind of long serpent: (Ṣ:) a great serpent; applied to the male and the female: (Mṣb:) a bulky and long serpent, (Sh, Ḳ, TA,) that hunts the rat or mouse, to which latter animal the name is sometimes metaphorically applied, and that is more useful in the house than are cats: (Sh, TA:) or particularly the male [serpent], (Ḳṭr, Ḳ,) that is yellow, and ruddy: (Ḳṭr:) or the serpent in general, (ISh, Ḳ,) male and female, great and small: (ISh:) [also applied to an enormous fabulous serpent; described by Ḳzw and others:] pl. vaEaAbiynu. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
[raYyisu Alv-aEaAbiyni The basilisk. (Golius, from a Glossary.)]
damu Alv-uEobaAni: see damN.
fuwhu yajoriI vaEaAbiyba, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or famuhu, (TA,) and saEaAbiyba, (Ṣ,) His mouth runs with clear water, having an extended [or a ropy] flow. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OuvoEubaAnN: see vaEobN.
OuvoEuwb: see vaEobN, in three places.

mavoEabN [The outlet, or place of outpouring, of the water of a watering-trough, &c.;] the place of passage for the water, in the side of a wateringtrough or tank: and a channel, or conduit, for water: (KL:) pl. mavaAEibu. (Ṣ, A.) You say mavoEabu AlHawpa [The outlet for the water of the watering-trough or tank]: (Ṣ, A:) and mavoEabu Als-aToHi [the outlet for the water of the house-top]: (A:) and mavoEabu AlmaTari [the outlet, or channel, for the rain-water]: (TA:) from vaEaba AlmaMCa “he gave vent to the water,” or, “made it to flow forth,”, &c. (A, TA.) And mavaAEibu Almadiynapi, meaning The channels, or places of flowing, of the water of the city: (Ḳ, TA:) whence it appears that MF has erred in saying that mavoEabN signifies [only] a mizoraAb [or spout for conveying away water from a housetop, &c.]: not a channel, or place of flowing. (TA.) [See also SunobuwrN, and lawolabo.]

vaEodN, as an epithet applied to a leguminous plant, or to an herb, Fresh, juicy, or sappy; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) soft, or tender. (Ṣ, A.) You say vaEodN maEodN in this sense; (Ṣ, A;) the latter word being an imitative sequent, not [generally] used alone; but some use it alone: (Ṣ:) and it is said to be syn. with the former. (TA.) You say also ruTabapN vaEodapN maEodapN, meaning A fresh, juicy, ripe date. (IAạr, TA.) And varFI vaEodN Soft, moist earth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaEodN. (Sudot;.)

[As a coll. gen. n.,] Fresh ripe dates: or dates for the most part in a state of ripeness: (Ḳ:) or ripening dates when they have become soft: n. un. with p {vaEodapN}: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) that which is ripening, but as yet hard and indigestible, is termed jumosapN. (Aṣ, TA.) [See busorN.]
Fresh butter: so accord. to Is-ḥáḳ Ibn-Ibrá- heem El-Kurashee, in a trad. related by him. (IAth, TA.)
maA lahu vaEodN walaA maEodN He possesses not little nor much. (Ḳ.) [Here, again,] the last word is an imitative sequent. (TA.)

1. vaEila, aor. _a {yavoEalu}, inf. n. vaEalN, His teeth were irregular in their places of growth, and overlying one another: (Mṣb:) [or he had a tooth, or teeth, in excess, or exceeding the usual number, and growing behind the others: see what follows.] And vaEilati Als-in-u The tooth exceeded the usual number, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) being behind the other teeth: or entered beneath another, being irregular in the place of growth. (Ḳ.) [See also vuEolN.]
4. AvElwA, said of guests, They were, or became, numerous, or many, (Ḳ, TA,) and straitened, or crowded, one another: (TA:) so, too, said of men coming to water. (Ḳ, TA.)
AvElwA EalayonaA They acted contrarily, or adversely, to us; they opposed us. (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AvEl said of a recompense, or reward, It was, or became, great. (Ḳ.)
And said of an affair, It was so great that one knew not how to apply himself to it: (Ḳ:) it implies incongruity. (TA.)
vaEolN: see vuEolN.

vuEolN (Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 647) and vaEalN↓ and vuEoluwlN↓, (Ḳ,) the last from Ibn-ʼAbbád, (TA,) A tooth in excess, or exceeding the usual number, (Ḳ, and Ḥam ubi suprà,) behind the other teeth: (Ḳ:) or the entering of a tooth beneath another, with irregularity in the place of its growth: (Ḳ:) or vaEalN↓ signifies superfluities in the teeth, and irregularity in their places of growth, so that they overlie one another: (Ṣ:) or the teeth's overlying one another, and the excess of a tooth among them [beyond the usual number]. (Ḥar p. 243.)

And vuEolN (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥam ubi suprà) and vaEolN↓ and vaEalN↓ (Ḳ) An excess, or a redundance, (Ḳ and Ḥam,) [i. e.] a small teat in excess, [in addition to the usual number,] (Ṣ,) in, or among, the teats of a sheep or goat, (Ṣ, Ḳ, Ḥam,) and of a she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of a cow: (Ḳ:) it does not yield milk, though hyperbolically described as doing so. (Ṣ. [But see vaEuwlN.])
Also vuEolN, [not vuEaAlN as in Freytag's Lex.,] A certain animalcule that appears in a skin used for holding water or milk when its odour has become bad. (Ibn-'Abbad, Ḳ.*)
vaEalN: see vuEolN, in three places.
vuEalN: see vuEaAlapu.
One says in reviling a man, heciA Alv-uEalu waAlkuEalu, meaning This ignoble fellow, that is naught. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

hom.sense: vuEoluwlN: see vuEolN.
Also A ewe, or she-goat, that may be milked from three places, or four, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) by reason of an excess in the [number of] teats. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA. [See also vaEuwlN.])
Angry. (Lth, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: vaEaAlK: pl. of vaEolabu [q. v.]. (Ḳ in art. vElb.)
vuEaAlN: see vuEaAlapu.

vaEuwlu, applied to a she-camel, a cow, and a sheep or goat, Having an excess, or a redundance, in the [number of] teats: or having, above her teat, a small teat: or having a nipple in excess: (Ḳ:) or a ewe, or she-goat, having a vuEol [q. v.]: or, accord. to some of the lexicologists, a ewe, or she goat, that may be milked from her vuEol. (Ḥam p. 647. [See also vuEoluwlN.])
TaEonapN vaEuwlN A wound made with a spear or the like from which the blood is scattered, or sprinkled. (TA.)
jayoXN vaEuwlN A numerous army. (TA.) And katiybapN An army, or a collected portion thereof, having with it much rabble and many followers: (Ḳ:) regard is had in it to multitude and crowding. (TA.)

hom.sense: vuEaAlapu Dry herbage: or vuEaAlapu is [the plant commonly called] Einabu Alv-aEolabi [see art. vElb]: (Ḳ:) this is from AḤn. (TA.)

entry.sense:
OavoEalu A man whose teeth are irregular in their places of growth, and overlying one another: (Mṣb:) or having superfluities in his teeth, and irregularity in their places of growth, so that they overlie one another: (Ṣ:)
or having a tooth in excess, (Mgh, Ḳ,) behind the other teeth: (Ḳ:) or having a tooth entering beneath another, being irregular in the place of growth: (Ḳ:) fem. vaEolaMCu, applied to a woman; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and also to a gum (livapN): (Ḳ:) pl. vuEolN. (Mṣb, TA.)
A portly, or corpulent, personage, or chief, characterized by superabundances of benificence, or bounty. (Lth, Ḳ.)
muvoEilN Spread, scattered, or sprinkled. (TA.)
wrodNmuvoElN [A company of men coming to water] straitening, or crowding, one another. (Ḳ.)
jaMCa Alqawomu muvoEiliyna The people, or company of men, came in a connected, or continnous, body. (TA.)

OaroDN mavoEalapN A land in which are many vaEaAlib [or foxes]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like maEoqarapN meaning “a land in which are many EaqaArib [or scorpions];” (Ṣ;) as also muvaEolibapN. (Ḳ in art. vElb. [But see this last word.])

Q. 1. vaEolaba He (a man) was cowardly, and eluded, or turned away, or went this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully; as also tavaEolaba↓: his doing so being thus likened to the running of the vaEolab. (TA.) And vElb minohu faraqFA [He was cowardly, and eluded him, or turned away from him,, &c., through fear]; i. e., from another man. (TA.)
Q. 2. tavaEolaba: see above.

hom.sense:
vaEolabN [The fox; canis vulpes of Linn.: but in the dial. of Egypt, the jackal; canis aureus of Linn.: the former animal being there called Oabuw AlHuSayoni, as it often is by the Arabs of other countries:] a certain beast of prey; (TA;) well known: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied to the male and the female; so that one says vaEolabN cakarN and vaEolabN OunovaI; but if one would designate the male by a single word applying to it only, he says vuEolubaAnN↓, with damm to the v and l: (IAmb, Mṣb:) or the former applies to the female: (Ḳ:) or the female is called vaEolabapN↓; (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and the male, vuEolubaAnN↓ (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ) and vaEolabN, (Ḳ,) [accord. to some,] like as one says EaqorabapN [and EuqorubaAnN] and EaqorabN: (Mṣb:) or vaEolabN is the male; and the female is called vuEaAlapu↓: (Az, TA: [but see this word is art. vEl:]) the pl. of vElb is vaEaAlibu and vaEaAlK, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lḥ: but ISd disapproves of this [latter pl.]; and Sb does not allow it except in poetry. (TA.) F charges J with error in citing, as a proof that vuEolubaAnN↓ signifies the male, the following verse:
Oarab-N yabuwlu Alv-uEolubaAnu biraOosihi
laqado cal-a mano baAlato Ealayohi Alv-aEaAlibu
[Is he a Lord, upon whose head the he-fox makes water? (the b in brOsh being syn. with EalaI: so in the Mughnee, in art. b:) Vile indeed is he upon whom the foxes make water!] said by a man who was keeper of an idol, on seeing a he-fox make water upon it: but in this, F opposes also Ks and others; and it is asserted by several authorities that the correct reading of the word vElbAn in a trad. whereby F attempts to establish his charge against J is not vaEolabaAni, dual. of vaEolabN, as he pronounces it to be, but vuEolabaAni, which is said to be the masc. of vaEolabN, like as OufoEuwaAnN and EuqorubaAnN are mascs. of OafoEFI and EaqorabN. (TA.)
daMCu Alv-aEolabi [for which Golius seems to have found in a copy of the Ḳ dawaMCu Alv-aEolabi] A well-known disease, [namely, alopecia,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in consequence of which the hair falls off. (Ṣ.)

Einabu Alv-aEolabi [Fox-grape: rendered by Golius “uvæ vulpinæ, i. e. solanum:” but now applied by some to the gooseberry: and the solanum nigrum, or gardennightshade, is now commonly called Einabu Alc-iYobi:] a certain astringent, cooling plant: seven (or, as in one copy of the Ḳ, nine) Hab-aAt [which here seems to mean berries] thereof, swallowed, are a cure for the jaundice (AlyaraqaAn), and stop pregnancy, (Ḳ, TA,) like the berries of the xirowaE [or castor-oil-plant], for the year, or, as some say, absolutely. (TA.)

A hole, or aperture, (juHor,) whence rain-water flows. (TA.) [And particularly,] The outlet, hole, or aperture, (maxoraj, Ṣ and Mṣb, or juHor, Ḳ, or vaqob, TA,) whence the rain-water flows from the place where dates are dried. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) And The place whence the water flows forth (L, Ḳ) from, (L, TA,) or to, (Ḳ, [probably a mistake,]) a watering-trough or tank. (L, Ḳ.)
The upper extremity of a spear-shaft that enters into the head thereof. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
The lowest part of a palm-shoot when it is cut from [the root of] the mother-tree: or the lowest part of a [shoot such as is termed] rAkuwb, on the trunk of a palm-tree. (AA, Ḳ.)
vaEolabapN: see vaEolabN.
Also The os coccygis, or tail-bone; syn. EuSoEuSN. (Ḳ.)
And The podex, or the anus; syn. AisotN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: vuEolubaAnN: see vaEolabN, in three places.
vaEolabiy-apN A running of the horse like the running of the dog. (Ḳ.)
vuEaAlapu: see vaEolabN, and see art. vEl.

OaroDN muvaEolibapN A land having vaEaAlib [or foxes]: (Ṣ:) or, having many thereof; as also OarDN mavoEalapN; (Ḳ;) which is from vuEaAlapN; or it may be from vaEolabN, like maEoqarapN applied to “a land having many EaqaArib [or scorpions].” (Ṣ, L.)

hom.sense: 1. vagarahu, (T, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yavogaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. vagorN, (T,) He broke it; (T, A;) namely, a part of a wall; (A;) he demolished it: this is [said to be] the primary signification: he demolished it, or pulled it down; namely, a wall: (T:) and he broke it (namely, anything, [as a wall and a vessel, &c.,] A) so as to make a gap in it, or a hollow in its edge. (A, Ḳ.)

Also, (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He broke his vagor [or front teeth], (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or his teeth. (IAạr, and TA as from the Ḳ.) And vugira, in the pass. form, inf. n. vuguwrN, He (a boy) had his vagor [or front teeth] broken. (Mṣb.)
vagarotu sin-ahu I pulled out his tooth. (El-Hujeymee, TA.) And vugira He (a man) had a tooth, or teeth, pulled out. (Aṣ, TA.)

Also vugira, (AZ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. vagorN, (AZ, Mṣb,) He (a boy) shed his central milk-teeth, (AZ, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or his vagor [or front teeth]: (AZ, Mṣb:) or Oavogara↓ has this latter meaning, (A, Ḳ,) or Ait-agara↓; (Aṣ, TA;) and vagira, (Ḳ,) or Ait-agara↓, (Sh, TA,) or Ait-agara↓, (Mṣb,) signifies he shed his teeth: (Sh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) vugira is said to have this last signification in the Kifáyet el-Mutaḥaffiḍh; and Av-gr↓ and At-gr↓ are there said to have the contr. signification, explained below [see 8]. (Mṣb.)
vugira also signifies He had his mouth bruised; and so Ouvogira↓. (Ḳ.)

vagara Alv-ulomapa, aor. _a {yavogaru}, He stopped up, or obstructed, the gap, or breach: thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.) And vagaronaAhumo We stopped up, or obstructed, against them the gaps, or passes of the mountain; (Ṣ, TA;) we stopped up, or obstructed, against them the place of exit, so that they knew not what way to take. (A.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in two places:
and 8 also, in two places.

8. Ait-agara (AZ, Sh, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Aiv-agara (AZ, Mgh, Mṣb) and Aid-agara, (Ḳ,) originally Aivotagara, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (a boy) bred his central milkteeth, (Ṣ,) or his vagor [or front teeth]; (Sh,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Oavogara↓: (Ḳ:) or he bred his teeth after the former ones had fallen out: (AZ, Mgh:) and Oavogara↓, inf. n. UivogaArN, of the measure of Oakorama, inf. n. UikoraAmN, he grew his vagor [or front teeth] after the former ones had fallen out: by some, Av-gr and At-gr are used specially in relation to a beast: the Benoo-Kiláb thus used the former; not in relation to a boy. (Mṣb.)
See also 1, in five places.

vagorN The front teeth; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) syn. mabosimN; (Mṣb;) described by a poet as eight in number, four upper and four lower: (TA:) afterwards applied to the central incisors: (Mṣb:) or all the teeth (TA) while they remain in their places of growth, (Ḳ, TA,) before they fall out: (TA:) or the teeth, (Ḳ, TA,) all of them, whether in their places of growth or not: (TA:) or the mouth: (Ḳ:) pl. vuguwrN. (TA.) [Hence, DaHika vagoruhu He laughed so as to show his front teeth, or his teeth.]

Any gap, opening, interstice, or open intervening space, (M, Ḳ,) in a mountain, or in the bottom of a valley, or in a road along which people pass; (TA;) as also vugorapN↓: (A,* TA:) or the latter signifies a gap, or breach, in a wall, &c.; the hollow of the broken edge of a vessel, &c.; and its pl. is vugarN. (Ṣ.) You say, hecihi madiynapN fiyhiA vugarN↓ This is a city in which are gaps, or breaches. (Ṣ.)

† A frontier-way of access to a country, [in the CK, quruwH is erroneously put for furuwj, the word occurring in its place in MSS. of the Ḳ and in the Ṣ,] such as is a place of fear; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also vugoruwrN↓: (Ḳ:) the part of a country from which the invasion of the enemy is feared; so that it is like a gap in a wall, from which one fears the invasion of the robber: (Mṣb:)
a place from, or through, which one fears the enemy's coming, in a mountain or fortress: (T, TA:) the frontier of a hostile country: (Ḳ:) a place that is a boundary between the countries of the Muslims and the unbelievers: (IAth, TA:) pl. vuguwrN. (Mṣb.) You say, fulaAnN yasud-u Alv-agora ‡ [Such a one stops up, or obstructs, the frontieraccess of the country by his bravery]. (A.)
See also vugorapN, in two places.
OamosuwA vuguwrFA ‡ They became dispersed, or scattered, (JK, A, Ḳ,) and lost, or in a state of perdition: (A, Ḳ:) sing. vagorN. (JK, Ḳ.)
vugorapN; pl. vugarN: see vagorN, in two places.

Also The pit of the uppermost part of the breast, or chest, between the two collar-bones; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) the pit in the middle of the naHor: pl. as above: (Mṣb:) in a camel, the pit which is the stabbingplace: and in a horse, [the part] above the juWojuW, (Ḳ,) which is the prominent portion of the naHor, between the upper parts of the fahodataAn [or two portions of flesh on the right and left of the breast]. (TA.)

A tract, or quarter, of the earth, or of land; (JK, Ḳ;) as also vagorN↓. (TA.) You say, maA bitiloka Alv-ugorapi mivoluhu There is not, in that tract, or quarter, of the earth, his, or its, like. (TA.)

A plain, level, or even, road; (Ḳ;) as also vagorN↓: (TA:) or any road that people tread, or pass along, with ease; because they furrow its surface: (T, TA:) pl. as above. (A.) [Hence,] vugaru Almasojidi The ways leading to the mosque: or vugorapu Almasojidi means the upper part of the mosque [app. next to the kibleh]. (TA.) And huwayaxotariqu vugara Almajodi ‡ [He travels] the ways of glory. (A.)
vugoruwrN: see vagorN.
vaAgirapN The root, or lower part, of a tooth: pl. vawaAgiru. (JK.)
mavogarN The place through which a tooth passes, in the head [or gum]. (TA.)
muvogarN: see what follows.
mavoguwrN Having his vagor [or front teeth], (A,) or his teeth, (IAạr, TA,) broken. (IAạr, A, TA.)
Having his mouth bruised; as also muvogarN↓. (TA.)
A boy (AZ, Ṣ) shedding his central milk-teeth, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or his vagor [or front teeth]. (AZ, A, Mṣb.)
4. Avgm It (a valley) produced the kind of plant called vagaAm: (Ḳ:) or abounded therewith. (A, TA.)
And ‡ It (the head) became like the vagaAmap in whiteness. (Ḳ, TA.)

vagaAmN A kind of plant, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) generally (Mṣb) found in the mountains, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) having a green stem, (TA,) which becomes white when it dries, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and to which hoariness is likened; (Ṣ, Mṣb; [Golius, app. misled by a false reading in a copy of the Ṣ, says “simile anetho;”]) it has a thick [head, or blossom, such as is called] sanamap, and [it is said that] it does not grow save upon a black mountain-top, and is found in Nejd and Tihámeh: (TA:) AʼObeyd says that it is a kind of plant, (TA,) IF, that it is a tree, (Mṣb,) with a white blossom and fruit, (Mṣb, TA,) to which hoariness is likened: (TA:) it is called in Persian drmnh; (Ḳ; [written in different copies of that work diramonah and dar-amonah and daramonah; the last of which is said in the TA to be the right reading; a word said to mean wormwood, and hyssop; or, accord. to Meninski, as mentioned by Freytag, zedoary; but this last is called in Persian zurunobaA, with which word drmnh may have been confounded;]) or drmnh Asbyd, (Ṣ,) or daromanah UisoPiyd, in which [SM thinks] the former word is a contraction of daromiyaAnah; the two together meaning “in the middle white:” (TA:) the n. un. is with p {vagaAmapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and OavogamaMCu↓ is a quasi-pl. n.; (Ḳ;) as though the AC were a substitute for the p of OavogimapN. (TA.)
vaAgimN A colour white like the vagaAm: (Ḳ:) in the L, a head wholly white. (TA.)
OavogimaMCu: see vagaAmN.

1. vagato, aor. _u {yavoguwu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. vugaMCN, (Ṣ, [in a copy of the Mgh, vigaMC,]) She, or it, bleated, or cried, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) [on the occasion of bringing forth, and on other occasions;] said of a sheep or goat [&c.]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AvgI He made a sheep or goat [&c.] to utter the cry termed vugaMC. (Ḳ.)

Oatayotuhu famaA OavogaI I came to him and he gave not anything: (Ḳ:) or famaA OavogaI wamaA OarogaI and he gave not a sheep or goat,, &c., that uttered the cry termed vugaMC, nor a camel that uttered the cry termed rugaMC. (TA.)

entry.sense: vagowapN A single cry of the kind termed vugaMC. (TA.)

hom.sense: vugaMCN The bleating, or crying, or cry, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the sheep and goat and the like, (Ṣ,) or of the sheep or goat, and gazelle, &c., on the occasion of bringing forth, (M, Ḳ,) and on other occasions; (M;) as also vaAgiyapN↓, like raAgiyapN in relation to camels, and SaAhilapN in relation to horses. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) thus we find in the copies of the Ḳ, but correctly vigaAyapN↓, as in the Tekmileh [and in the JK], (TA,) The fissure in the lip of the sheep or goat. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: vigaAyapN: see what next precedes.
vaAgK [part. n. of vagaI: and hence,]

A sheep or goat [&c.]; (TA;) as also [its fem.] vaAgiyapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say, maAlahu vaAgK walaA raAgK (TA) and maA lahu vaAgiyapN walaA raAgiypN (Ṣ, TA) He has not a sheep or goat, nor a camel: (Ṣ, TA:) or maA lahu raAgiyapN walaA vaAgiyapN he has not a she-camel nor a sheep or goat. (Ḥar p. 333.) And maA biAld-aAri vaAgK walaA raAgK † There is not in the house any one. (Ṣ, TA.)
vaAgiyapN fem. of vaAgK [q. v.].
See also vugaMCN.

vuf-aMCN, (T, Jm, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of the measure fuE-aAlN, (Ṣ,) or vufaMCN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) of the measure of guraAbN, (Mṣb,) [a coll. gen. n.,] i. q. xarodalN [i. e. Mustard]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) in the dial. of the people of El-Ghowr: (M:) or xarodal worked together, or mixed up, or compounded, (muEaAlajN), with SibaAg [i. e. sauce, or fluid seasoning]: (M, Mgh:) or what is called HurofN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA) in the dial. of the people of El-Ghowr, (TA,) or, (M,) which is the same thing, (TA,) what is called Hab-u Alr-aXaAdi (M, Mgh, Mṣb, TA) in the dial of the people of El-'Irák, (TA,) which is eaten in case of necessity: (Mṣb: [see art. rXd:]) n. un. with p {vuf-aMCapN}: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) the C may be original, or it may be substituted for I or w: (M:) Ṣgh says, in the O, that he thinks the latter to be the case. (TA.) It is said in a trad., maA caA fiI AlOamar-ayoni mina AlX-ifaMCi AlS-abiri waAlv-uf-aMCa [What remedy is there in the two most bitter things, aloes and the vf-MC?]. (T, Mgh: but in the latter, the last word is without teshdeed to the f.)
1: see 4.
2: see 4.

4. Avfrhu He bound, tied, or fastened, upon him a vafar [or crupper]; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a beast, a horse, an ass, or a camel: (Ṣ,* M,* TA, &c.:) or he made for him (namely, a camel or an ass, &c., TA) a vafar [or crupper]. (M, Ḳ.) [Hence,] Oavofarotuhu bayoEapa suwoCK ‡ [app. I imposed upon him a bad sale so that he could not rid himself of it; lit.] I stuck a bad sale to his backside. (A, Ḳ.)
‡ He drove him, or urged him on, from behind; (A, Ḳ;) as also vf-rhu↓, inf. n. tavofiyrN; (Ḳ;) in some copies of the Ḳ, vafarahu↓, aor. _u {yavofuru}. (TA.)
At She (a goat) showed, or gave evidence of, pregnancy, or bringing forth. (Ḳ: in the CK, bay-anati AlwilAda: in MṢ. copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA, AlwilaAdap.)

10. Astvfr ‡ He (a man, M) put [a part of] his UizaAr [or waist-wrapper] between his thighs, twisted together; (M, Ḳ;) he (a wrestler) turned back the extremity of his garment [between his thighs] and stuck it in the part where it was bound round his waist: (A:) or Ast bivawobihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or biUizaArihi, (T, Mgh,) or Ast UizaArahu, (Mgh,) he (a man) turned back the extremity of his garment between his legs to the part where it was bound round his waist; (Ṣ;) or he (a wrestler, T, Mgh) bound his garment, (IF, Mṣb,) or his AzAr, (T, Mgh,) round the lower part of his body, (IF, Mgh, Mṣb,) or round his thighs, (T,) and then turned back its extremity between his legs, and stuck it in the part where it was bound round his waist, behind. (T, IF, Mgh, Mṣb.)

Astt, said of a menstruous woman, signifies the like; (Mṣb;) ‡ i. q. talaj-amato; (A, Mṣb;) She closed her vulva with a broad piece of rag, or stuffed it with some cotton, and fastened the [or each] extremity of the bandage to a thing tied round her waist. (T, L.)
And Ast, (M,) or Ast bicanabihi, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of a dog, ‡ He put his tail between his thighs, (Ṣ, M, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) making it to cleave to his belly. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
vaforN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vuforN↓ (M, Ḳ) The vulva of an animal of prey, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of any creature that has claws, or talons: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:)
or the vagina thereof: (M, Ḳ:) and metaphorically used in relation to other animals: (Mṣb:) thus applied to that of a cow, (Ṣ, M, TA,) and of a mare, and of a ewe, and of a woman: or applied to that of a cow it is proper, not tropical. (M, TA.)
Also, accord. to AA and others, The anus. (Mz 44th nwE.)
See also vafarN.

entry.sense: vuforN: see vaforN.

vafarN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and sometimes vaforN↓, (Ḳ,) The [crupper, or] strap, or thong, at the hinder part of the saddle; (M, Ḳ;) the appendage of the saddle that is put beneath the tail (Mgh) of a beast, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) of a horse, an ass, or a camel: (T, TA:) its two ends are bound to the daf-ataAni: (IDrd in his book on the Saddle and Bridle, p. 4:) pl. OavofaArN. (Mṣb.)
mivofarN: see what follows.
mivofaArN A beast that throws its saddle backwards. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)
‡ A catamite; syn. maOobuwnN; (Ḳ;) Al-aciI yuWotaI; (M;) as also mivofrN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

vuforuwqN The qimaE [or base] of a date: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the qimaE of a full-grown unripe date; i. e., the round portion of its covering, surrounding the stalk, and adhering to the upper part of the date: (Mgh:) or the part (El-'Adebbes, A-ʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ) of the date (El-'Adebbes, AʼObeyd, Ṣ) to which the qmE adheres: (El-'Adebbes, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Lth, the connecting medium (ElAqp) between the stone of the date and the qmE; and AZ says the like: (TA: [see farDN as signifying a sort of dates of 'Omán:]) or a raceme of which the dates have been eaten, or of which all the dates have been stripped off except one or two or three: (ISh, TA:) pl. vafaAriyqu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) explained by Ks as meaning the OaqomaAE of fullgrown unripe dates. (Ṣ.) tuforuwqN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA in art. tfrq.) The pl. also signifies The bases (OaqomaAE) of grapes: (JK:) or the vuforuwq of a grape is what adheres to the raceme; and a closed perforation therein. (Mgh.)
[Hence,] maA lahu vuforuwqN † He possesses not anything. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. [vafala, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of J, quasi safola, i. q. rasaba, i. e. It subsided; said of any sediment: but I do not find this in the Ṣ, nor in any other lexicon.]
vafala Alr-aHaI, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavofulu}, inf. n. vafolN; (TA;) or vaf-alahaA↓; (so in a copy of the M;) He placed a vifaAl [q. v.] beneath the hand-mill. (M, Ḳ.)

vafalahu, (Lth, T, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavofulu}, (TA,) inf. n. vafolN, (T, M,) He left it, or cast it away as a thing of no account, or neglected it, (tarakahu, Lth, T, M,) or he scattered it, strewed it, or dispersed it, (navarahu, Ḳ,) all of it, (Lth, T, TA,) at once. (Lth, T, M, Ḳ.)
2. vf-l Eani All-abani biAlT-aEaAmi, inf. n. tavofiylN, He ate wheat, or other food, with the milk. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 3. [vAfl probably signifies † He ate vufol, i. e. grain,, &c.; as Golius has assumed from the explanation, in the Ṣ and Ḳ, of the act. part. n., which see below: or vAflhu he ate vufol with him.]
Accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, (TA,) vAflhu is syn. with vaAfanahu, q. v. (Ḳ, TA.)
4. Avfl It (wine, or beverage,) had in it vufol [meaning a sediment, or dregs]. (Zj, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 5. tvfalhu ‡ It (a radical, or hereditary, evil quality) withheld him from generous actions. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA.)
‡ He overcame him, or subdued him, [as though] putting him beneath him like the vifaAl. (TA.)

entry.sense: vufolN The sediment, or settlings, of anything; (Ṣ;) the dregs; lees; or thick, or turbid, portion that sinks to the bottom of a thing, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) beneath the clear portion; (T, Mṣb;) as, for instance, of water, and of broth, (TA,) and of medicine, (T, TA,) and the like, and of a cookingpot, [i. e. of its contents,] (T,), &c.; (TA;) as also vaAfilN↓. (IDrd, M, Ḳ.)

‡ Grain, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) and whatever is eaten of flesh-meat or bread or dates; and particularly when people are in want of milk: (T:) or flour; and what is not drunk, as bread, and the like: (TA:) or the refuse, or worse sort, of TaEaAm [i. e. wheat, or other food]. (Ḥam p. 768.) You say, Xariba AlmaMCa EalaI gayori vufolK ‡ [He drank water, or the water, not upon, i. e. not having eaten, grain, or flesh-meat,, &c.]. (A in art. bHt.)
See also vifaAlN.
vafalN: see vafaAlN.

vafilN ‡ One who eats vufol. (Ḳ. [It seems to be there indicated that the latter word is to be understood in this case in the former of the senses assigned to it above; but it is not so.]) One says, layosa Alv-afilu kaQlomaHiDi, i. e. ‡ He who eats vufol [or grain,, &c.,] is not like him who drinks pure milk. (TA.) And humo muvaAfiluwna↓ ‡ They are eating vufol, i. e. grain, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) or flesh-meat, or bread, or dates, (T,) [&c.,] being in want of milk; (T, Ṣ;) the hardest of the means of subsistence (T, Ṣ, M) to the Bedawee. (T, Ṣ.)
vufolapN, (T,) or vafalapN, (TA,) † Somewhat remaining (T) of dates, in a sack: on the authority of a person of the tribe of Suleym. (T, TA.)

vafaAlN Slow; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) applied to a camel (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ), &c.; as also vafalN↓; (Ḳ;) and vaqaAlN: (Ḳ in art. vql:) one that will not rise and go save with reluctance: (T:) the first thus written with fet-ḥ [to the v] in the generality of books; but in the Tekmileh [of the ʼEyn] vifaAlN↓, and there said to be applied to a beast and to a man. (Mgh.)
vufaAlN: see the paragraph next following.

hom.sense:
vfaAlN The thing by which the mill is preserved from the ground; as also vufolN↓: (M, Ḳ:) it is a skin that is spread beneath the hand-mill to preserve the flour from the dust; (T;) a skin, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or the like, that is put beneath the mill, (Mṣb,) [i. e.,] which is spread, and whereon is placed the mill, which is turned with the hand, (Ṣ,) in order that the flour may fall upon it. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) When the vfAl has another thing to preserve it from the ground, this latter is called the wifaAD. (M.) Zuheyr says, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) describing war, (T,)
fataEorukukumo Earoka Alr-aHaIbivifaAlihaA . (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) meaning [And it frets you as frets the mill] when it is with its vfAl: for they do not place a vfAl beneath the mill except when grinding. (Ḳ.)
Also, (sometimes, Ṣ,) The nether, or lower, mill-stone; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so vufaAlN↓. (Ḳ.)
And A ewer; syn. UiboriyqN: (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ:) occurring in a trad. in which mention is made of washing the hand therewith. (T, M.)
See also vafaAlN.

entry.sense: vaAfilN: see vufolN.
Hence, as some say, metonymically, (M,) Dung; ordure; syn. rajiyEN. (M, Ḳ.)
muvaAfilN: see vafilu.

hom.sense: 1. vafinato yaduhu, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yavofanu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. vafunN, (Ṣ, M,) ‡ His hand was, or became, rough, or callous, [as though resembling a vafnap of a camel,] (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and blistered, (A,) from work. (M.)
vafanatohu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) aor. _i {yavofinu}, inf. n. vafonN, (Ṣ,) She (a camel) struck him with her vafinaAt [pl. of vafanapu, q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

And vafanahu, (T, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (T, M,) He impelled, pushed, thrust, or drove, him; or pushed, thrust, or drove, him away, or back: (T, M, Ḳ:) and struck, or beat, him. (M.)

Also, (T, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yavofinu} (M, Ḳ) and _u {yavofunu}, (M,) inf. n. vafonN, (T, M,) He followed him: (M, Ḳ:) or he came to him from behind him: (T, Ḳ:) or you say, jaMCa yavofinu as meaning he came closely pursuing a thing, having almost overtaken, or reached, it: and mar-a yavofinuhumN, and yavofunuhumo, he went along, or away, following them. (M.)
And vafana AlX-aIoCa, aor. _i {yavofinu}, inf. n. vafonN, He kept, clave, clung, or held fast, to the thing. (M.)
And vafana Alr-ajula He associated with the man in such a manner that nothing of his case was hidden from him. (T.) [See also 3.]

entry.sense: 3. vAfnhu, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. muvaAfanapN, (T,) He sat with him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said to be derived from:vafinapN as though meaning he made the vafinap [or lower portion of the fore part] of his knee to cleave to the vafinap of the knee of the other: (Ṣ:) or he sat with him, knee to knee, or each sitting upon his knees, fighting with him. (T.)
He kept, clave, or clung, to him, (T, Ḳ,) speaking to him. (T.) [See also 1.]

He consulted with him in order to know what was in his mind; and kept, clave, or clung, to him, that he might know his inward state or case, or his opinion, or his mind. (M.) [See 1, last signification.]
vAfnhu EalaI AlX-aIoCi He aided, or assisted, him to do the thing. (Ṣ, M.)
4. Avfn yadahu It (work) rendered his hand rough, or callous. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See 1, first signification.]
vaqonN Weight: or a weight: syn. viqolN. (T.)
vafanN A disease in the vafinap [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
vufunu mazaAdapK The sewed sides of a leathern water-bag. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: vafinapN [The callosity, or callous protuberance, upon] the knee; and what touches the ground, [in the act of lying down,] of [the callosity upon the breast called] the kirokirap and the saEodaAnap, [two words having the same meaning, for the latter of which the Ḳ erroneously substitutes the pl. form,] and of [each of the stifle-joints, i. e.,] the roots, or lower parts, of the thighs; of the camel: (M, Ḳ:*) pl. vifanN and vifaAnN (M, Ḳ) and vifinaAtN: (T, Ṣ, M:) the vafinaAt of the camel are the parts that fall upon the ground when the animal lies down, and that become rough, or callous, such as the two knees, &c.; (Ṣ;) the parts that are next the ground when the camel lies down, one of them being the kirokirap, with which they are five in number [as explained above]: or, as some say, the vafinap is [only the stifle-joint, i. e.,] the joint between the thigh and the sAq [or leg properly so called], internally, [meaning anteriorly,] and [the knee, i. e.,] the joint between the shank and the arm: (T:) or, accord. to some, any part that is next the ground, of any quadruped, when he lies down like the camel and like the sheep. (M.)
Hence, (TA,) [The stifle-joint, i. e.,] the joint between each thigh and leg, internally, [meaning anteriorly,] of a horse. (M, Ḳ.)

Hence also, (TA,) The knee of a man: or [so accord. to the M, but in the Ḳ “and,”] the place of union of the shank and thigh: (M, Ḳ:) [or the lower portion of the fore part of the knee, which becomes callous in consequence of much kneeling: see 3, first sentence. Hence,] ʼAbd-Allah Ibn-Wahb Er-Rásibee was surnamed cuw Alv-afinaAti (Ṣ, M, Ḳ *) from his much praying, (M,) because long prostration produced an [indurating] effect upon his vfnAt: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and ʼAlee Ibn-El-Hoseyn Ibn-ʼAlee, (Ḳ, TA,) known by the appellation of Zeyn-el-'Ábìdeen, (TA,) was [likewise] so surnamed, (Ḳ, TA,) because those parts of him upon which he prostrated himself were like the vfnp of the camel in consequence of his much praying: (TA:) so too was ʼAlee Ibn-AbdAllah Ibn-El-ʼAbbás. (A, Ḳ.)

Alv-afinapu mina Aljul-api, (Ḳ, [in some of the copies of the Ḳ AlHul-ap, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake,]) or vafinataA Aljul-api, (AḤn, M,) The two edges of the lower part of the jul-ap, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) [meaning,] of the dates [contained in the receptacle thus called; app. because the dates in the edges become more dry and hard than the main portion]. (AḤn, M.)
Also A number, and a company, of men. (M, Ḳ.)

And [as fem. of vafinN, which is perhaps unused,] A she-camel that strikes with her vafinaAt [here meaning her stifle-joints] on the occasion of her being milked. (M, Ḳ.) Her case is easier than that of the Dajuwr. (M.)

entry.sense: muvofanN, (M,) or muvofinN↓, (TA,) may mean Large in the vafinaAt. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: muvofinN: see muvofinN:
and see also muvaAfinN.

entry.sense: mivofanN lixaSomihi A man who keeps, cleaves, clings, or holds fast, to his adversary, or antagonist. (M.) [See also muvaAfinN.]
muvaf-inN: see muvaAfinN.
mivofaAnN A camel whose vafinap [here meaning his stifle-joint] has hit, or hurt, his side and his belly, (Ḳ, TA,) usually. (TA.)

muvaAfinN Keeping to a person, or thing, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously: (T, M:) or keeping, cleaving, or clinging, to another: as also muvofinN↓ or muvif-inN↓ (Ḳ, accord. to different copies,) [or, probably, mivofanN, q. v.].
1. vafaAhu, aor. _u {yavofuwu}: see art. vfI.

1. vafaAhu, aor. _i {yavofiIu} (M, Ḳ) and _u {yavofuIu}, (Ḳ,) He followed him; (M, Ḳ;) as also Oavafahu: or he was with him, near after him, or at his heels, as though treading in his footsteps: (TA:) or vafawotu Alr-ajula signifies I was with the man, near after him,, &c.: and jaMCa yavofuwhu, he came following him. (M.)
vafayotu Alqawoma I drove away, or drove away and pursued closely, or hunted, the people, or company of men; syn. Taradotu: (Ḳ:) perhaps from Oavafahu, which also signifies Taradahu. (TA.)

2. vf-I Alqidora, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, [in the CK, the verb is erroneously without teshdeed,]) He put the cooking-pot upon the OavaAfiI [pl. of Ouvofiy-apN, q. v.]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;*) as also OavofaAhaA↓; (M, Ḳ;) and Av-fhA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taOoviyfN; (TA;) and OavafahaA; (so in some copies of the Ḳ;) or MvafahaA, (so in other copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA,) inf. n. UiyvaAfN: (TA:) or AvfAhA↓ signifies he put, or made, for it OavaAfiI. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] vuf-iyati AlmaroOapu ‡ The woman was a wife of a man who had two wives beside herself; she being the third of them; they being likened to the OavaAfiI of the cooking-pot. (M.) And OavofaI↓ † He took three women as his wives. (Ḳ.)
4. AvfI Alqidora: see 2, in two places. See also Q. Q. 1 in art. Avf.
And AvfI said of a man: see 2.
5. tvf-I fulaAnFA Eiroqu sawoCK [Evil origin, or a bad hereditary disposition,] withheld such a one (qaS-ara bihi [in the CK, erroneously, qaSura bh]) from generous actions. (Ḳ)
vuf-aMCN, or vufaMCN; n. un. with p {vuf-aMCapN or vufaMCapN}: see art. vfO.

Ouvofiy-apN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) and Uivofiy-apN (Fr, AʼObeyd, Ḳ) The stone [which is one of the three] whereon the cooking-pot is placed: (M,* Ḳ:) it is a stone like the head of a man: (T, TA:) pl. OavaAfiI-u and OavaAfK. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) [See more in art. Avf.]
mivofFI, and its fem. mvofaApN: see what next follows, in three places.

muvaf-FI, (M,) or mivofFI↓, (Ḳ, [but this is probably a mistranscription,]) † A man of whom many wives die: (M, Ḳ:) or of whom three wives have died: (M, Ḳ:*) and muvaf-aApN, (T, M,) or mivofaApN↓, (Ḳ, [but this, again, is probably a mistranscription,]) † a woman of whom many husbands die: (M, Ḳ:) or of whom three husbands have died: (M:) or it signifies also (Ḳ) a woman who has buried three husbands: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) or muvaf-aApN signifies [like muWav-afapN] † a woman whose husband has two wives beside her; she being the third of them; they being likened to the OavaAfiI of the cooking-pot: and muvaf-iyapN↓, † a woman of whom three husbands have died: and muvaf-K↓, † a man of whom three wives have died. (Ṣ.)
muvaf-aApN, (Ṣ,) or mivofaApN↓, (Ḳ,) also signifies † A brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon an animal, resembling the OavaAfiI [of the cooking pot]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
muvaf-K, and its fem. muvaf-iyapN: see what next precedes.
qadorN muWavofaApN A cooking-pot put upon the OavaAfiI. (Ḳ * and TA, and M in art. Avf, q. v. [In the CK, erroneously, muWovafApN.])

hom.sense: 1. vaqaba, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yavoqubu}, (JK, Mṣb,) inf. n. vaqobN, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) He made a hole in a thing (JK,* Ṣ,* A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) with a mivoqab; (A, Mṣb;) meaning, a hole of small size; (Mgh;) such as passed through; he perforated, bored, or pierced, it: (A, Mgh, Ḳ:) and in like manner, vq-b↓, (Ḳ,) but this signifies he did so much, or to several, or many, things; (Ṣ, TA;) and tvq-b↓. (Ḳ, TA) You say, vaqaba Ald-ur-a [He bored, or perforated, or pierced, the pearls]; (A, TA;) and AlA-ucuna [the ear]. (Mgh.) And vaqaba AlqaroHa He pierced, or punctured, the purulent pustule, in order that the fluid, or water, in process of excretion, might issue. (A, TA.) And vaqaba AlHalamu Aljiloda The [ticks called] Halam pierced holes in the skin. (A, TA.) And vaq-abona↓ AlbaraAqiEa (A, Mgh) They made holes in the face-veils, (Mgh,) liEuyuwnihin-a [for their eyes]: (A:) said of women. (Mgh.)

[Hence,] vaqaba Alkawokabu, (Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 701,) [aor. _u {yavoqubu},] inf. n. vuquwbN, (JK, Ḥam,) ‡ The star shone brightly [as though it pierced through the darkness: see vaAqibN]: (Ḳ:) or shone and glistened intensely. (Ḥam ubi suprà.) And vaqabati Aln-aAru, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavoqubu}, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. vuquwbN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and vaqaAbapN, (Ṣ, L,) ‡ The fire burned brightly; burned, blazed, or flamed, up. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) And vaqaba Alz-anodu, (JK, TA,) aor. _u {yavoqubu}, inf. n. vuquwbN, (TA,) † [The znd emitted fire]: said when the spark falls (JK, TA) upon [or from] the znd [or wooden instrument for producing fire]. (JK.)
vaqabati Alr-aAYiHapu ‡ The odour diffused itself, and rose. (Ḳ, TA.)
vaqaba raOoyuhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. vuquwbN, (TA,) ‡ His judgment was penetrating; syn. nafaca. (Ḳ.)
vaqabati Aln-aAqapu, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavoqubu}, inf. n. vuquwbN, (JK, TA,) ‡ The she-camel had much milk; abounded with milk. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
vaquba, aor. _u {yavoqubu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. vaqaAbapN, (JK, A, Ḳ,) ‡ He (a man, JK, A) was, or became, very red; (JK, A, Ḳ;) so as to be likened to the flame of fire. (A, TA.)
2. vq-b: see 1, in two places.
[Hence,] ‡ He (a bird) soared high, piercing the region of the air next to the clouds: (A, TA:) or reached, or ascended to, the midst of the sky. (TA.)

vq-bhu AlX-ayobu, (JK, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. tavoqiybN; (JK, Ḳ;) and vq-b fiyhi; (IAạr, Ḳ;) ‡ Hoariness appeared upon him: (Ḳ:) or began to appear upon him: (A, TA:) or became intermixed in his hair; or appeared and spread upon him; or his blackness and whiteness of hair became equal. (A, TA.) And vq-b AlX-ayobu biAll-iHoyapi ‡ Hoariness commenced in the sides of the beard. (A.)

vq-b Euwdu AlEarofaji ‡ The stalk of the Erfj [q. v.], the plant being rained upon, became soft: (Ṣ:) or the sap ran in it, and it put forth leaves. (JK, A.) When it has become blackish, one says of it, qabila: when it has increased a little, OadobaI; in which state it is fit to be eaten: and when its xuwS are perfect, OaxowaSa. (Ṣ.)

vq-b, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. tavoqiybN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) also signifies ‡ He made a lamp, and a fire, to burn, shine, glisten, or gleam, very brightly, as though piercing through the darkness, and dispelling it; and so Avqb↓; (A, TA;) and the latter, he kindled a fire (TA) with tinder, (A, TA,) or camel's dung, or the like: (A:) or both signify he made a fire to burn brightly; to burn, blaze, or flame, up; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so tvq-b↓: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to AZ, Avqb↓ Aln-aAra, inf. n. UivoqaAbN, signifies he scraped a hole for the fire, in the ground, then put upon it, [i. e. the fire] dung, such as is called baEor, and small pieces of fire-wood or similar fuel, and then buried it in the dust; and so tvq-b↓ Aln-aAra, and tvq-b↓ bihaA; as also ms-k biAln-aAri, inf. n. tamosibkN: and tvq-b↓ Aln-aAra signifies also he struck fire: and Avqb↓, inf. n. as above, he made a spark to fall from a zanod, q. v. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 2, in three places.

hom.sense: 5: see 1, first sentence:
and see also 2, in four places:
and 7, in two places.

entry.sense: 7. Anvqb It was, or became, perforated, bored, or pierced; and in like manner, [but properly, as quasi-pass. of 2, signifying it was, or became, perforated,, &c., much or in many places,] tvq-b↓. (Ḳ.) You say, tvq-b↓ Aljilodu The skin was, or became, pierced with holes by the [ticks called] Halam. (Ṣ, A.)

vaqobN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb. Ḳ) and vuqobN↓ (Mṣb) and vaqobapN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb) A hole, perforation, or bore, that penetrates, or passes through, a thing; (A, Mgh, Ḳ;) accord. to Mṭr, (Mṣb,) only such as is small; (Mgh, Mṣb;) such as is large being termed naqobN, with n: (Mgh:) or a hole that is not deep: or, as some say, a hole descending into the earth: (Mṣb: [but this last explanation is not of general application:]) said to be opposed to Xaq-N: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] (of the first word, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) vuquwbN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OavoqubN (Ḳ) and (of vuqobapN, Ṣ, Mṣb) vuqabN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and vuqubN. (Ṣ [in which this last is said to be with damm, meaning, to the q, not (as some have supposed) to the v only,] and A.)
vuqobN: see vaqobN.
vuqobapN: see vaqobN.
viqaAbN: see what next follows.

vaquwbN ‡ Fuel; or a thing with which fire is kindled, or made to burn brightly, or to burn, blaze, or flame, up; (JK, Ṣ, A;) as also viqaAbN↓; (Ḳ;) consisting of small sticks, (Ṣ, TA,) or dung, such as is called baEor; (A, TA;) and tinder. (JK, A, TA.)
vaqiybN ‡ A man very red; (JK, A, Ḳ;) so as to be likened to the flame of fire: (A:) fem. with p {vaqiybapN}. (JK, A.)
See also vaAqibN, in three places.

vaAqibN ‡ A star, and a lamp, and fire, (A,) or a flame of fire, or a shooting star, (Ṣ,) shining brightly: (Ṣ:) or shining, glistening, or gleaming, very brightly, as though piercing through the darkness, and dispelling it. (A, TA.) Aln-ajomu Alv-aAqibu [in the Ḳur lxxxvi. 3] means ‡ The star, or asterism, brightly shining; (Fr, Bḍ, L;) as though it pierced through the darkness, or the celestial spheres, by its light: (Bḍ:) or the star, or asterism, that is high, above the others: or the planet Saturn: (L, Ḳ:) or the Pleiades, or any star or asterism, brightly shining; because it pierces through the darkness by its light. (Jel.)
† A zanod (q. v.) that emits fire, when struck. (TA.)
‡ Applied to Hasab [i. e. nobility, or grounds of pretension to respect or honour], it means Famous and exalted: (Lth, JK, A,* TA:) or bright; brilliant. (Aṣ, TA.)

And hence, ‡ applied to knowledge [as meaning Penetrating, or brilliant]. (Aṣ, TA.) You say also vaAqibu AlEilomi, for vaAqibN fiI AlEilomi, meaning ‡ Brilliant [or penetrating] in knowledge; as also mivoqabN↓: (TA:) which latter signifies also ‡ learned, and sagacious, or intelligent; (TA;) penetrating in judgment: (Ḳ:) and vaAqibu Alr-aOoIi ‡ a man of sound and penetrating judgment, sagacity, or intelligence. (A, TA.)
OatatoniI Eanohumo EayonN vaAqibapN, (JK,) or Eanoka, (A, TA,) ‡ There came to me, from them, or from thee, certain, or sure, news or information. (JK, A, TA.)

naAqapN vaAqibN ‡ A she-camel having much milk; abounding with milk; (AZ, JK, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also vaqiybN↓; (AZ, JK, Ḳ;) and vaqiybapN↓: (TA, voce naqiybapN:) pl. (of the former, A) nuwqN vuqubN, (so in a copy of the A,) or vuq-abN. (TA.) One says also, Uin-ahaA lavaqiybN↓ mina AlUibili, meaning Verily she is one that vies with the other camels abounding with milk, and surpasses them in abundance thereof. (TA.)
Oavoqabu [More, and most, piercing, or penetrating:, &c.]
[Hence,] Oavoqabu HaTabK naArFA † [The most excellent of fire-wood in yielding fire]. (TA in art. mZ.)
OuvoquwbN † A man (TA) who enters, or penetrates, much into affairs. (Ḳ, TA.)
mavoqabN † A great road, (Ḳ, TA,) which people [as it were] pierce, or perforate, by their tread. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]
mivoqabN An instrument with which one perforates, bores, or pierces; a drill, or the like: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. mavaAqibu. (A.)

And hence, ‡ A road passing through a mountain; as though perforating it: (A, TA:) or a road passing through a stony and rugged tract: (L, TA:) and, with the article Al, particularly applied to the road of El-'Irák, (A, Ḳ,) from El-Koofeh (Ḳ) to Mekkeh: (A, Ḳ:) or a road between El-Yemámeh and El-Koofeh: (L, TA:) and a road between Syria and El-Koofeh: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to El-Bekree and the Marásid, a road called after a man named mvqb. (MF, TA.) Hence the saying, huwa Tal-aAEu AlmavaAqibi, ‡ i. q. Tal-aAEu Alv-anaAyaA [q. v. voce vaniy-apN]. (A, TA.)
See also vaAqibN.
dur-N muvaq-abN (Ṣ, A) i. q. mavoquwbN↓ [i. e. Bored, perforated, or pierced, pearls]: (Ṣ, TA:) the pl. of the latter is mavaAqiybu. (TA.)
UihaAbN muvaq-abN A hide pierced with holes by [the ticks called] Halam. (A, TA.)
Han-a kamaA Han-a AlyaraAEu Almuvq-abu [He, or it, uttered plaintive sounds like the reed pierced with holes; i. e., the musical reed]. (A, TA.)
mavoquwbN: see muvaq-abN.

hom.sense: 1. vaqufa, aor. _u {yavoqufu}, inf. n. vaqaAfapN; and vaqifa, aor. _a {yavoqafu}, inf. n. vaqafN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and vaqofN; (Ḳ;) He (a man, Ṣ) became skilled, or skilful; and light, active, quick, or sharp; and intelligent, or sagacious. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

vaqufa, aor. vaqaAfapN, is also said of vinegar (xal-N), meaning It was, or became, very acid; and so vaqifa. (TA. [But I suspect that this may have been taken from a MṢ. in which xul-N has been erroneously put for rajulN. In the JK, I find rajulN vaqiyfN waqado vaqufa vaqaAfapF.])
vaAqafahu favaqafahu, aor. of the latter _u: see 3.
vaqafotu AlX-aIoCa, aor. _a {yavoqafu}, inf. n. vaqaAfapN and vuquwfapN, I was, or became, skilled in the thing. (Ḥam p. 772.)

And vaqofN signifies The learning a thing quickly: [its verb is vaqafa or vaqifa:] you say, vaqafotu AlEiloma fiI OawoHaI mud-apK, and AlS-inaAEapa, I acquired knowledge, or the science, and the art, or handicraft, quickly [in the shortest period]: (TA:) and vaqifotu AlHadiyva I understood the narration, or tradition,, &c., quickly. (Mṣb.) vaqifahu, aor. _a {yavoqafu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. vaqofN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or vaqafN, (Mṣb,) [but the former is better known,] primarily signifies, He perceived it, or attained it, by knowledge, or by deed: (Bḍ ii. 187:) or he perceived it, or attained it, by his sight, by expertness in vision: and hence, (Er-Rághib, TA,) ‡ he reached him, or overtook him, (IF, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Er-Rághib,) in war, or fight: (Mṣb:) or (Ḳ) † he found him: (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Bḍ in ii. 187, &c.:) or † he found him in the way of taking and overcoming: (Ksh in ii. 187:) or (Ḳ) † he took him, or it, (Lth, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, a thing: (Mṣb:)
or (Ḳ) by implication, (Bḍ in ii. 187,) † he gained the victory, or mastery, over him; overcame him; (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Bḍ ubi suprà;) or got possession of him. (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 187 and iv. 93], waQqotuluwhumo Hayovu vaqifotumuwhumo And slay ye them wherever ye find them: (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel, TA:) or wherever ye take them, or overcome them, or overtake them. (TA.) And exs. occur also in the Ḳur [iii. 108 and] viii. 59 and xxxiii. 61 [and lx. 2]. (TA.) For another ex., see 4, below.
vaqifahu also signifies He thrust him, or pierced him, [with a spear or the like,] namely, a man. (Ḥam p. 772.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 2. vq-fhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tavoqiyfN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, KL,) He straightened it, or made it even, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, KL,) or straightened what was crooked thereof; (Mṣb;) namely, a spear, (Ṣ, KL,) [and a bow, (see viqaAfN,)] or a crooked thing; with the viqaAf: (Mgh:) [and so vaqafahu↓, accord. to an explanation of the inf. n. vaqofN in the KL.] tavoqiyfu Als-ahomi EalaI Alqawosi, as meaning The directing the arrow upon the bow straightly towards the object aimed at, is not approved. (Mgh.)

Hence, (Mgh,) ‡ He disciplined him, or educated him well, and amended him, or improved him. (Mgh, TA.) You say, lawolaA tavoqiyfuka watawoqiyfuka maA kunotu XayoYFA ‡ [But for thy disciplining, or good educating, and amending, or improving, and thy teaching, I had not been anything]. (TA.)
You say also, of vinegar, yuvaq-ifu AlT-aEaAma, i. e. It makes food acid. (Ḥar p. 227.)

3. vAqfhu favaqafahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. of the former muvaAqafapN and viqaAfN, (TA,) and aor. of the latter _u, (Ḳ,) He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, in skill, (Ḳ, TA,) and intelligence, or sagacity, and the perceiving, or attaining, of a thing, and the doing thereof, (TA,) and he surpassed him therein. (Ḳ, TA.) Er-Rághib says that this is metaphorical. (TA.) [Accord. to J,] AlmuvaAqafapu is from vaqufa in the first of the senses explained above. (Ṣ.)

viqaAfN also signifies The contending with another: and particularly in fight, or with the sword: (Ḳ: [see also vaqofN, below:]) and the using of, or performing with, the sword; like viqaAfapN. (TA.) And vAqfhu, inf. n. muvaAqafapN, He played with him with the sword, or some other weapon. (TA.)

4. Ouvoqifotuhu [I was made to gain the mastery over him, or to overcome him: or, which is virtually the same,] he was appointed for me [that I might have the mastery over him]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) ʼAmr Dhu-l-Kelb says,
faUino OuvoqifotumuwniI faQqotuluwniI
waUino Oavoqafo↓ fasawofa tarawona baAliI
And if ye [be made to] gain the mastery over me, i. e. if it be appointed for you to meet me [and overcome me], then slay me: but if I meet [you and overcome], then shall ye see my condition: but some relate it thus: wamano Oavoqafo, meaning but whom I meet, of you, I will slay him: (Skr, Ṣgh, TA:) [and J gives it thus:] faUim-aA tavoqafuwniI Alx [meaning And if ye meet me, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

5. tvq-f ‡ [He was, or became, disciplined, or educated well, and amended, or improved; quasi-pass. of 2, q. v.] You say, halo tavaq-afotu Uil-aA EalaI yadika ‡ [Was I, or have I been, disciplined,, &c., save by thy agency, or means?]. (A, TA.)
6. tvAqfwA They contended, or played, one with another, with swords, or other weapons. (TA.)

hom.sense: vaqofN Skilled, or skilful; and light, active, quick, or sharp; and intelligent, or sagacious; as also vaqifN↓ and vaqufN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and vaqiyfN↓ and viq-iyfN↓: (Ḳ:) or vaqiyfN↓ signifies quick in understanding a narration: (Mṣb:) and vaqaAfN↓, applied to a woman, intelligent, or sagacious. (Ḳ.) You say also rajulN vaqofN laqofN and vaqifN↓ laqifN, meaning A man who is a relater, a poet, an archer or a caster of the spear, &c.: (Lth, JK, TA:) or light, active, quick, or sharp, and skilful: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. lqf:) or quick in understanding what is said to him; and in taking what is thrown to him: or skilful in his art, or handicraft: (TA in that art.:) or a man who keeps, preserves, or guards, and manages, or orders, well, that which he possesses: (ISk, TA:) and Lḥ adds vaqiyfN↓ laqiyfN: and Ibn-ʼAbbád, viq-iyfN↓ liq-iyfN. (TA.)
A man quick in taking, or seizing, his opponents, or adversaries. (Ksh ii. 187.)
vaqofN, or (as it is written in one place in the TA) vaqafN↓, also signifies Contention: and particularly in fight, or with the sword: like viqaAfN [inf. n. of 3, q. v.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: vaqafN: see vaqofN.
vaqufN: see vaqofN.
vaqifN: see vaqofN, in two places.
vaqaAfN: see vaqofN.

hom.sense: Also An instrument with which spears are straightened, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and bows also, (TA,) and [other] crooked things; (JK, Mgh, TA;) made of iron: (JK, TA:) or a strong piece of wood, a cubit in length, having at its extremity a hole large enough to admit the bow, [or the spear], which is inserted into it, and pinched and pressed in the part that requires this to be done until it becomes in the state that is desired; but this is not done to bows nor to spears until they have been greased, and prepared with fire, or exposed thereto so as to have become altered in colour: (AḤn, TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OavoqifapN and [of mult.] vuqufN. (JK, TA.)
[Also The handle of a shield of the kind called Hajafap: see UixaAcapN.]

entry.sense: vaqiyfN: see vaqofN, in three places.
Also Very acid; applied to vinegar; (Ḳ;) and so viq-iyfN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like Hir-iyfN applied to the onion. (Ṣ.) And Oabuw vaqiyfK ‡ Vinegar [itself]; so named because it makes food acid. (Ḥar p. 227.)
Also, and mavoquwfN↓, A thing skilled in. (Ḥam p. 772.)
And both these words, A man thrust or pierced [with a spear or the like]. (Ḥam ibid.)

viqaAfapN The use of, or performance with, the sword; like viqaAfN [inf. n. of 3, q. v.]. (TA.) You say, huwa Hasanu Alv-iqaAfapi biAls-ayofi [He is good in respect of performance with the sword]. (TA.)
vuquwfapN: see viqaAfN.
viq-iyfN: see vaqofN, in two places:
and see vaqiyfN.
Oavoqafu More, and most, skilled, or skilful, [in a general sense, and particularly] in contending, or playing, with the sword, or other weapon. (TA.)
muvaq-afN A spear straightened, or made even. (TA.) [Accord. to Freytag, it is poetically used as signifying A spear itself; and so with p {muvaq-afapN}.]
mavoquwfN: see vaqiyfN.

hom.sense: 1. vaqula, aor. _u {yavoqulu}, inf. n. viqalN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and viqolN, a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) and vaqaAlapN, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK viqAlap, but) like karaAmapN, (TA,) It (a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb) was, or became, heavy, weighty, or ponderous. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See viqalN, below.]
See also 4.

[† It was, or became, heavy, weighty, or preponderant, ideally.] faOam-aA mano vaqulato mawaAziynuhu, in the Ḳur ci. 5, means † And as to him whose good deeds shall be preponderant. (Bḍ, Jel.) [See also Ḳur vii. 7 and xxiii. 104.]

[† It was, or became, heavy, or weighty, as meaning onerous, burdensome, oppressive, afflictive, grievous, or troublesome.] You say, vaqula Alqawolu ‡ The saying was [heavy, or weighty,, &c.; or] unpleasant to be heard. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur vii. 186, vaqulato fiI Als-amewaAti waAlOaroDi † It (the time of the resurrection) will be momentous, or formidable, [in the heavens and on the earth, or] to the inhabitants of the heavens and the earth, (Bḍ, Jel,) to the angels and men and genii; app. alluding to the wisdom shown in concealing it: (Bḍ:) or it means the knowledge thereof [is difficult]: (Ibn-ʼArafeh, TA:) or it is occult, or hidden. (Ḳṭ, TA.) [vaqula is also said of a word, and of a sound, meaning † It was heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: see 2. And of an affair, or action, meaning † It was afflictive, grievous, troublesome, or difficult. In these and similar senses, it is trans. by means of EalaI: you say, vaqula Ealayohi † It was, or became, heavy, weighty, onerous,, &c., to him. In like manner also it is said of food, meaning † It was, or became, heavy to the stomach; difficult of digestion.] You say also, vaqula samoEuhu ‡ [His hearing was, or became, heavy; or] his hearing partially went. (Ḳ, TA.)

‡ He (a man) was, or became, heavy in sickness, or disease: [and in like manner, in his sleep:] the verb is thus, with damm to the q; though said in the Ḳ to be vaqila, like fariHa, as meaning his disease became violent; (Fet-ḥ el-Báree, TA;) not improbably through error or inadvertence. (MF.)

[† He was, or became, heavy, slow, sluggish, indolent, lazy, dull, torpid, or drowsy; wanting in alacrity, activity, agility, animation, spirit, or intelligence; stupid.] You say, yavoqulu Eano qubuwli maA yuloqaI Uilayohi † [He is averse from receiving, or accepting, or admitting, or is slow to receive,, &c., what is said to him]. (TA.)
Also, said of the Earofaj, and of the vumaAm, ‡ Its shoots became luxuriant, or succulent, or sappy. (Ḳ, TA.)

vaqalahu, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) biyadihi, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavoqulu}, (TA,) inf. n. vaqolN, (Ḳ,) He tried the weight of it, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) namely, a thing, (Ḳ,) or a sheep or goat, (Ṣ,) by lifting it [with his hand] to see if it were heavy or light. (Ṣ, TA.)
vaqala AlX-aIoCu AlX-aIoCa fiI Alwazoni, aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) The thing surpassed the thing in weight; outweighed it. (PṢ.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 2. vq-lhu, inf. n. tavoqiylN, He, or it, made it, or him, vaqiyl [i. e. heavy, properly and tropically]: (Ḳ:) tvqyl is the contr. of taxofiyfN; (Ṣ;) and signifies the making heavy in weight [&c.]; as also vaqolN [inf. n. of vaqalahu↓]. (KL.)

[Hence, † He made it (a word or a sound) heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: and particularly a word by uttering hemzeh with its true, or proper, sound, which is commonly termed taHoqiyqu Alhamozapi, and opposed to taxofiyfuhaA; and by making a single consonant double; and by making a quiescent consonant movent: often occurring in these senses in lexicons and grammars: opposed to xaf-afahu.]

hom.sense: 4. Avqlhu He, or it, (a load, Ṣ, or a thing, Mṣb,) [burdened him: or] burdened him heavily: (Ḳ:) or beyond his power; overburdened him. (JK, Mṣb, TA.*)

† In the latter sense, said also of a debt: and of sickness, or a disease: (JK:) or, said of sickness, or a disease, and of sleep, and of meanness, or sordidness, ‡ it [burdened him,] overcame him, and rendered him heavy. (Ḳ,* TA,* TḲ.)

Avqlt, said of a woman, She became gravid; her burden became heavy in her belly: (Ṣ:) or she had a burden, (Akh, Ṣ, and Bḍ in vii. 189,) by reason of the greatness of the child in her belly: (Bḍ, Jel:) or her pregnancy became apparent, or manifest; as also vaqulato↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. [tvAql EalaI XaIoCK He pressed heavily, or bore his weight, upon a thing: see mutavaAqilN.]

tvAqlwA † [They were heavy, sluggish, or spiritless:] they did not rise and hasten to the fight when commanded to do so. (IDrd, Ḳ.) And tvAql UilaI AlOaroDi, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. ArD, &c.,) and Aiv-aAqala AlI AlrD, the former being the original form of the verb, (Bḍ and Jel in ix. 38,) † He was, or became, heavy, slow, or sluggish, (Bḍ, Jel,) averse from warring against the unbelievers, (Jel,) and inclining to the earth, or ground; (Bḍ, Jel;) or propending thereto. (Bḍ.) And Aiv-aAqala UilaI Ald-unoyaA † He propended to the present world. (TA.) And tvAql Eanohu † He was heavy, or sluggish, and held back from it. (Ḳ.)
10. Astvqlhu contr. of Aisotaxaf-ahu; (Ṣ and Ḳ and TA in art. xf;) He deemed it, or him, vaqiyl [i. e. heavy, properly and tropically]. (TA in that art.)
[Hence, † He deemed it (a word or a sound) heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: often occurring in this sense in lexicons and grammars.]

Ausotuvoqila nawomFA † [He was overcome, and rendered heavy, by sleep: and in like manner, maraDFA, by sickness or disease: and luWomFA, by meanness or sordidness: see its pass. part. n., below]. (JK.)

viqolN Weight: or a weight: syn. wazonN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, KL:) pl. OavoqaAlN. (Ṣ.) So in the phrase OaEoTihi viqolahu [Give thou him his, or its, weight]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) See also mivoqaAlN. You say also, OaloqaI Ealayohi viqolahu or viqalahu↓ [He threw upon him his weight: see mivoqaAlN, last sentence: and see jiromN]. (Ṣ in art. Awq, &c., accord. to different copies.)

And A load, or burden: (KL:) or a heavy load or burden: pl. as above. (Ḳ.) wataHomilu OavoqaAlakumo, in the Ḳur xvi. 7, means And they carry your loads, or burdens; (Bḍ;) or your heavy loads or burdens. (TA.)
OavoqaAlN ( as pl. of viqolN, Ḳ, or of vaqalN↓, Bḍ) also signifies ‡ The treasures, or buried treasures, of the earth: and its dead, or corpses. (Ḳ, TA, and Bḍ and Jel in xcix. 2.)

Also ( as pl. of viqolN, Ḳ) ‡ Sins. (JK, Ḳ.) So in the saying in the Ḳur [xxix. 12], walayaHomilun-a OavoqaAlahumo waOavoqaAlFA maEa OavoqaAlihimo ‡ [And they shall assuredly bear their sins, and sins (of others whom they have seduced) with their sins]. (TA.)

vaqalN A thing, or things, that a man has with him, of such things as burden him: (Ḥam p. 295:) [and particularly] the household-goods, or furniture and utensils, (El-Fárábee, JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, Ḥam ubi suprà, and Bḍ in xcix. 2,) and (accord. to El-Fárábee, Mṣb) the household and kindred and party, or domestics, or servants, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Ḥam,) of a man, (Ḥam,) or of a traveller: (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or the travelling-apparatus and baggage and train, of a man:] pl. OavoqaAlN; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) with which vaqilapN↓ is syn., (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) as are also vaqalapN↓ and viqolapN↓ and vaqolapN↓ and viqalapN↓; (Ḳ;) as meaning all the household-goods or furniture and utensils of persons going on a journey. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also viqolN.

† The requisites and apparatus, instruments, tools, or the like, of a man: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) as, for instance, ‡ the books and writing-reeds of the learned man: every craftsman has what is thus termed. (TA.) By the saying
kilaA vaqalayonaA TaAmiEN biganiymapK
the author thereof, Iyás Et-Tá-ee, means Each of our two armies, the possessors of the vaqalaAni [or apparatus, or weapons,, &c., of war, is longing for spoil]: or an army may be termed vaqalN because it is heavy in assault. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)

Anything held in high estimation, in much request, and preserved with care. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence the trad., Uin-iI taArikN fiykumu Alv-aqalayoni kitaAba Qll-ehi waEitoratiI [Verily I am leaving among you the two objects of high estimation and of care, the Book of God, and my kindred, or near kindred]: (Ḳ:) or they are thus called because of the heaviness of acting in the manner required by them: (Th, TA:) or as being likened to the requisites and apparatus, instruments, tools, or the like, of a man. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)
Also Eggs of the ostrich; because he who takes them rejoices in them, and they are food. (TA.)

Alv-aqalaAni Mankind and the jinn or genii; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because, by the discrimination that they possess, they excel other animate beings. (TA.) It may also mean The Arabs and the foreigners: or mankind and other animate beings. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)

viqalN Heaviness; weight, or weightiness; ponderousness; gravity; contr. of xif-apN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Er-Rághib:) and preponderance: in its primary acceptation, relating to corporeal objects: then, to ideal objects. (Er-Rághib, TA. [See vaqula, throughout.]) See also viqolN.

fiI Oucunihi viqalN ‡ [In his ear is a heaviness, or dulness,] is said of him whose hearing is not good; as though he were averse from receiving, or accepting, or admitting, or slow to receive, &c., what is said to him. (TA.)
vaqolapN: see vaqalN.

Also † A fit of drowsiness, or of slumber, that overcomes one: (JK, M, Ḳ:) and ‡ a heaviness experienced in the chest, (Ḳ, TA,) or in the body, (TA,) from food: as also vaqalapN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) or the former, or ↓the latter, (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,) † a heaviness and languor in the body: (Ṣ:) and ↓the latter, † a heaviness that is experienced on the heart. (JK.)
viqolapN: see vaqalN.
vaqalapN: see vaqalN:
and see vaqolapN, in three places.
vaqilapN: see vaqalN.
viqalapN: see vaqalN.
vaqaAlN: see vaqiylN, in two places.
Also, applied to a woman, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) Heavy; (Ṣ;) large in the hinder part, or posteriors: (JK,* Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA:) or heavy (Ḳ, TA) in an ideal sense. (TA.)
vuqaAlN: see vaqiylN.

vaqiylN part. n. of vaqula; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) Heavy, weighty, or ponderous: (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Er-Rághib:) and so in relation to another thing; preponderant: primarily applied to a corporeal thing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and vaqaAlN↓ and vuqaAlN↓ signify the same: (Ḳ:) pl. viqaAlN and vuqolN and vuqalaMCu [which last, however, seems to be applied only to rational beings, agreeably with analogy]. (Ḳ.)

[Like its verb,] it is also applied to an ideal thing. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Thus it signifies † Heavy, or weighty, in the sense of onerous, burdensome, oppressive, afflictive, grievous, or troublesome: momentous, or formidable: difficult: heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear; applied to a word and a sound; and particularly to a word in which a single consonant is made double, and to one in which a quiescent consonant is made movent, like muvaq-alN↓: heavy to the stomach; difficult of digestion: heavy applied to the hearing: see the verb.] qawolFA vaqiylFA, in the Ḳur [lxxiii. 5], means † A heavy, or weighty, saying. (TA.) Aln-uwnu Alv-aqiylapu means † [The heavy-sounding n; as in yafoEalan-a, &c.;] the contr. of Alxafiyfapu. (TA in art. xf.)

It is also applied to a man, (JK,) meaning ‡ [Heavy in sickness, or disease; or] suffering a violent disease: (Ḳ:) [and † heavy, slow, sluggish, indolent, lazy, dull, torpid, or drowsy; wanting in alacrity, activity, agility, animation, spirit, or intelligence; stupid:]
and so is musotavoqalN↓: (JK:) which also means, particularly, † overcome, and rendered heavy, by sleep (nawomFA), (JK,* Ḳ,* TḲ,) and by sickness or disease (maraDFA), and by meanness or sordidness (luWomFA). (Ḳ.) viqaAlu Aln-aAsi [expressly said in the TA to be with kesr, but in the CK, erroneously, vuqAl,] and vuqalaMCu AlnAs mean † Those men whose company is disliked; (Ḳ;) whom others deem heavy: each is pl. of vaqiylN. (TA.) One says, Oanota vaqiylN EalaI julasaAYika † [Thou art heavy, or dull, or unwelcome, to thy companions with whom thou sittest]. (TA.) And (to him who is vaqiyl, TA in art. nsm,) maA Oanota Uil-aA vaqiylu AlZ-il-i baAridu Aln-asiymi † [Thou art no other than one who casts a gloom upon others, and chills them: lit., heavy of shade, or shadow; cold of breeze]. (TA.) vaqiylN, applied to a man, is mostly used in dispraise: but sometimes, in praise: (Er-Rághib, TA:) used in praise, it signifies † Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (Kull.) Applied to a horse, † Slow; (Kull;) and so vaqaAlN↓ applied to a camel; (Ḳ;) a meaning also assigned to vafaAlN, with f; (TA;) and muvoqalN↓, applied to a horse or the like. (JK.) AinofiruwA xifaAfFA waviqaAlFA, in the Ḳur [ix. 41], means † [Go ye forth to fight] prompt and not prompt: (Ḳatádeh, Bḍ, Jel, TA:) or whether moving be easy to you or difficult: (Bḍ,* TA:) or riding and walking: or lightly armed and heavily armed: or healthy and sick: (Bḍ:) or strong and weak: (Jel:) or rich and poor: (Jel, TA:) or young and old. (TA.)
vaAqilN A deenár of full weight; (Z;) not deficient: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. vawaAqilu. (Ṣ, Z, Ḳ.)
OaSobaHa vaAqilFA † He became, or became in the morning, heavy by reason of sickness, or disease. (Aboo-Naṣr, Ḳ, TA.)
Oavoqalu More [and most] heavy. (TA.)
muvoqalN Heavily burdened: (TA:) or burdened beyond his power; overburdened. (JK, TA.)
† Weighed down, or oppressed, by sickness, or disease, (JK,) and by debt. (JK, Er-Rághib.)
See also vaqiylN.
muvoqilN, applied to a woman, Gravid; whose burden has become heavy in her belly: (Ṣ:) or whose pregnancy has become apparent, or manifest. (Ḳ.)
muvaq-alN: see vaqiylN.
Also † Ill received; disapproved; not rendered an object of love to hearts. (Ḥam p. 37.)
muvaq-alapN A stone of marble; (JK;) a piece of marble by which a carpet is made heavy: (Ḳ:) by rule it should be with kesr to the q. (TA.)

mivoqaAlN The weight (miyzaAn, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, or wazon, Mṣb, TA, and Jel in iv. 44 and x. 62 and xxi. 48, or zinap, TA) of a thing, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the like thereof (mino mivolihi [but why this is added I do not see]); (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [i. e.] its equal in weight; (PṢ, and Bḍ in x. 62;) its quantity (miqodaAr). (Bḍ in xxi. 48.) maA yaEozubu Eano rab-ika mino mivoqaAli car-apK, in the Ḳur x. 62, means There is not hidden from thy Lord aught of the weight of the smallest ant: (Jel:) or a thing equal in weight to a small ant; or to the motes that are seen in a ray of the sun that enters through an aperture. (Bḍ.)
A thing with which one weights; as also viqolN↓; i. e., any of the weights of the balance. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

A certain weight, of which the quantity is well known; (JK;) a dirhem and three sevenths of a dirhem; (Mṣb, and Ḳ in art. mk;) i. e., the seventh part of ten dirhems: (Mṣb:) or [a dirhem and a half; so in the present day; i. e.,] seventy-two sha'eerehs: (El-Karmánee, TA:) or twenty keeráts. (Hidáyeh, TA.)
[A certain coin;] i. q. diynaArN, q. v.; (Mṣb in art. dnr;) a mivoqaAl of gold: pl. mavaAqiylu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OaloqaI Ealayohi mavaAqiylahu He threw upon him his weight, or burden; syn. maWuwnatahu [perhaps meaning the burden of supporting him]. (Aboo-Naṣr, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also viqolN.]
mutavaAqilN Bearing one's weight upon a thing: whence the saying, waTiYahu waToOapa AlmutavaAqili [He trod upon him, or it, with the tread of him who bears his weight, or presses heavily]. (TA.)
musotavoqalN: see vaqiylN.

1. vakilatohu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yavokalu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. vakalN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or vukolN, (Mgh,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and vakolN, (Mgh,) [or this last is also a simple subst.,] She (a mother) lost him, or became bereft of him; namely, her child, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) by death: (Mgh:) and vakilahu, aor. _a {yavokalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. vakalN, (TA,) he lost him; namely, a friend, or person beloved, or a child. (Ḳ.) vakilatoka Oum-uka [lit. meaning May thy mother be bereft of thee] is an imprecation against him to whom it is addressed, not said with the desire of its having effect, but on an occasion of vehement love, like laA OabaA laka, [and qaAtalaka Qll-ehu,], &c. (Ḥar p. 165.)

hom.sense: 4. Oavokalato A state of bereavement clave to her; (Ḳ;) namely, a woman: or she became in a state of bereavement. (TA.)
OavokalahaA Qll-ehu waladahaA God made her to be bereft of her child [by death]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) And Avklhu Qll-ehu Oum-ahu God made him to be bereft of his mother [by death]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: vakolN: see what next follows.

vukolN The loss, or the state of being bereft, of a child [by death], (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of a friend, or person beloved; (Ḳ;) i. e., a woman's loss of her child; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also vakalN↓ [which is the inf. n. by general consent], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and vakolN↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlEuquwqu vukolu mano lamo yavokalN [Undutiful treatment of a parent is (like) the bereavement of him who is not (really) bereft of his child]. (TA.)
Also Death: and a state of perdition or destruction. (Ḳ.)
vakalN: see vukolN.
vakolaAn; fem. vakolaI and vakolaAnapN: see vaAkilN.
vakuwlN: see vaAkilN.
falaApN vakuwlN ‡ A desert in which the traveller becomes lost. (Ḳ, TA.)

vaAkilN, applied to a man, Bereft of a child, or of a friend, or person beloved; as also vakolaAnu↓ or vakolaAnN [with or without tenween, as is shown by the two forms of the fem. mentioned in what follows, but generally without]: (Ḳ:) and applied to a woman; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and sometimes vaAkilapN; (Mṣb;) as also vakolaI (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vakolaAnapN, (IAạr, Ḳ,) which is rare, (Ḳ,) and vakuwlN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) meaning bereft of her child [by death]; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) pl. (of vaAkilN, TA, [and of vaAkilapN,]) vawaAkilu, [and of vAkl also vakolaI, as is implied in the TA voce EuborN,] and (of vakolaI, TA) vakaAlaI. (Mṣb, TA.)

UivokaAlN and OuvokuwlN↓ i. q. EivokaAlN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and EuvokuwlN, i. e., The fruit-stalk (XimoraAx) upon which are the ripening dates: pl. OavaAkilu, [app. a contraction of OavaAkiylu, like EavaAkiylu,] occurring in poetry. (Ṣ.) These two words are mentioned here by J and Ṣgh, and F has followed them; but they should be mentioned among words whose first radical letter is hemzeh, for the O is a radical, substituted for E. (TA.)
OuvokuwlN: see what next precedes.
