muvokilN A woman whose state of bereavement is constant: (Ḳ:) or who is in a state of bereavement: (TA:) pl. mavaAkiylu (Ḳ) [or this is pl. of mivokaAlN]. Hence, nisaMCu AlguzaApi mavaAkiylu [The wives of the warriors are constantly bereft, or often bereft, of their husbands]. (TA.)
qaSiydapN muvokilapN ‡ An ode in which bereavement is mentioned. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, Ḳ.)
rumoHuhu lilowaAlidaAti mavokalapN [His spear is a cause of bereavement to mothers] (Ṣ, Ḳ) is a saying similar to Alwaladu maboxalapN wamajobanapN [explained in art. bxl]. (Ṣ.)
mivokaAlN A woman much, or often, bereft of her children: (Mṣb, TA:) pl. mavaAkilu (TA) [or mavaAkiylu: see muvokilN].
And A she-camel that is accustomed to lose her young by death or by slaughter or by gift: pl. mavaAkiylu. (Ḥam p. 746.)

hom.sense: 1. val-a, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavolulu}, inf. n. val-N, (T,) He put [or poured] back the earth into a grave, and a well, after digging it: (T:) or he poured the earth into a well, (Ṣ, Ḳ,), &c. (Ṣ.)
Also, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, M,) He poured forth pieces of money. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and valovala↓; (M, Ḳ;) He moved, or put in motion, with his hand, or he broke at one of its sides, [app. so as to make it pour down, or fall,] a quantity of earth collected together, or a sand-heap, (M, Ḳ,) or a house: (O, TA:) or he dug it. (TA.)

And the former, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, M,) and so the inf. n., (M, TA,) He threw down, or demolished, a house, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) by digging beneath the wall, and then pushing, so that it fell in ruins: (Ṣ, TA:) and he demolished, and broke, a thing. (M.)

[Hence,] val-a Qll-ehu EaroXahumo ‡ God destroyed their dominion: and vul-a EaroXuhumo ‡ Their might, or power, departed: (Ṣ:) or val-a Qll-ehu EaroXahu ‡ God caused him to die; or caused his dominion, or his might, or power, to depart: (Ḳ, TA:) and vul-a EaroXuhu, inf. n. val-N, ‡ His means of support became destroyed, and ceased; (M, A;*) or he became abased, or in an abject condition; (IDrd, M;) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, it means OusoqiTato vl-p minohu [perhaps a company of men (vul-apN) was made to fall away from him]: (TA:) El-'Otbee says that ErX here has two meanings; namely, a throne, and a booth, or shed, constructed for shade. (TA. See art. ErX.) You say also, vul-a EaroXuhu and EuroXuhu, meaning † He was slain: and a poet says, of a sword, val-a EuroXayohi, meaning † [It severed] the base of his neck; the part where his neck was set on his back. (IDrd, M.)

And val-a, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M,) inf. n. val-N (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and valalN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He killed, or destroyed, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) a man, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) or men. (M, Ḳ.) And vul-a He died, or perished. (T.)
val-a AlbiYora, (M, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yavolulu}, inf. n. val-N, (M,) He took, or cast, forth the earth from the well; (M, Ḳ;) and the mud from the bottom of the well. (M.)
val-a AlwiEaMCa, aor. and inf. n. as in the next preceding case, He took what was in the receptacle; as also Avtl-hu↓; the latter from Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)
And val-a He became rich, or in a state of competence. (T.)
4. Avl- He (a man, Ṣ) abounded in what is termed val-ap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which may mean either wool or a flock of sheep or goats: both these meanings are assigned to it in this case by Z. (TA.)
Avl-hu He ordered, or commanded, the repairing of it; (M;) or the repairing of what had been thrown down, or demolished, of it. (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tvl-l It (a house) became thrown down, or demolished; (Ḳ;) as also Anvl-↓: (TA:) or it (a house) became thrown down, or demolished, and it fell by degrees, part after part. (M.) And taval-alati Alr-akiy-apu The well became demolished. (TA.)
7. Anvl- It (a thing) poured forth, or became poured forth. (TA.)
Ainoval-uwA i. q. AinovaAluwA [app. as meaning They poured themselves forth]. (Ḳ.) You say, Anvl-wA Ealayohi They poured forth, or down, upon him, or against him. (Z, TA in art. vlm.)
See also 5.
8: see 1, near the end.
R. Q. 1. valovala: see 1, near the beginning.

hom.sense: val-apN The earth that is taken forth from a well: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and the mud that is taken forth from the bottom of a well: (M:) and the space upon which is cast the earth taken forth from a well, around its mouth; which space, when the well has been dug in a place that is not the property of any one, belongs exclusively to the owner of the well: (AʼObeyd, T:) pl. vulalN. (Ḳ.)
val-apN mavoluwlapN↓ A grave (turobapN) filled up with earth, after it has been dug. (T.)

A thing that is made of clay, or mud, (M,) like a manaArap [q. v.], (Ḳ,) in the desert, for the sake of its shade. (M, Ḳ. [Erroneously written by Golius and Freytag maval-apN, and compared to maZal-apN.])

Wool, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) alone: (M, Ḳ:) or a portion of wool collected together: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and wool and goats' hair (XaEar) and camels' hair (wabar) together; (Aboo-Yoosuf, T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) but not the second of these alone, nor the third alone: (Aboo-Yoosuf, T, Ṣ:) or it signifies camels' hair (wbr) also: (T:) or wool and XEr and wbr together; but none of these alone. (M.) kisaMCN jiy-idu Alv-al-api is said to mean A ksAC of good wool: (Ṣ, M:) and Habolu val-apK, a rope of wool. (Ṣ.) It is said in a prov., laA taEodamu SanaAEN val-apF [A clever woman is not without wool to spin or weave when she has nothing else to do]: applied to a skilful man. (TA.) And you say, Einoda fulaAnK val-apN kaviyrapN, meaning Such a one has much wool and goats' hair (XEr) and camels' hair (wbr). (Aboo-Yoosuf, Ṣ.) [Hence,] fulaAnN kaviyru Alv-al-api [sometimes] means ‡ Such a one has much hair on his body. (TA.)

A flock of sheep or goats, (T, M, Ḳ,) whether many or few: (M:) or many thereof: (M, Ḳ:) or specially a flock of sheep: or sheep, absolutely: (M:) or a numerous flock of sheep: (ISk, T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and numerous sheep and goats together: many goats are not thus called; but are called HayolapN: (Aboo-Yoosuf, Ṣ, M:) pl. vilalN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is extr., (M,) and vilaAlN. (M, Ḳ.)
Many pieces of money; or much money; (M, Ḳ;) as also vul-apN↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

In relation to the times of camels' coming to water, (fiI mawaAridi AlUibili, TA, [in the copies of the Ḳ, fI is omitted, and mawaAridu is put for mawaAridi,]) The interval of two days, or keeping from water during two days, between two drinkings. (Ḳ, TA. [The word to which this signification is assigned is erroneously written by Golius and Freytag maval-apN; and explained as meaning “Locus ubi aquantur cameli postquam per biduum non biberint.”])

entry.sense: vul-apN A party of men; (T;) a company of men: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or a numerous company. (Bḍ in lvii. 13.) You say, fulaAnN laA yaforuqu bayona Alv-al-api waAlv-ul-api [Such a one will not distinguish] between a flock of sheep or goats and a company of men. (Z, TA.)
See also val-apN.

vil-apN Death; or a state of perdition or destruction; (Ḳ;) and so valalN↓; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) which latter is also an inf. n. of val-a signifying “he killed,” or “destroyed:” (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. of the former vilalN. (Ḳ.)
vul-aI ‡ Might, power, or elevated condition, perishing, or passing away. (Ḳ, TA.)
valalN: see vl-apN.

muvil-N A man (Ṣ, M) abounding in what is termed val-ap. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ. [See 4, Oaval-u, mentioned by Golius with this word, as syn. therewith, and as from the Ṣ and Ḳ, is not in either of those Lexicons.])
muhorN mival-N [A colt that dungs much]. (M. [The meaning is there indicated, but not expressed.])
muval-ilN Collecting wealth, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) and disposing it well, or putting it into a good state or condition. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
mavoluwlN A house thrown down, or demolished. (TA. [See 1.])
See also val-apN, second sentence.

hom.sense: 1. valabahu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yavolibu}, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. valobN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb) and mavolabN, (T,) He blamed him; reprehended him; found fault with him; imputed to him, or charged him with, a fault, vice, or the like: (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he charged him plainly, or openly, with a fault, vice, or the like; (Ṣ;) spoke against him; (TA;) censured him, reproached him, detracted from his reputation, or impugned his character: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or he blamed him severely; and assailed him with his tongue; as is done in punishings and the like. (Lth, T.)
valabahu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. valobN, (M,) also signifies He drove him (a man, M) away; expelled him; or put him at a distance, away, or far away. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And He turned it (a thing, M) upside down, or over, or inside out; or changed its manner of being, or state. (M, Ḳ.)
And I. q. valamahu: (M, Ḳ:) formed from the latter by substitution of b for m. (M.)
valiba, (M,) inf. n. valabN, (M, Ḳ,) It (one's skin, M, or a garment, TḲ) was, or became, dirty, or filthy: (M, Ḳ:) and it (a thing, TḲ) was, or became, contracted. (Ḳ, TḲ.)
Also It was, or became, broken in the edge or middle, [like valima,] and split, or cracked. (KL.)

entry.sense: 2. vl-b, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M,) inf. n. tavoliybN, (Ṣ,) He (a camel) became such as is termed vilob. (Aṣ, Ṣ, M.)

Also A camel extremely old, or old and weak, (M, A,) and having his teeth much broken: (M:) or a camel whose canine teeth are broken (Ṣ, Ḳ) much (Ḳ) by reason of extreme old age, or age and weakness, and the hair of whose tail has fallen off by degrees: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. with p {vilobapN}; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) but some disallow this, and say that the female is termed naAbN: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] OavolaAbN (M, Ḳ) and [of mult.] vilabapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Hence, (A,) ‡ A man extremely old, or old and weak, (A, TA,) whose teeth are much broken: (TA:) or an aged man; a man advanced in years: (IAạr, M, Ḳ:) [said to be] of the dial. of Hudheyl; but IAạr mentions it without assigning it to the dial. of any particular tribe of the Arabs. (M.)
Also A camel that does not impregnate. (M, Ḳ.*)
See also what next follows.
valibN: see vilobN.

Also, applied to a spear, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, but in a copy of the A written vilobN↓,) Much notched, or broken in the edges [of the head]: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or weak, or weak and soft. (A.)
You say vilobN EalaI vilobK wabiyadihi valibN [An extremely old, or old and weak, man, whose teeth are much broken, upon a camel in the like condition, and having in his hand a spear that is much notched, or weak, or weak and soft]. (A, TA.)
vaAlibapN AlX-awaI A woman having cracked, or chapped, feet: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) from valbN as an epithet applied to a spear. (Ṣ.)

OavolabN and UivolibN, (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more common, (Fr, T,) Dust, or earth; and stones: (Fr, T, M, Ḳ:) or small fragments, or particles, of stones, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of dust or earth: (Ṣ:) or stone (A' Obeyd, Sh, T) in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz: and dust, or earth, in the dial. of Temeem: (T:) and El-Hejeree says, AlOavolamu is like AlOavolabu; but [ISd says,] whether it be formed by substitution or be a dial. var., I know not. (M, TA.) One says, bifiyhi AlOavolabu and AlUivolibu In his mouth are, or be, dust, or earth, and stones; (Fr, T;) or, particles of stones and of dust or earth. (Ṣ.) Lḥ mentions the phrase AlOavolaba laka or AlUivoliba [Dust, or earth, and stones, be thy lot]; and Alt-uraAba: and he says that the noun is thus put in the accus. case, as though the phrase were an imprecation [of the ordinary kind]: he means, as though the noun were an inf. n. used in an imprecation; though it is a simple subst. (M.) liloEaAhiri AlUivolibu or AlOavolabu, occurring in a trad., means For the adulterer, or fornicator, stone (AlHajaru [but see this word, and see also art. Ehr]): or dust, or earth: or small stones. (TA.)
mivolabN Accustomed to blame, reprehend, or find fault. (A, TA.)

mavolabapN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mavolubapN (M, Ḳ) A fault, vice, or the like: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:*) or [properly] a cause of [blame or] reviling: (Mṣb:) pl. mavaAlibu. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) You say, maA Earafotu fiI fulaAnK mavolabapF [I have not known in such a one a fault, or vice, or cause of blame,, &c.]. (A, TA.)

1. valava Alqawoma, aor. _u {yavoluvu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. valovN, (TA,) He took the third of the goods, or property, of the people, or company of men. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And vulivati Alt-arikapu The property left at death had a third of it taken. (A.) And valava, aor. _i {yavolivu}, [but in this case it seems that it should be _u, as above,] is also said to signify He slew a third. (L.)

valava Alqawoma, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or AlAivonayoni, (Fr, T, M,) or Alr-ajulayoni, (Mṣb,) aor. _i {yavolivu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [thus distinguished from the verb in the first sense explained above,] inf. n. valovN, (TA,) signifies He was, or became, the third of the people, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a third to the two, (Fr, T, M,) or to the two men: (Mṣb:) or he made them, with himself, three: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and similar to this are the other verbs of number, to ten [inclusive], except that you say, OarobaEuhumo and OasobaEuhumo and OatosaEuhumo, with fet-ḥ, because of the E. (Ṣ.) A poet says, (IAạr, Ṣ,) namely, AbdAllah Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr El-Asadee, satirizing the tribe of Teiyi, (IB, TA,)
faUino tavolivuwA narobaEo waUino yaku xaAmisN
yakuno saAdisN Hat-aI yubiyrakumu Alqatolu
[And if ye make up the number of three, we will make up the number of four; and if there be a fifth of you, there shall be a sixth of us; so that slaughter shall destroy you]: (IAạr, Ṣ, IB:) he means, if ye become three, we will become four: or if ye slay three. (IB, TA.)

Also; (Ṣ, M, TA;) in the Ḳ, “or,” but this is wrong; (MF, TA;) valava Alqawoma signifies He made the people, with himself, thirty; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) they being twenty-nine: and in like manner one uses the other verbs of number, to a hundred [exclusive]. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.) And valava also signifies He made twelve to be thirteen. (T.)
valava AlOaroDa He turned over the ground three times for sowing, or cultivating. (A, TA.)
See also 2.

valava, (T, M, L, TA,) [as though intrans., an objective complement being app. understood,] or vl-v↓, (Ḳ, [but the former is app. the right reading, unless both be correct,]) said of a horse, He came [third in the race; i. e., next] after that which is called AlmuSal-iI: (T, M, L, Ḳ: [in the CK, AlcI, after Alfarasu, should be omitted:]) then you say rabaEa: then, xamasa. (T, M, L.) And in like manner it is said of a man [as meaning He came third]. (T.)

laA yavoniI walaA yavolivu, (so in a copy of the M in art. vnI, but in the present art. in the same copy written lA yvniI wlA yvolivu,) or laA yuvan-iI walaA yuval-ivu↓, (so in a copy of the A, [in the CK in art. vnI, and in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 545, laA yuvan-aI walaA yuval-avu,]) or laA yuvoniI walaA yuvolivu↓, (so in a copy of the Ḳ in art. vnI, [in the TA, in the present art. and in art. vnI, without any syll. signs,]) said of an old man, meaning He cannot rise, (M, A, TA,) when he desires to do so, a first time, nor can he (M, TA) the second time, nor the third. (M, A, TA.)

2. vl-vhu He made it three; or called it three: (Esh-Sheybánee, and Ḳ in art. wHd:) tavoliyvN signifies the making [a thing] three [by addition or multiplication or division]; as also valovN↓ [inf. n. of valava]: and the calling [it] three. (KL.)
[Hence, vl-v, inf. n. tavoliyvN, He asserted the doctrine of the Trinity.]

[Hence also,] fulaAnN yuvan-iI walaA yuval-ivu Such a one counts two Khaleefehs, namely, the two Sheykhs [Aboo-Bekr and ʼOmar], and [does not count three, i. e.,] rejects the other [that succeeded them]: and fulaAnN yuval-ivu walaA yurab-iEu Such a one counts three Khaleefehs, [namely, those mentioned above and ʼOthmán,] and [does not count a fourth, i. e.,] rejects [ʼAlee,] the fourth. (A, TA.)
laA yuvan-iI walaA yuval-ivu: see 1.
vl-v liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained three nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sab-aEa.)
vl-v binaAqatihi He tied, or bound, three of the teats of his she-camel with the SiraAr. (Ṣ.)
val-avato said of a she-camel, and of any female: see 4.
vl-v said of a horse in a race: see 1.
vl-v Albusoru, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) The full-grown unripe dates became, to the extent of a third part of them, ripe, or in the state in which they are termed ruTab. (M, Ḳ.)
tavoliyvN also signifies The watering seed-produce [on the third day, i. e.,] another time baEoda Alv-unoyaA [which app. means after excepting, or omitting, one day]. (M.)
And The making [a thing] triangular [or trilateral]. (KL.)
[The making a letter three-pointed; making it to have three dots.]
The making [a thing] to be a third part. (KL.)
The making the electuary, or confection, of aromatics, or perfumes, that is called muval-av. (KL.)

4. Avlv Alqawomu The party of men became three: (Th, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:) and similar to this are the other verbs of number, to ten [inclusive]: (Ṣ:) also The party of men became thirty: and so in the cases of other numbers, to a hundred [exclusive]. (M, L.)
Avlvt She (a camel, and any female,) brought forth her third young one, or offspring; (Th, M;) and so vl-vt↓, or Avtlvt↓. (TA in art. bkr.)
laA yuvoniI walaA yuvolivu: see 1.
Avlv said of a grape-vine, It had one third of its fruit remaining, two thirds thereof having been eaten. (M.)
8: see 4.
vulovN: see vuluvN.

vilovN The third young one or offspring, (M, A, Ḳ,) of a she-camel, (M, Ḳ,) and, accord, to Th, of any female: (M:) and in like manner others are termed, to ten [inclusive]. (A.) But one should not say naAqapN vilovN [after the manner of vinoIN, q. v.]. (M.)

saqaI naxolahu Alv-ilova He watered his palm-trees once in three days: (A:) or he watered them baEoda Alv-unoyaA [which app. means after excepting, or omitting, one day]. (Ḳ.) vilovN is not used [thus] except in this case: there is no vilov in the watering of camels; for the shortest period of watering is the rifoh when the camels drink every day; then is the gib-, which is when they come to the water one day and not the next day; and next after this is the riboE; then, the ximos; and so on to the EiXor: so says Aṣ: (Ṣ, TA:) and this is correct, though J's assertion that vilov is not used except in this case is said by F to require consideration. (TA.)
Hum-aI Alv-ilovi i. q. Hum-aI Algib-i, [The tertian fever;] the fever that attacks one day and intermits one day and attacks again on the third day; called by the vulgar Almuval-ivapu↓. (Mṣb.)
vulavN: see what next follows.

vuluvN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vulovN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and vulavN↓, which last is either a dial. var. or is so pronounced to make the utterance more easy, (MF,) A third; a third part or portion; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also valiytN↓, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like vamiynN and sabiyEN and sadiysN and xamiysN and naSiyfN, (Ṣ,) though AZ ignored valiyvN (T, Ṣ) and xamiysN: (Ṣ:)
[and mivolaAvN↓, q. v., app, signifies the same:] the pl. of vlv, (M, Mṣb,) and of vlyv also, (M,) is OavolaAvN. (M, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., diyapu Xibohi AlEamodi OavolaAvFA [The expiatory mulct for that homicide which resembles what is intentional shall be thirds]; i. e., thirty-three she-camels each such as is termed Hiq-ap, and thirtythree of which each is such as is termed jacaEap, and thirty-four of which each is what is termed vaniy-ap. (TA.)
UinaMCN valovaAnu A vessel in which the corn, &c. that is measured therein reaches to one third of it: and in like manner one uses this expression in relation to beverage, or wine, &c. (M, L.)
vilovaAnN, (so in a copy of the M,) or valivaAnN, and valavaAnN, (Ḳ,) I. q. Einabu Alv-aEolabi; (Ḳ;) the tree thus called. (M, TA.)
valaAvN, also written valevN: see valaAvapN, in six places: and vulaAvu, in two places.

vulaAvu and mavolavu↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) Three and three; three and three together; or three at a time and three at a time; (L;) imperfectly decl. [because] changed from the original form of valaAvapN valaAvapN; (Ḳ;) or because of their having the quality of epithets and deviating from the original form of valaAvapN: they are epithets; for you say, mararotu biqawomK mavonaI wavulaAva [I passed by a party of men two and two, and three and three, together]: (Sb, Ṣ:) or they are imperfectly decl. because they deviate from their original as to the letter and the meaning; the original word being changed as above stated, and the meaning being changed to valaAvapN valaAvapN: but the dim. is vulay-ivN↓, perfectly decl., like OuHay-idN, &c., because it is like Humay-irN [dim. of HimaArN], assuming the form of that which is perfectly decl., though it is not so in the cases of OaHosanu and the like, as these words, in assuming the dim. form, do not deviate from the measure of a verb, for maA OuHayosinahu [How goodly is he!] is sometimes said. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [iv. 3], faQnokiHuwA maA TaAba lakumo mina Aln-isaMCi wavulaAva warubaAEa, i. e. Then marry ye such as please you, of women, two [and] two, and three [and] three, and four [and] four: [meaning, two at a time,, &c.:] here mvnI, &c. are imperfectly decl. because deviating from the original form of Aivonayoni Aivonayoni, &c., and from the fem. form. (Zj, T, L.) And one says mavolava mavolava↓, like vulaAva vulaAva. (T.) You say also, faEalotu AlX-aIoCa mavonaI wavulaAva warubaAEa, meaning I did the thing twice and twice, and thrice and thrice, and four times and four times. (L.)

[vulaAvN is app. fem. of vulaAvapN, a dial, var. of valaAvapN, of which the fem. is valaAvN: and hence,] cuw vulaAvK, with damm [to the initial v], A camel's [girth of the kind called] waDiyn. (Ḳ.) You say, Ailotaqato EuraA ciI vulaAvihaA ‡ [lit., The loops of her girth met together]; (A, TA; [but in a copy of the former, cI valaAvihaA↓;]) meaning, she was, or became, lean, or lank in the belly. (A. [See a similar saying voce biTaAnN.]) And a poet says,
waqado Damarato Hat-aI badaA cuw vulaAvihaA
[And she had become lean, or lank in the belly, so that her girth appeared]: but some say that cw vlAvhA [here] means her belly, and the two skins, [namely,] the upper, and that which is pared, or scraped off, after the flaying: (TA:) or, accord. to some, the phrase is Hat-aI QrotaqaI cw vlAvhA, meaning, so that her fœtus rose to her back; the vlAv [here again in a copy of the A written with fet-ḥ to the initial v, and in like manner vlAvhA,] being the saAbiyaMC and the salaA and the womb. (A, TA.) You say also Ealayohi cuw valaAvK↓, [so I find it written, but perhaps it should be cw vulaAvK,] meaning, ‡ Upon him is a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC made of the wool of three sheep. (A, TA. [In the latter without any syll. sign to show that vlAv here differs from the form in the exs. cited before.])
vilaAv: see vaAlivN.

valuwvN A she-camel that fills three vessels (Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ) such as are called OaqodaAH, (M, L,) when she is milked, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [i. e.,] at one milking. (A.) This is the utmost quantity that the camel yields at one milking. (IAạr, M.)

Also A she-camel three of whose teats dry up: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ: [accord. to the TA, it is said in the T that such is termed mavoluwvN↓; but I think that this is a mistranscription:]) or that has had one of her teats cut off (IAạr, T, M, L, Ḳ) by cauterization, which becomes a mark to her, (IAạr, M,) and [in some copies of the Ḳ “or”] is milked from three teats: (T, M, L, Ḳ:) or that has three teats; (IAạr, TA;) [and] so muval-ivapN↓: (T, TA:) or a she-camel having one of her teats dried up in consequence of something that has happened to it. (ISk.)
valiyvN: see vuluvN.

valaAvapN, also written valevapN, a noun of number, [i. e. Three,] is masc., (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and is also written and pronounced vulaAvapN↓, with damm: (IAạr, M, TA:) the fem. is valaAvN↓, also written valevN; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) [and app. vulaAvN also, mentioned above, under the head of vulaAvu, but only as occurring with cuw prefixed to it.] You say vulaAvapu rijaAlK [Three men]: and valaAvu↓ nisowapK [three women]. (Mṣb.) In the saying of Moḥammad, rufiEa Alqalamu Eano valaAvK↓ [The pen of the recording angel is withheld from three persons] vlAv is for valaAvi OanofusK. (Mṣb. [See art. rfE.]) [In like manner, valaAvN↓ occurs in several trads. for valaAvu xiSaAlK; as, for instance, in the saying,] valaAvN mano kun-a fiyhi HaAsabahu Qll-ehu HisaAbFA yasiyrFA [There are three qualities: in whomsoever they be, God will reckon with him with an easy reckoning]: these are, thy giving to him who denies thee, and forgiving him who wrongs thee, and being kind to him who cuts thee off from him. (El-Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer.) The people of El-Ḥijáz say, OatawoniI valaAvatahumo [The three of them came to me], and OarobaEatahumo, and so on to ten [inclusive], with nasb in every case; and in like manner in the fem., OatayonaniI valaAvahun-a↓, and OarobaEahun-a: but others decline the word with the three vowels, making it like kul-uhumo: after ten, however, only nasb is used; so that you say, OatawoniI OaHada EaXarahumo [and valaAvapa EaXarahumo], and UiHodaI EaXoratahun-a [and valaAva EaXoratahun-a]. (Ṣ.) The saying waladu Alz-inaA XarN Alv-alaAvapi means [The offspring of adultery, or fornication, is the worst of the three] if he do the deeds of his parents. (Mgh.) [It is said that when vlAvp means the things numbered, not the amount of the number, it is imperfectly decl., being regarded as a proper name; and so are other ns. of number. (See vumaAniypN.) See also sit-apN.]

valaAvapa EaXara [indecl. in every case, meaning Thirteen,] is pronounced by some of the Arabs valaAvapa EoXara: and [the fem.] valaAva↓ EaXorapa, thus in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz [and of most of the Arabs], is pronounced valaAva EaXirapa in the dial. of Nejd. (Ṣ in art. EXr.)
vulaAvapN: see valaAvapN.

Alv-alaAvaMCu, also written Alv-alevaMCu, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M,) or yawomu Alv-alaAvaMCi or Alv-alevaMCi, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Alv-ulaAvaMC↓, with damm, (A, Ḳ,) [meaning The third day of the week, Tuesday,] has this form for the sake of distinction; for properly it should be Alv-aAlivu: (Ṣ, M:) or it has meddeh in the place of the p in the noun of number [valaAvapN] to distinguish it from the latter: (Lth, T:) [it is without tenween in every case; when indeterminate as well as when determinate; being fem.:] the pl. is valaAvaAwaAtN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) and OavaAlivu. (Th, M.) It has no dim. (Sb, Ṣ in art. Ams.) Lḥ relates that Aboo-Ziyád used to say, maDaI Alv-alaAvaMCu bimaA fiyhi [Tuesday passed with what occurred in it]; making vlAvAC sing. and masc.; [but this he did because he meant thereby yawomu Alv-alaAvaMCi; ywm being masc.:] Th is related to have said, bimaA fiyhaA; making it fem.: and Abu-l-Jarráh used to say, maDati Alv-alaAvaMCu bimaA fiyhin-a, treating the word as a numeral. (M.)
Alv-ulaAvaMCu: see Alv-alaAvaMCu.
vulaAviI-N a rel. n. from valaAvapN, anomalously formed, (M,) [or regularly formed from vulaAvapN,] Of, or relating to, three things. (T, TA.)
Three cubits in length, or height; applied in this sense to a garment, or piece of cloth; (T, A;) and to a boy. (T.)
A word comprising, or composed of, three letters [radical only, or of three radical letters with one or more augmentative; i. e., of three radical letters with, or without, an augment]. (T, TA.)

[valaAvuwna, also written valevuwna,] the noun of number, [meaning Thirty, and also thirtieth,] is not considered as a multi ple of valaAvapN, but as a multi ple of EaXarapN; and therefore, if you name a man valaAvuwna, you do not make the dim. to be valiy-ivuwn, but [you assimilate the noun from which it is formed to a pl. with w and n from EaXarapN, or to EiXoruwna, and say] vulayovuwna↓. (Sb, M.)
vulayovuwna: see what immediately precedes.
valaAvaAwiI-N: One who fasts alone on the third day of the week. (IAạr, Th, M.)
vulay-ivN: see vulaAvu.

vaAlivN [Third]: fem. with p {vaAlivapN}. (T, &c.) The final v in Alv-aAlivu is sometimes changed into I. (M.) You say, huwa vaAlivu valaAvapK [He, or it, is the third of three]: thus you say when the two [terms] agree, each with the other; but not vaAlivN valaAvapF; vAlv being regarded in the former case as though it were a subst.; for you do not mean to convey by it a verbal signification, but only mean that he, or it, is one of the three, or a portion of the three: (Fr, ISk, T, Ṣ:) and in like manner you say, hiIa vaAlivapu valaAva [She is the third of three]; but when there is among the females a male, you say, hiIa vaAlivapu valaAvapK, making the masc. to predominate over the fem. (T.) When the two [terms] are different, you may make the former to govern the gen. case or to govern as a verb; saying, huwa raAbiEu valaAvapK or huwa raAbiEN valaAvapF, like as you say DaAribu zayodK and DaAribN zayodFA; and thus you also say, hecaA vaAlivu Qvonayoni and hecaA vaAlivN Qvonayoni, meaning This makes two to be three, with himself, or itself. (ISk, T,* Ṣ. [In most copies of the Ṣ, for vaAlivN Qvonayoni is put vaAliva Qvonayoni; and, in the explanation of this phrase, val-ava Qvonayoni for valava Qvonayoni: IB has remarked that these are mistakes.]) vilaAv↓ occurs in the sense of vaAliv in a trad. cited voce vaAnK in art. vnI. (Sh, T in art. vnI.)

vaAlivapu AlOavaAfiI means A projecting portion of a mountain, by which are placed two pieces of rock, upon all which is placed the cooking-pot. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, ramaAhu Qll-ehu bivaAlivapi AlOavaAfiI [explained in art. Avf]. (TA.)

[vaAliva EaXara and vaAlivapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Thirteenth, are generally held to be indecl. in every case without the art.; but with the art., most say in the nom. Alv-aAlivu EaXara, accus. Alv-aAliva EaXara, and gen. Alv-aAlivi EaXara; and in like manner in the fem. Accord. to some,] you say, huwa vaAlivu EaXara as well as huwa vaAliva EaXara [He, or it, is a thirteenth]: he who uses the former phrase says that he means huwa vaAlivu valaAvapa EaXara, (T, Ṣ,) i. e. He, or it, is one of thirteen, (T,) and that he suppresses vlAvh, and leaves vAlv decl. as it was; and he who uses the latter phrase says that he likewise means this, but that, suppressing vlAvp, he gives its final vowel to the word vAlv, (T, Ṣ,) to show that there is a suppression: (Ṣ:) but IB says that the former of these two phrases is wrong; that the Koofees allow it, but that the Basrees disallow it, and pronounce it a mistake. (L.) [And accord. to J, one says, hecaA Alv-aAliva EaXara and hecihi Alv-aAlivapa EaXorapa This is the thirteenth, or this thirteenth: for he adds,] and you say, hcaA AlHaAdiI EaXara and Alv-aAniIa EaXara and so on to twenty [exclusive]; all with fet-ḥ; for the reason which we have mentioned: and in like manner in the fem., in which each of the two nouns is with p. (Ṣ.) You say also, vaAliva EaXara valaAvapa EaXara [The thirteenth of thirteen]; and so on to taAsiEa EaXara tisoEapa EaXara: and in like manner in the fem. (I'AK p. 316.)
[Alv-aAluwvu The Trinity.]
mavolavu and mavolava: see vulaAvu.

mvlv [i. e. matolavN] signifies A chord [of a lute] composed of three twists: that which is of two twists is called mvnI [i. e. mavonFI]: or, as some say, these two words signify [respectively] the third chord and the second: their pls. are mavaAlivu and mavaAnK. (Ḥar p.244.)
muvolivN A she-camel, and any female, bringing forth her third young one, or offspring: one should not say naAqapN vilovN. (M.)
See also muval-ivN.

muval-avN A thing having three angles or corners, triangular [or trilateral]; a triangle. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say muval-avN HaAd-N [An acute-angled triangle]: and muval-avN qaAYimN [A right-angled triangle]. (TA.) And OaroDN muval-avapN A three-sided piece of land. (TA.)

A thing composed of three layers or strata, or of three distinct fascicles or the like; (M, TA;) [see also mavoluwvN;] and in like manner what are composed of four, and more, to ten [inclusive], are called by similar epithets: (TA:) or a thing of three folds. (Lth, T.)

[As a conventional term in lexicology, A word having a letter which has any of the three vowels: ex. gr., badoOapN is muval-avapu AlbaMCi; i. e., it is written badoOapN and budoOapN and bidoOapN. As such also, A verb having its Eayon (or middle radical letter) movent by any of the three vowels: ex. gr., bahaOa bihi is muval-avN; i. e., it is written bahaOa and bahuWa and bahiYa. And as such, muval-avapN (not muvolavapN) signifies Three-pointed; having three diacritical points: it is an epithet added to vaMC, to prevent its being mistaken for baMC or taMC or yaMC.]
Wine (XaraAb) cooked until the quantity of two thirds of it has gone; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the expressed juice of grapes so cooked. (Mgh.)
And A certain electuary, or confection, of aromatics, or perfumes. (KL.)

muval-ivN A calumniator, or slanderer, of his brother [or fellow] to his prince; because he destroys three; namely, himself and his brother and his prince: (Sh, T, M,* Ḳ:) as also muvolivN↓; (Ḳ;) or thus accord. to Aboo-'Owáneh. (Sh, T.)
See also vilovN, last sentence:
and see valuwvN.
mivolaAvN from vuluvN is like mirobaAEN from ruboEN. (M.) See vuluvN and mirobaAEN.
mavoluwvN Property of which a third part has been taken. (A.)

[Applied to a verse,] That of which a third has been taken away: (M, Ḳ:) whatever is mavoluwv is manohuwk: (TA:) or the former word signifies as above, and the latter signifies that of which two thirds have been taken away: this is the opinion of the authors on versification with respect to the metres called rajaz and munosariH: (M, TA:) the mvlwv in poetry is that whereof two feet out of six have gone. (TA.)

A rope composed of three strands (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) twisted together, (Lth, T, A,) and in like manner woven, or plaited: (Lth, T:) and ropes composed of four, five, six, seven, and nine, strands, but not of eight nor of ten, are similarly called. (M.)
A garment of the kind called kisaMC woven of wool and camels' hair (wabar) and goats' hair (XaEar). (Fr, T.)
mazaAdapN mavolawvapN A mzAdp [or leathern water-bag] made of three skins. (T. Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
OaroDN mavoluwvapN Land turned over three times for sowing or cultivating. (A.)
See also valuwvN.

1. valajati Als-amaMCu, aor. _u {yavoluju} and _i {yavoliju}, The sky snowed; let fall snow. (A, TA.) [Here, and in other cases, throughout this art., the meaning of valojN is assumed to be well known.]

valajatonaA Als-amaMCu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavoluju}; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and OavolajatonaA↓; (Mṣb,* Ḳ;) The sky snowed upon us; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like as one says maTaratonaA. (Ṣ.) And vulijuwA They were snowed upon. (TA.) You say, vulijonaA AlEaAma valojFA kaviyrFA [We were snowed upon this year much]. (A.) And vulijati AlOaroDu, (A, Mṣb, TA,) and Ouvolijat↓, (TA,) The land was snowed upon. (A,* Mṣb, TA.*)

[vulija, said of water, &c., It was cooled, or made cold, with snow: see an ex. voce mavoluwjN. In the present day, val-ajahu↓ signifies He cooled it, or made it cold, with snow or ice; iced it; froze it.]
See also 4.

[Hence,] valija, (IAạr, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yavolaju}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. valajN, (TA,) † His heart became cool, or refreshed, and relieved of a thing: (IAạr:) and he rejoiced; or was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and he was, or became, at ease, at rest, tranquil, or free from disquietude. (TA.) And valijato nafosuhu bikacaA ‡ His mind became refreshed and happy by means of such a thing. (A.) And valajato nafosiI, aor. _u {yavoluju}, inf. n. vuluwjN; (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and valijato, aor. _a {yavolaju}, inf. n. valajN; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ; [in the CK valoj;]) and Oavolajato↓; (Ḳ;) biAlX-aIoCi; (TA;) † My mind became at ease, at rest, tranquil, or free from disquietude, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and became healed, by means of the thing: (TA:) or I knew it, and was rejoiced at it, or by it: or my mind became at ease, and I confided, or trusted, in the thing: as also vljtu Uilayohi; and vlj SadoriI: or this last, accord. to Sh, means my bosom became dilated [with joy], liloOamori at the event. (TA.) And vljtu bimaA xab-arotaniI † I became healed, and my heart became at rest, or tranquil, by means of the information which thou gavest me. (ISk, TA.) And valaja qalobuhu and valija, the latter mentioned by Lb, on the authority of 'AbdEl-Hakk, ‡ His heart became certified, or assured. (TA.) valajN is said to mean ‡ Certitude, or assurance, because it is taken from the delight that one has in water rendered cool, or cold, by means of snow and the like. (TA.)
vulija fuWaAduhu ‡ He was, or became, stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence: (IAạr, A, TA:) his heart, or his mind, or intellect, quitted him. (TA.)
valajahu, (Sh, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavoluju}, inf. n. valojN, (Sh, TA,) also signifies He, or it, soaked it; moistened it. (Sh, Ḳ, TA.)
2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4. Avlj It (a day, Ṣ, Ḳ, or a year, A) was, or became, snowy. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
He reached, came upon, or lighted on, snow; (Ḳ;) as also vlj [written without any syll. signs, app. valaja↓]. (TA.) He entered upon [a tract, or time, or season, of] snow. (TA.)
OavolajatonaA Als-amaMCu: and Ouvolijati AlOaroDu: see 1.
[Thus the verb is intrans. and trans. And hence,] Oavolajato nafosiI: see 1.

And Avljhu † He rejoiced him; made him joyful, glad, or happy. (Ḳ.) And Avlj SadoriI ‡ It (news, or information,) healed and tranquillized me. (A,* TA.) And maA OavolajaniI bihecaA AlOamori † How joyful, or happy, am I made by this thing, or event! (TA.)
[Hence also,] Hafara Hat-aI Avlj ‡ He dug until he reached the clay, or mud, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or the cold of the moist earth, (A,) or the moist earth and the water. (TA.)
Avlj maMCu AlbiYori ‡ The water of the well ceased, or stopped. (A, Ḳ.) And hence, (TA.) Avljt Eanohu AlHum-aI ‡ The fever quitted him. (A, TA.)
UivolaAjN [the inf. n.] is also syn. with UifolaAjN [inf.n. of Oafolaja, q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: valojN [Snow;] a thing well known, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) that falls from the sky: (TA:) pl. vuluwjN. (Mṣb.)
valijN Cold: (Ḳ:) applied to water. (TA.)
vulujN † Men joyful, glad, or happy, by reason of news. (IAạr, TA.)
† Men who are stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence. (TA.) [See also mavoluwjN.]
valojiI-N: see val-aAjN.
vulaAjiI-N ‡ Very white: applied to an iron head of an arrow or of a spear or of a sword or the like: (A, Ḳ:) fem. with p {vulaAjiy-apN}. (A.)
val-aAjN A seller of snow; (Ḳ;) as also valojiI-N↓. (TA.)
mavolajapN A place in which is [kept] snow [for cooling water, &c. in summer]. (Ḳ.)
mavoluwjN: fem. with p {mavoluwjapN}: the latter applied to land (OaroD), meaning Snowed upon. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)

Water cooled, or made cold, with snow. (TA.) A poet says, speaking of a woman's mouth,
yuxaAlu mavoluwjFA waUin lamo yuvolaji
[It would be thought to be cooled with snow, though it was not cooled therewith]. (TA.)
mavoluwju AlfuWaAdi ‡ A man (Ṣ) stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also vulujN.]

hom.sense: 1. valaTa, aor. _i {yavoliTu}. (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ.) inf.n. valoTN, (Az, Ṣ,) He (a camel, Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ, and a bull, IAth, Ḳ, and an elephant, mostly said of these three animals, IAth, and a man, Az, and a child, Ḳ) voided his dung in a thin state. (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., (Ṣ, TA,) of ʼAlee, (TA,) kaAnuwA yaboEaruwna baEorFA waOanotumo tavoliTuwna valoTFA, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning that the former ate little, and that the latter ate much and of various kinds. (TA.)
valaTa fulaAnFA He threw valoT, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. thin dung, (TA,) at such a one: (Ḳ, TA:) and he befouled him, or smeared him, therewith. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: valoTN Thin dung of an elephant and the like, (Lth, Ḳ,) and of anything, when it is thin. (TA.)
mavolaTN, (Ḳ, TA, [but by rule it should be mavoliTN,]) or mavolaTapN, (CK,) The place of exit of valoT. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. valamahu, aor. _i {yavolimu}, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. valomN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) He broke its edge; (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, that of a vessel, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of a sword, and the like; (M, Ḳ;) as also valimahu, aor. _a {yavolamu} (Ḳ, TA; [but I suspect that this latter form of the verb has been taken from a copy of the Ṣ in which the intrans. verb valima has been erroneously made trans,;]) and vl-mhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) or this last signifies he did so much, or in many places: (Ṣ:) and the first signifies also he made a gap, or breach, in it; namely, a wall. (T,* Ṣ.)

[Hence,] vulima fiI maAlihi, (TA,) or vulima fiI maAlihi valomapF, (M,) ‡ He suffered the loss of somewhat of his property. (M, TA.) And hecaA mim-aA yakolimu Ald-iyna wayavolimu Alyaqiyna † [This of the things that wound religion and impair sure faith]. (TA.)

valima, aor. _a {yavolamu}, inf. n. valamN; (Ṣ;) and Anvlm↓, and tvl-m↓; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said of a thing, (Ṣ,) a vessel, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a sword, and the like, (M, Ḳ,) It was, or became, broken in its edge: (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or ↓the last, being quasi-pass. of 2, it was, or became, broken much, or in several places, in its edge:] and Anvlm↓ and tvl-m↓ are said of a wall [as signifying it had a gap or breach, or gaps or breaches, made in it]. (T.) valamN, [the inf. n. of valima,] when relating to a valley, signifies The having its Harof, (T, M, Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ, [meaning brink, or edge,]) or its juruf, (so in other copies of the Ṣ, [meaning its abrupt, water-worn, bank,]) broken; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) i. e., broken down: (TA:) and in like manner, in relation to a trench dug round a tent to prevent the rain-water from entering it, and in relation to a watering-trough, or tank. (M, TA.) [Golius and Freytag have explained it as signifying the part so broken; but I do not think that this can be meant by the explanation given above.]

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
5: see 1, in three places.
7: see 1, in two places.
You say also, AnvlmwA Ealayohi They poured forth, or down, upon him, or against him; as also Anvl-wA. (Z, TA.)
valomN A break of the edge in a vessel (ISk, T, Ṣ) and in a sword. (T, Ṣ.) [See also what next follows.]

vulomapN A gap, or breach, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in a wall, &c., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or of a thing that is broken, and of a thing ruined, (Ḳ,) or of a broken edge: (M:) or a place that has been broken in an edge, or that has had a gap, or breach, made in it: (T, TA:) a broken place of a vessel: (TA:) pl. vulamN. (T, Mṣb.) [See also valomN.]

[Hence,] mawotu fulaAnK vulomapN fiI AlUisolaAmi vulomapN laA tusad-u ‡ [The death of such a one is an occasion of a gap in the body of the Muslims; a gap that will not be filled up]. (TA.) [See also its syn. xal-apN.]

hom.sense: Oavolamu A thing [such as a vessel and a sword and the like] broken in its edge: (Ṣ:) a wateringtrough, or tank, broken in its side. (TA.)
OavolamN Dust, or earth; 'and stones; like OavolabN; accord. to El-Hejeree: but [ISd adds,] whether it be a dial. var. or formed by substitution, I know not. (M.)

entry.sense: 1. vam-ahu, (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavomumu}, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. vam-N, (T, Ṣ, M,) He repaired it; or put it into a good, sound, or right, state; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) [by filling up its interstices, &c.,] with vumaAm [q. v.]. (Ṣ.) Hence the saying, vamamotu OumuwriI † I put my affairs into a good, sound, right, or proper, state; restored them to such a state; or set them right, or in order. (Ṣ.) And hence also the saying, kun-aA Oahola vam-ihi waram-ihi † [We were the fit persons to put it into a good, sound, right, or proper, state;, &c.]; (Ṣ;) occurring in a trad.; accord. to the relaters thereof, vum-ihi↓ warum-ihi; but AʼObeyd holds the former reading to be the right. (T.)
He spread vumaAm for it, namely, a skin of milk, and put it [vmAm] above it, in order that the sun might not strike it, and its milk become consequently decomposed, or curdled. (T.)
[He stuffed it, either with vumaAm or absolutely: for] vum-a signifies it was stuffed. (T.)

He collected it together; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; (Ṣ, M;) mostly used in relation to dry herbage. (M, Ḳ.) You say, vum-a lahaA, i. e. Collect thou [for them; namely, the cattle, &c.; like vimo lahaA from wavama]. (TA.) And huwa yavum-uhu wayaqum-uhu He sweeps it, and collects the good and the bad. (Ṣ.)
vam-a AlT-aEaAma, (M, Ḳ,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (M,) He ate the good of the food and the bad thereof; (M, Ḳ;) as also qam-ahu. (TA.)

vam-atopu, (T,* Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) She (a ewe or a goat, M, Ḳ, or, as some say, only the latter, M) pulled it, or plucked it, up, or out, with her mouth; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) namely, a thing, (T, M,) or a plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and anything by which she passed. (TA.)
vam-a yadahu biAlHaXiyXi, (M, Ḳ,) or biAlOaroDi, (Ṣ, M,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (TA,) He wiped his hand (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) with the dry herbage, (M, Ḳ,) or upon the ground. (Ṣ, M.)

vam-a There; syn. hunaAka; (Zj, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) a noun of indication, (Zj, T, M, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ,) denoting a place that is remote (Zj, T, Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ) from the speaker, (Zj, T, M,) like as hunaA denotes that which is near; (Zj, T, Ṣ;) or denoting a place other than that of the speaker: (Mṣb:) it is an adverbial noun, not to be used otherwise than as such; (Mughnee, Ḳ;)
indecl. because of its vagueness, and with fet-ḥ for its termination to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters. (Zj, T, M.) Thus in the saying [in the Ḳur xxvi. 64], waOazolafonaA vam-a AlMxariyna [And we brought near, there, the others]. (Mughnee.) He who makes it decl. as an objective complement (Mughnee, Ḳ) in this ex., (Mughnee,) and in the saying in the Ḳur [lxxvi. 20], waUicaA raOayota vam-a raOayota naEiymFA, is in error: (Mughnee, Ḳ:*) Zj says that the meaning is, And when thou castest thine eyes, or thy sight, there, thou shalt behold [scenes of] enjoyment: that Fr asserted the meaning to be, UicaA raOayota maA vam-a [when thou seest what is there]; but that this is an error; for mA, accord. to this interpretation, is a conjunct noun, and it is not allowable to suppress a conjunct noun and leave its complement. (T.)
[mino vam-a is used by post-classical writers as meaning Therefore; for that reason; on that account.]

vum-a, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) for which one also says fum-a, (M, Mughnee,) substituting f for the v, (M,) and vum-ata (T, Ṣ, M) and vum-ato, (M, TA,) but vum-ata is the more common, (Mughnee and Ḳ on the letter t,) and fum-ata and fum-ato, (M, TA,) [meaning Then, i. e., afterward, or afterwards,] a particle, (M, Ḳ,) or conjunction, (Zj, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee,) denoting order (Zj, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Mughnee) and a delay, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or having three properties, namely, that of virtually associating in the same case [the latter of the two members which it conjoins with the former of them], and denoting order, and denoting a delay; but respecting all of these there is a difference of opinions. (Mughnee, Ḳ.*) As to the associating in the same case, Akh and the Koofees assert that it sometimes fails to have this property, by its occurring redundantly, so as not to be a conjunction at all; and they hold to accord with this assertion the saying in the Ḳur [ix. 119], Hat-aI UicaA DaAqato Ealayohimu QloOaroDu bimaA raHubato waDaAqato Ealayohimo Oanofusuhumo waZan-uwA Oano laA malojaOa mina Qll-ehi Uil-aA Uilayohi vum-a taAba Ealayohimo [Until, when the earth became strait to them, notwithstanding its amplitude, and their minds became straitened to them, and they knew that there was no repairing for refuge from God save unto Him, then He returned to forgiveness towards them]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:*) but this has been resolved by the subaudition of the complement [of what precedes vum-a, as though the meaning were, then (they betook themselves unto Him, begging forgiveness, and) He returned, &c.]. (Mughnee.) And as to its denoting order, some hold that there are exs. of its not necessarily implying this; (Mughnee, Ḳ;*) one of which is the saying in the Ḳur [xxxix. 8], xalaqakumo mino nafosK waAHidapK vum-a jaEala minohaA zawojahaA: (Mughnee: [in which are added other similar exs., one of which is given in the Ḳ:]) but to this there are five replies: 1st, that this passage is elliptical; the meaning being, He created you from one person (which He originated); then He made therefrom its mate: 2nd, that the meaning is, He created you from a person that was alone; then, &c.: 3rd, that the progeny of Adam were made to come forth from his back like little ants; then Eve was created from his [rib called the] quSayoraI: 4th, that the creation of Eve from Adam being unusual, vm- is used to notify its order and posteriority in respect of wonderfulness and of the manifestation of power; not to denote order and posteriority of time: 5th, that vm- is here used to denote the order of enunciation; not the virtual order: the replies preceding this last are better than it, inasmuch as they verify the order and the delay; whereas the last verifies the order only, as there is no delay between the two enunciations; but the last reply is of more common application, applying to the ex. given above and to others: (Mughnee:) Fr says that the meaning of the ex. given above is, He created you from a person (which He created) single; then, &c.; and in like manner says Zj. (T.) And as to its denoting a delay, Fr asserts that sometimes this is not the case, as is shown by the saying, OaEojabaniI maA SanaEota Alyawoma vum-a maA SanaEota Oamosi OaEojabu [What thou didst to-day excited my wonder, or admiration, or pleasure; then (I tell thee) what thou didst yesterday was more wonderful, or admirable, or pleasing]; for vm- is here used to denote the order of the enunciation; not a delay between the two enunciations. (Mughnee, Ḳ.*)

[It is said that] it denotes order and a delay when it conjoins single words: but Akh says that it has the meaning of wa [And], because it is used in cases in which there is no order; as in waQll-ehi vum-a waQll-ehi laOafoEalan-a [By God, and (I say again,) By God, I will assuredly do such a thing]: and when it conjoins propositions, it does not necessarily denote order, but has the meaning of wa: (Mṣb:) it has the meaning of wa, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) the conjunction, (Ṣ,) in the saying in the Ḳur [x. 47], vum-a Qll-ehu XahiydN EalaI maA yafoEaluwna [And God is witness of what they do]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

The Koofees allow its being used in the manner of fa and wa so as that the aor. immediately following it after a conditional verb may be man- soob: and Ibn-Málik allows its being thus used so as that the aor. immediately following it after the expression of a desire that the thing shall not be done may be marfooa and mejzoom and man- soob. (Mughnee.)

hom.sense: vum-N: see vumaAmN.

In the saying maA lahu vum-N walaA rum-u [He has not vum- nor rum-], the former of these two nouns signifies water-skins, or milk-skins, and vessels; (M;) or what is bad, or the worst, of those things, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to ISk; (Ṣ;) or men's household-goods, or furniture and utensils, and their water-skins, or milk-skins, and vessels; (T, TA;) which last is the right meaning: (TA:) and the latter noun signifies maram-apu Albayoti [app. meaning, accord. to analogy, (for I find no suitable explanation of it in any of the lexicons,) the means by which a house, or tent, is put into a good state; and therefore, good furniture and utensils]. (ISk, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) You say also, maA yamoliku vum-FA walaA rum-FA, meaning the same: (Ṣ, TA:) or he possesses not little nor much: it is not used save with a negation. (M, TA.) An Arab of the desert said, jaEojaEa biIa Ald-ahoru Eano vum-ihi warum-ihi, [thus in some copies of the Ṣ, and in the TA, in which latter the last two nouns are expressly said to be with damm, but in two copies of the Ṣ, in this instance, erroneously written, vam-ihi waram-ihi,] i. e. [Fortune has debarred me] from its little and its much. (Ṣ, TA.) And hence the saying of the vulgar, jaMCa biAlv-um-i waAlr-um-i, except that they pronounce both these nouns with kesr, meaning He brought little and much. (TA.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: vam-apN: see vumaAmN.
vum-apN A handful of dry herbage. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Also n. un. of vum-N, which is syn. with vumaAmN: see the next paragraph in six places.

vumaAmN [Panicum, or panic grass; applied to several species thereof; but restricted by Forskål (Flor. Aeg. Ar., descr. plant., p. 20, where its Arabic name is written “tummâm,”) to panicum dichotomum; called by Delile (Flor. Aeg., no. 58, where its Arabic name is written “temâm,”) pennisetum dichotomum; and described by him in the “explication des planches” accompanying his Flora, plate 8: the Arabs use it for making thatch for their huts:] a kind of plant, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the M termed XajarN,]) well known in the desert, not desired, or not much eaten, by the camels, or cattle, except in a case of scarcity, or drought; (T;) weak, or frail; having what are termed xuwS [q. v.], or what resemble xwS, sometimes used for stuffing, (Ṣ, TA,) and for stopping up the interstices of houses; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and sometimes used for removing whiteness from the eye: (Ḳ:) accord. to Az, it is of several species, one of which is the DaEap, and another is the jaliylap, and another is the garaf, which resembles rushes (Ousal), and brooms are made of it, and water-bags are covered with it to protect them from the sun, causing the water to become cool: (TA:) [see also OumoSuwxapN:] it is also called vayomuwmN↓, (Ḳ,) and vum-apN↓, [but see what follows,] (T, M,) which is sometimes contracted into vumapN; (T;) or it is also called vum-N↓, of which vum-apN↓ is the n. un.: (AḤn, TA:) the n. un. of vumaAmN is [likewise] with p {vumaAmapN}. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say of a thing that may be reached, or taken with the hand, without difficulty, (T, Z, Ḳ,) huwa EalaI Tarafi Alv-umaAmi, (IAạr, T, M, Z, Ḳ,*,) i. e. † It is easy to thee, or within thy reach, no obstacle intervening between thee and it: (IAạr, M:) because the vmAm is not tall, (T, Ḳ,) so that the reaching it should be difficult. (T.) And huwa laka EalaI raOosi Alv-um-api↓ [meaning the same]. (M.) And huwa EalaI raOosi Alv-um-api↓, (TA,) or laka celika EalaI raOosi Alv-um-api↓, † [That is easy of attainment to thee], (M,) is a prov. used in relation to the attainment of a thing that one wants. (M, TA.) The Arabs also say, huwa Oabuwhu EalaI Tarafi Alv-um-api↓, meaning † He is like his father: and some of them say Alv-am-ap↓, with fet-ḥ. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, AugozuwA waAlgazowu HulowN xaDirN qabola Oano yaSiyra vumaAmFA vum-a rumaAmFA vum-a HuTaAmFA † [Engage ye in predatory warfare while it is sweet and fresh], meaning, while ye see, and make abundant, your spoils, before it become feeble like the vmAm; [then, decayed; then, broken up.] (TA.)
It also signifies What has become dry, or dried up, of the branches that are placed beneath the naDad [q. v.]. (M.)
vamuwmN A sheep (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) or goat (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) that pulls, or plucks, up, or out, with her mouth, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) a thing, (T, M,) or a plant: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and that eats vumaAm. (M, TA.)
vayomuwmN: see vumaAmN.

mivam-N (like misan-N, Ḳ [in the CK, erroneously, muvim-, like musin-,]) One who pastures for him who has no pastor, (T, Ḳ,) or no pasturage, (TA,) and lends a beast or camel for riding or carrying, to him who has no beast or camel for riding or carrying (yufoqiru mano laA Zahora lahu, [in the CK, erroneously, yafoqiru,]) and sets right (yavum-u [in the CK, erroneously, yavim-u]) what the tribe are unable to manage, of their affair: (T, Ḳ:) so explained by ISh. (T.) And A man who is strong; who comes after, and aids, those who have recourse to him in need; and bears, or carries, what is redundant, or in excess; and repels the riders. (T.) And rajulN miEam-N mivam-N milam-N A man who sets right an affair, and manages it, or acts vigorously in it. (IAạr, T.)

rajulN mivam-N wamiqam-N and mivam-apN↓ wamiqam-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which latter phrase the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification, (Ṣ,) A man who sweeps and collects the good and the bad of a thing: (Ṣ:) or who eats the good of the food and the bad thereof. (Ḳ.) [See also mixam-apN, in art. xm.]
mivam-apN: see what next precedes.
mavomuwmN, applied to a house or chamber, (M, Ḳ,) and to a skin containing milk [&c.], (M,) Covered with vumaAm. (M, Ḳ.)
vum-at and vum-ato: see vum-a.

hom.sense: 1. vamadahu, aor. _u {yavomudu}, inf. n. vamodN, He took forth, or dug out, from it (i. e. a vamad q. v. infrà) the earth, in order that the water might come forth; (M, L;) as also Avmdhu↓, (so in the TA, and in the TT from the M,) or Aiv-amadahu↓, (accord. to the L,) and Astvmdhu↓. (M, L.)
Also, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He took it (At-xchu) as a vamad; and so Avmdhu↓ and Astvmdhu↓. (Ḳ, TA. [But see 8 below.])
[Hence, ‡ He begged of him until he exhausted him of what he possessed. (A meaning indicated, but not expressed, in the A.)]
And vamadotu Aln-aAqapa biAlHalobi ‡ I exhausted the she-camel by milking. (A.)
And vamadatohu Aln-isaMCu ‡ Women exhausted him of his seminal fluid. (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ. In the CK vam-adatohu.)
‡ He gave him a gift. (A.)
4: see 1, in two places.
Avmd Eayonahu He applied Uivomid as a collyrium to his eye. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 8. Avtmd and Aiv-amada He (a man, Ṣ) came to a vamad [q. v.] to drink. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Avtmd vamadFA He made, or prepared, (At-xc,) a vamad. (ISk, L.) See also 1.
10. Astvmdhu: see 1, in two places.
[Hence,] ‡ He sought of him a gift, (A,) or a benefit, a favour, or an act of kindness. (Ḳ.)
11. AvmAd-: see 1.
Q. Q. 4. AivomaOad-a: see 1.
vamodN: see what next follows.

vamadN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and vamodN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and vimaAdN↓, (M, Ḳ,) or the last is a pl. of one of the two preceding words, (MF,) Water that is little in quantity, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) that has no continual increase: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) or a little water remaining in a tract of hard, or hard and level, ground: or what appears in winter and goes away in summer (AlS-ayof): (M, Ḳ:) or a small round hollow or cavity (qalot) in which the rainwater collects and from which men drink during two months of the spring-season (AlS-ayof), but which fails when the summer (AlqayoZ) comes: (IAạr, T:) and rain-water that remains retained beneath the sand, and, when this is removed, is yielded by the ground: (A:) pl. vimaAdN (T, A) and OavomaAdN [a pl. of pauc.]: (so in the L:) some say that vimaAdN signifies holes dug or excavated, in which is a little water; and hence AʼObeyd says, sujirati Alv-imaAdu, meaning that the holes, &c. were filled by the rain; but he does not explain it: (M:) or vimaAdN signifies wells dug around a place which has been prepared to receive the water of the rain, where there is continually rain-water, this place having water-courses, and the said wells being filled therefrom: men drink the water that lies open to view until it becomes dried up by the effect of the hot winds of summer; the wells remaining. (Aboo-Málik, T.)
vimaAdN: see vamadN.
vaAmidN A lamb or kid or calf that has begun to eat. (Ṣ.)

UivomidN [An ore of antimony: or antimony itself; stibium; or stimmi:] collyrium-stone (Hajaru AlkuHoli), (Ḳ, TA,) which is black inclining to red, the mines whereof are in Ispahán, whence the best is obtained, and in the West, whence the hardest is obtained: (TA:) a certain stone used as a collyrium: (Ṣ:) a certain stone from which collyrium (kuHol) is prepared: or collyrium (kuHol) itself: (M:) or a substance resembling it: (Seer, M:) or a species thereof: (Lth, T:) or black kuHol, the mine whereof is in the East: said by some of the lawyers to be that of Ispahán: and said to be an arabicized word. (Mṣb.) The women of the Arabs used also to sprinkle [or rub] it upon the lips and gums, in order that the teeth might glisten the more. (EM p. 62.) [And for the same purpose, many of them tattoo their lips, so as to make them of a uniform dull bluish hue.]

One says of a man who remains awake at night, journeying or working, fulaAnN yajoEalu All-ayola UivomidFA [Such a one makes the night a collyrium]; the blackness of the night being as though it were a collyrium to his eyes because he labours all the night in seeking the means of attaining to eminence. (AA, T, L.)
mavomuwdN A water exhausted by the crowding of men to it, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) except the smaller portion of it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And [hence,] ‡ A man exhausted of what he possessed, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) by his giving when asked, (M, Ḳ,) or in consequence of much begging. (T, Ṣ, M, A.)
And ‡ A man exhausted of his seminal fluid by women. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. vamara: see 4, in three places.
Also It (fruit) was, or became, ripe. (T.)
vamira, aor. _a {yavomaru}, ‡ It (a man's wealth) became abundant. (A, TA.)
fulaAnN majoduwdu maA yavomaru ‡ [Such a one is fortunate in the abundance of his wealth: or] such a one possesses wealth. (A, TA.)
2. vm-r, inf. n. tavomiyrN, It (a plant) shook off its blossoms, [or shed them,] and organized and compacted (in the M Eaqada, and in the Ḳ Eaq-ada) its fruit. (AḤn, M, Ḳ.)

vm-r Als-iqaMCu, inf. n. as above; and Avmr↓; ‡ The skin [of milk] showed upon it the forming of the butter in little clots: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:) and vm-r All-ibanu, and Avmr↓, (T,* A,) ‡ the milk, being churned, showed upon it what resembled dry scabs on the skin, (T, A,) previously to their becoming large and collecting together and forming butter: and you say of the skin [containing it], vm-r and Avmr↓: (T:) and Avmr↓ Alz-ubodu † the butter collected together. (T.)
Also † He (God) made a man's wealth abundant. (Ṣ) And ‡ He (a man) increased, and made abundant, his wealth. (M, Ḳ.)
He (a man) had fruit that had come forth but that was not yet ripe. (T.)
‡ He (a man) became abundant in wealth; (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also vamara↓, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavomuru}, (TA,) inf. n. vumuwrN. (A, TA.)
maA Oavomara Qbonu vamiyrK↓ ‡ [As long as the moonlight-night renews itself, or recurs; i. e. ever]. (TA.)
See also 2, in four places.
This verb is mentioned by most of the lexicologists only as intrans.; but it is also trans., signifying It [a tree, or ‡ other thing,] produced fruit, ‡, &c. (Shifá el-Ghaleel, MF.)
Also He fed a person with fruits. (TA.)

entry.sense: vumorN: see vamarN, in two places.

vamarN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vamurN↓ (Sb, M, A) and viymaArN↓, (M,) [coll. gen. ns.,] The fruit of trees; (M, Ḳ;) the several kinds of fruits; (T;) the fruit which a tree produces, whether it is eaten or not eaten: (Mṣb:) pl. of the first, vimaArN; and pl. pl. (i. e. pl. of vimaArN, Fr, Ṣ, M, Mṣb) vumurN; and pl. pl. pl. (i. e. pl. of vumurN, Ṣ, Mṣb) OavomaArN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and the pl. of OavomaArN is OavaAmiyru; (IHsh, TA:) or vumurN is pl. of vamarN; (AHeyth, TA;) or it may be pl. of vamarapN, because it is of a form more common as that of a pl. of a word of this form than of the form of vimaArN: (M:) vamarapN is the n. un. of vamarN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and vamurapN is that of vamurN: (Sb, M, Ḳ:*) the pl. of vamarapN is vamaraAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and vamoraMCu↓: (Ḳ:) [or rather this last is a quasi-pl. n.:] vamurapN, which none but Sb mentions, has, accord. to him, no broken pl.: (M:) IHsh says that there is no word like vamarN in its series of pls. except OakamN. (MF: see OakamapN.)

Also vamarN, (M, A, Ḳ,) or vamurN↓, (T, Ṣ,) and vumorN↓, (Ṣ,) and vamaArN↓, (Ḳ,) or viymaArN↓, (M,) or vayomaArN↓; (TA;) of which last three, the first (vmAr) is disapproved by several writers; and some say that it is for vamarN, the second vowel being lengthened for the sake of metre; (MF;) ‡ Property, or wealth, (T, Ṣ,) increased and multiplied: (Ṣ:) or various kinds of property or wealth, (I’Ab, M, Ḳ,) increased and multiplied, and gained, or acquired, for oneself: (I’Ab, B:) or, accord. to Mujáhid, vamarN, in the Ḳur, means fruit; and vamurN↓, property, or wealth; but Yoo did not admit this, app. holding both to mean the same: (T:) in the Ḳur xviii. 32, AA read vumorN↓, and explained it as signifying kinds of property or wealth. (Ṣ.)
vamarN also signifies ‡ Gold and silver: (AAF, M, Ḳ:) so accord. to Mujáhid in the Ḳur xviii. 32; but this is not known in the proper language. (AAF, M.)
And Trees [or shrubs]: (TA:) and vamarapN a tree [or shrub]. (Th, M, Ḳ. [In the CK, erroneously, vamorap.])

And [the n. un.] vamarapN, [in the CK, erroneously, vamorap,] ‡ A child, or son; (Ḳ, B, TA;) as also vamarapu Alqalobi, [of which other meanings will be found below,] and vamarapu AlfuWaAdi [lit., like the next preceding expression, fruit of the heart]: accord. to some, in the Ḳur ii. 150, Alv-amaraAt means AlOawolaAd [or children] and AlOaHofaAd [or grandchildren,, &c.]. (B, TA.)

† Progeny; or offspring. (Ḳ.) [Whence, app.,] quTiEato vamaratuhu † His [power of] procreating was cut off: or his appetite for sexual intercourse. (TA from a trad.) [Another meaning of this phrase will be found below.]

† The fruit, as meaning the profit, of a thing: (Mṣb, TA:) as that of knowledge, namely, good works; and that of good works, namely, Paradise. (TA.) Hence, layosa lahu vamarapN † There is no profit pertaining to it. (Mṣb.) [Hence also,] vamarapu maAlK † The increase of property. (A.)

‡ The knot of the extremity, (A,) or of the extremities, (Ḳ,) of a whip; (A, Ḳ;) because like a fruit in its form and in its manner of hanging: (B, TA:) and vamarN, the knots of the extremities of whips: (Ṣ, Mj, Mgh:) or the former signifies the end, or extremity, of a whip: (T:) or, more correctly, the tail, which is [the appendage that forms] the end, or extremity, of a whip; its Eacabap. (Mgh.)
‡ The extremity, (T, Ḳ,) or tip, (A,) of the tongue: (T, A, Ḳ:) or its lower extremity. (IAth, TA.)

‡ A man's prepuce: pl. vimaArN: so in the phrases quTiEato vamarapu fulaAnK, and quTiEato vimaAruhumo, meaning ‡ Such a one was circumcised, and they were circumcised. (A.) [Another meaning of the former of these phrases has been mentioned above.]
† The skin of the head. (ISh, T, Ḳ.)

vamarapu Alqalobi [of which one meaning has been given above] also signifies † The heart's core; or the black, or inner, part of the heart; syn. suwayodaAWuhu, and Hab-atuhu. (Ṣ in art Hb.) [Hence,] xaS-aniI bivamarapi qalobihi ‡ [He distinguished me peculiarly, or specially,] by his love, or affection. (A, TA.) And OaEoTaAhu Safoqapa yadihi wavamarapa qalobihi ‡ [He gave him his ratification of the bargain, and] his sincerest agreement. (A, TA.)
fiI Als-imaMCi vamarapN and vamarN ‡ In the sky is a small portion, or quantity, of cloud. (A, TA.)
vamaru AlHin-aMCi: see art. HnO.
See also vamiyrN.
vamurN: see vamarN, in three places.
OaroDN vamirapN: see vamoraMCu.

maA nafosiI laka bivamirapK ‡ My mind has no sweetness for thee: (Ḳ, TA:) but accord. to Z, in the A, art. tmr, the last word in this phrase is with t, and so it is written in the Ḳ in that art., and explained as meaning Tay-ibapN [or agreeably affected]. (TA.)

hom.sense: vamoraMCu: see vamarN, first sentence.

entry.sense: vamaArN: see vamarN, second sentence.
vamiyrN; fem. with p {vamiyrapN}: hence XajarapN vamiyrapN, and OaroDN vamiyrapN: see vamoraMCu.

vamiyrN also signifies † Milk of which the butter has not come forth; (M, Ḳ;) and so vamiyrpN↓: (Ḳ:) or both signify milk of which the butter has appeared: (M, Ḳ:) or labanN vamiyrN, milk of which the butter has not been taken forth: (TA in art. jhr:) or milk of which the butter has formed into little clots: (IAth, TA:) and labanN muvam-irN↓ [in like manner], milk fit for churning, and showing upon it the formation of little clots of butter: (Aṣ, M:) and vamiyrapN↓, (as some say, M,) ‡ what appears, of butter, before it collects together (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ) and attains the time of its becoming in a good, or proper, state: (Ṣ, M:) and vamarN↓, what is seen upon milk, when it has been churned, resembling dry scabs on the skin, (T, A,) is also termed the vamiyrap↓ of milk. (T.) [See 2.]
Aibonu vamiyrK ‡ The moonlight-night, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) when the moon is full; (TA;) [contr. of Aibonu samiyrK.] See 4.
vamiyrapN fem. of vamiyrN.
Also a subst.: see vamiyrN, in three places.
vaAmirN: see 4.
vaAmiru AlHilomi ‡ Perfect, or complete, in respect of forbearance, or clemency; like ripe fruit. (IAạr, M.)
Alv-aAmiru The flower of the Hum-aAD [or rose-coloured sorrel]; (AḤn, M, Ḳ;) which is red. (TA.)
The luwbiyaMC [dolichos lubia of Forskål]. (AḤn, M, Ḳ.)
viymaArN, or vayomaArN: see vamarN, in three places.
EaqolN muvomirN † [Fruitful intellect;] the intellect of the Muslim: opposed to EaqolN EaqiymN [barren intellect;] the intel-lect of the unbeliever. (M, TA.)
muvam-irN: see vamiyrN.
mavomuwrN: see vamirN.
qawomN mavomuwruwna ‡ A people, or company of men, abounding in wealth. (Ḳ,* TA.)

hom.sense: 1. vamala, [aor., app., _i and _u,] inf. n. vamolN, It (water) remained in a watering-trough or tank. (Mṣb.)

Also, (T, TA,) aor. _i {yavomilu} and _u {yavomulu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. vamolN (T, M, Ḳ) and vumuwlN, (M, Ḳ,) He (a man, T) remained, stayed, resided, dwelt, or tarried. (T, M, Ḳ.) You say, vamala fulaAnN famaA yaboraHu Such a one remained,, &c., and does not quit his place. (T.) And ArotaHala banuw fulaAnK wavamala fulaAnN fiI daArihimo, i. e., [The sons of such a one removed, or departed, and such a one] remained [in their abode]. (T, TA.)
vamalahu He steeped it, or macerated it, and left it, or kept it, long; namely, poison. (Skr p. 194.) [See vumaAlN.]

vamalati AlS-iboyaAna, aor. _i {yavomilu}, [inf. n., app., vamolN,] She (a woman) was a support to the children, remaining, or abiding, with them. (M.) And vamalahumo, (T, M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yavomulu} (T, Ḳ) and _i {yavomilu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tamolN, (M,) He aided them, or succoured them, (T, Ḳ,) namely, his party, kinsfolk, or tribe, (Ḳ,) and undertook, or managed, their affairs: (Ibn-Buzurj, T, Ḳ:) he fed them, and gave them drink, (M, Ḳ,) namely, orphans, (M,) and undertook, or managed, their affairs. (M, Ḳ.)
maA vamala XaraAbahu biXaIoCK (Yoo, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) mino TaEaAmK (Yoo, Ṣ) He ate no food before drinking. (Yoo, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
You say also, Oakalati AlmaAXiyapu mina AlkalaOi maA yavomulu maA fiI OajowaAfihaA mina AlmaMCi The cattle ate of the herbage what was equal to the water that they had drunk. (T.)
And vamala, aor. _i {yavomilu}, He ate (Ḳ) food. (TḲ.)
vamila, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yavomalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. vamalN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,*) He (a man, Ṣ) became intoxicated. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
2. vm-l as an intrans. v.: see 4.

vm-lhu, inf. n. tavomiylN, He made it, or caused it, to remain; he left it; or reserved it; (Ṣ, Ḳ; [in the former of which, for the explanation bq-Ahu, Golius found nq-Ah;]) as also Avmlhu↓. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, AuHoquni AlS-ariyHa waOavomili↓ Alv-umaAlapa, i. e., [Collect thou the clear milk in a skin, and] leave the vmAlp [or froth] in the milking-vessel. (T.)
vam-alotu AlHub-a I took forth the vumaAlap [or remaining water or the like] from the bottom of the jar; as also Oavomalotuhu↓. (TA.)
4. Avml It (a thing, Ṣ, or milk, TA) had much vumaAlap, i. e., froth; (Ṣ,* TA;) as also vm-l↓. (TA.)
Avmlt She (a camel) gave much froth in her milk. (TA in art. Hlb.)
See also 2, in three places.

entry.sense: 5. tvm-l He supped, or sipped, what was in a vessel. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
vamolN: see vamalN, in four places.
vumolN: see vumolapN.

hom.sense: vamalN Remanence, stay, residence, or tarriance; like vamolN↓: (T, M, Ḳ:) [the latter is an inf. n.: see 1:] and both signify also ease; repose; easiness of life, and ampleness of the circumstances thereof. (T.) You say daAru vamalK (T, M) and vamolK↓ (M) An abode of [fixed] residence, (T, M,) and of ease, or repose,, &c. (T.) And makaAnu vamolK↓ A place peopled, inhabited, well stocked with people and the like. (Th, AAF, M.) And daAru baniI fulaAnK vamalN and vamolN↓ The abode of the sons of such a one is an abode of [fixed] residence. (IDrd, TA.)
Shade, or shadow. (M, Ḳ.)
Intoxication: (Ḳ:) inf. n. of vamila. (Ṣ, M.)
See also vamalapN, in two places.

entry.sense: vamilN Intoxicated. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
OanaA vamilN UilaI mawoDiEi kacaA ‡ I have a love for such a place. (Ḳ,* TA.)
vamolapN, (T, M,) or vumolapN↓, (Ḳ,) Mud taken forth from the bottom of a well. (AZ, T, M, Ḳ.)
See also vumolapN, in two places.

vumolapN Grain, and meal of parched barley or wheat (sawiyq), and dates, of which half and less, (AZ, T, M, Ḳ,) or half and more, (M, Ḳ,) is [remaining] in the receptacle, or bag; (AZ, T, M, Ḳ;) as also vamolapN↓ (Ḳ) and vamiylapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) pl. (of the first, TA) vumalN and (of the last, TA) vamaAYilu. (Ḳ.)
And in like manner, A [heap such as is termed] Suborap of wheat. (TA.)

Also, and vamalapN↓, (AA, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and vamolapN↓, (Ḳ,) and vumaAlapN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and vamiylapN↓, (Ḳ,) A remainder, (AA, Ṣ,) or water remaining, (Mṣb,) or a little water remaining, (M, Ḳ,) in a wateringtrough, (Mṣb,) or in the bottom of a wateringtrough, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or of a skin, (M, Ḳ,) or of a vessel (AA, Ṣ, M) of any kind, (M,), &c.; (AA, Ṣ;) and the same, (TA,) or vamiylapN↓, of which vamiylN↓ is the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.], (Ṣ,) water, (Ṣ,) or a little water, (TA,) remaining in a rock, or in a valley: (Ṣ, TA:) or these two words signify water remaining in pools left by torrents, and in hollows that have been bug. (T.) [See an ex. of vumaAlapN↓ in a verse cited voce qaSara.]
bihi vumolapN and vumolN↓ † In him is somewhat [remaining] of intelligence, and prudence, (Ḳ, TA,) and judgment, to which regard, or recourse, may be had. (TA.)
See also vamolapN.
And see vamalapN.
vamalapN: see vumolapN.
Also, (IF, TA,) or vamalN↓, (M,) Some tar remaining in a vessel. (IF, M, TA.)

And (hence, IF, TA) the former, A piece of rag, (IF, M,) dipped in tar, (M,) or a tuft of wool, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with which a camel is tarred, (IF, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [to cure him of, or preserve him from, the mange, or scab,] and with which a skin for water or milk is anointed; (M, Ḳ;) as also vumolapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and mivomalapN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And (hence, as being likened thereto, TA) The rag of the menses: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] vamalN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

vumaAlN Steeped, or macerated, poison; as also muvam-alN↓: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ: [in the CK, AlmunotaqiEu is put for AlmunoqaEu:]) or ↓the latter signifies poison that has been long steeped, and has remained: (Ṣ,* M:) or that has been steeped in a vessel, and remained steeped for some days, until it has fermented: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z:) or poison with which has been mixed something that strengthens it and excites its energy, that it may be more penetrating, or more effective: (Ḥam p. 215:) and simply poison. (T.) [The poison of a serpent or other thing. (Golius, from Meyd.)]
[Hence,] ran-aHahu muvam-alu↓ AlkaraI ‡ [The infection of drowsiness made him to incline from side to side]. (TA.)
See also vamaAlapN.

vimaAlN An aider, or a succourer, who undertakes, or manages, the affairs, of his party, kinsfolk, or tribe: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) their stay, or support: (M:) the aider, or succourer, of orphans: (Lḥ, M:) a refuge, or protector. (Mgh. [See also mavomilN.]) Hence, (Mgh,)
vimaAlu AlyataAmaI EiSomapN liloOaraAmili
[The aider,, &c., or the stay, or support, or the refuge, of the orphans; a defence to the widows]; (Mgh, TA;) said by Aboo-Tálib, in praising Moḥammad. (TA.) [See also another ex. in a verse cited voce Oano.]
vamiylN: see vumolapN.
vumaAlapN: see vumolapN, in two places:
and see vamiylapN.

Also, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and vumaAlN↓, (M, Mgh,) accord. to Th, (M,) or the latter is pl. of the former, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or rather coll. gen. n.,] Froth, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of any kind: (M:) or froth of milk (Th, M) when it is drawn. (M.)
vamiylapN: see vumolapN, in three places.

Also Remains of food, (M, Ḳ,) or of herbage, or fodder, (Ṣ,) or of fresh pasture and of fodder, (T,) and of drink, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the belly, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or in the intestines and other parts, (T,) of a camel, or other animal; (Ṣ;) as also vumaAlapN↓: (Ḳ:) and food that has been eaten before drinking: (T, Ṣ:) and any remains, or anything remaining: (Ṣ:) pl. vamaAYilu. (TA.)
Also The part (Lḥ, M, Ḳ) of the belly (Ḳ) of a man (Lḥ, M) in which are the food and drink: (Lḥ, M, Ḳ:) and the part in which is the drink in the belly of the ass. (Lḥ, M.)
mavomilN, (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) like manozilN, (Ḳ, TA, but in one copy of the Ṣ mavomal, and in another muvomal, and in the CK like minobar,) A refuge; an asylum. (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ. [See also vimaAlN.])
mivomalapN: see vamalapN.
muvam-alN: see vumaAlN, in three places.
muvam-ilN: see muvomilN.

hom.sense: 1. vamanahumo, aor. _u {yavomunu}, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, &c.,) inf. n. vamonN, (M,) He took the eighth of their goods, or property. (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

And, aor. _i {yavominu}, He was, or became, the eighth of them: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he made them, with himself, eight. (Ṣ in art. vlv.) And He made them, they being seventy-nine, to be eighty. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ in art. vlv.)
vamuna, [aor. _u {yavomunu},] inf. n. vamaAnapN, It (a commodity) was, or became, precious, costly, of high price; and Avmn↓ [signifies the same; or] it had a price, or value. (TA. [See vamiynN.])
2. vm-nhu He made it eight: or called it eight. (Esh-Sheybánee, and Ḳ in art. wHd.)
[He made it octangular.]
vm-n liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained eight nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA in art. sbE.)
Also, (T, TA,) inf. n. tavomiynN, (TA,) He collected it together. (T, TA.)

Also, inf. n. as above, (Mṣb, TA,) He made known, or notified, [or he set or assigned it,] its price; i. e., the price of a commodity; like qaw-amahu: (TA:) or he assigned it a price by conjecture: (Mṣb:) and Avmnhu↓ he named a price for it. (TA.)
4. Avmn Alqawomu The party of men became eight: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and also the party of men became eighty. (M and L in art. vlv.)
Oavomanato She brought forth her eighth offspring. (TA in art. bkr.)
Avmn said of a man, He was, or became, one whose camels came to water vimonFA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., on the eighth night [after the next preceding watering]. (Ḳ.)
Avmn said of a commodity: see 1.
Avmnhu He sold it for a price. (Mṣb.)
See also 2.

Avmn Alr-ajula mataAEahu, (T, Ṣ,) or siloEatahu, (Ḳ,) and Avmn lahu, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) [i. e. Avmn lh mtAEh, or slEth,] signify the same, (T, Ṣ,*) He gave the man the price of his commodity: (Ḳ:) or Avmn Alr-ajula bimataAEihi, and Avmn lahu mataAEahu, he named to the man a price for his commodity, and assigned it to it, or to him. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: vumonN: see vumunN.

hom.sense: vimonN The eighth young one or offspring. (A in art. vlv.)

One of the periods between two drinkings, or waterings, of camels: (Ṣ:) [or the end of one of those periods; namely, the night of coming to water which is] the eighth night of a period between two drinkings, or waterings, of camels, (Ḳ,) [counting the night of the next preceding drinking, or watering, as the first: see riboEN and ximosN, &c.] See also 4.

entry.sense: vamanN The price of a thing; i. e. the thing that the seller receives in return for the thing sold, whether money or a commodity; (Er-Rághib, TA;) the vaman of a thing sold: (Ṣ:) and also (Er-Rághib, TA) a compensation, or substitute, (Mgh, Mṣb, Er-Rághib, TA,) whatever it be, for a thing, (Er-Rághib, TA,) i. e., for a thing that is sold; but in the sense commonly known, such as it is incumbent upon one to pay, of pieces of silver, and of gold [or other money]; not commodities and the like: (Mgh:) or the value, or worth, of a thing; (Ḳ;) its qiymap: (T:) or the estimated value, or worth, of a thing, by mutual consent, even though it be really excessive or deficient; whereas the qiymap is its real value or worth, its equivalent: (MF:) pl. OavomaAnN (T, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OavomunN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter used only as a pl. of pauc., (Mṣb,) and [so] OavominapN. (CK: not in the TA.) The saying in the Ḳur [ii. 38 and v. 48], walaA taXotaruwA biMyaAtiI vamanFA qaliylFA is metaphorical, meaning ‡ And take ye not in exchange for my signs a small substitute: [i. e. purchase not in exchange for belief in my word the happiness, or enjoyments, of the present life.] (Mgh.)
