With respect to this saying, Fr remarks, when vamanFA occurs in the Ḳur, with bi prefixed to the name of the thing sold or bought, in most cases it relates to two things whereof neither is a vmn in the sense commonly known, i. e., such as pieces of gold and of silver: and such is the case when you say, AiXotarayotu vawobFA bikisaMCK [I purchased a garment with a ksAC, q. v.]: either of these may be termed a vmn for the other: but in speaking of pieces of silver and of gold, you prefix the b to the vmn [only]; as is done in [the chapter of] Yoosuf, [i. e. ch. xii., v. 20, where it is said,] waXarawohu bivamanK baxosK daraAhima maEoduwdapK [And they sold him for a deficient, or an insufficient, price: for pieces of silver not many, so as to require their being weighed, but few, and therefore counted]: for pieces of silver are always a vmn: and when you purchase pieces of silver and of gold with the like, you prefix the b to whichever of the two you will, because each of them in this case is a purchase and a price. (T.)
vamaAnK and vamaAnN: see vamaAniyapN.

hom.sense: vamiynN: see vumunN.

Also High-priced; or of high value; (Ṣ, TA;) and muvominN↓ [signifies the same; or] having a price, or value: (TA:) but accord. to the Durrat el-Ghowwáṣ, the assertion that the former has the meaning here assigned to it is a mistake; for it means [only] the same as vumunN; and a thing that has a price, or value, is termed mvmn [app. muvominN, as above; but perhaps muvomanN, q. v.]. (Ḥar p. 42.)

entry.sense: vamaAniyapN a noun of number, well known; [meaning Eight;] as also vamaAnK↓, (M, TA,) which is like yamaAnK, (M, Ḳ,) in form: (M:) the former is the masc. form: the latter, the fem.: (Mṣb:) this is not a rel. n. [though likened above to yamaAnK]: (M, Ḳ:) or it is originally a rel. n. from Alv-umunu, because it is the part, or portion, that makes seven to be eight, so that it is its eighth: they make the first letter to be pronounced with fet-ḥ, because they make changes [in some other cases] in the rel. n., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as when they say suholiI-N and duhoriI-N, [which are rel. ns. of saholN and dahorN,] (Ṣ,) and they suppress one of the two I which are characteristic of the rel. n., and compensate it by the insertion of A, as they do in the rel. n. of Alyamanu [when they say yamaAnK, originally yamaAniIN, for yamaniI-N]: (Ṣ, Ḳ: [and the like is said in the Mgh:]) El-Fárisee says that the A of vamaAnK is the characteristic of the rel. n., because this word is not a broken pl. like SaHaArK; and IF assents to this, and says that were it not so, the p would be inseparable, as it is in EabaAqiyapN, &c. (M.) You say vamaAniyapu rijaAlK [Eight men], (T, Ṣ, Mgh,) and vamaAniyapu Oay-aAmK [eight days]. (Mṣb.) And when vmAn is prefixed to another noun, its I is retained, like the I in AlqaADiI: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and it is decl. in the same manner as words of the class to which this last belongs: (Mṣb:) you say vamaAniI nisowapK [Eight women], (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and vamaAniI miAYapK [eight hundred], (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [in the nom. and gen. cases;] and raOayotu vamaAniIa nisowapK [I saw eight women], pronouncing the fet-ḥah [at the end, in this case]. (Mṣb.) When it is with tenween, the I is dropped in the nom. and gen. cases, but it is retained in the accus. case: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [i. e.,] when the fem. form is not prefixed to another noun, you say, EinodiI mina Aln-isaMCi vamaAnK [I have with me, of women, eight], and mararotu minohun-a bivamaAnK [I passed by, of them, eight], and raOayotu vamaAniyFA [I saw eight]. (Mṣb.) It sometimes occurs, in poetry, indecl.: (Ṣ, M:) this is because it is fancied to be a pl.; (Ṣ;) or because it is likened, as to the letter, but not as to the meaning, to jawaAriIa. (M.) The people of El-Ḥijáz pronounce the masc. and the fem. with nasb in every case, in phrases like OatawoniI valaAvatahumo and OatayonaniI valaAvahun-a; and so on to ten [inclusive]. (Ṣ voce valaAvapN, q. v.) Th mentions vamaAnN↓; (TA;) and some instances of its occurrence are cited; but Aṣ disallows it. (T, Mgh, TA.) kisaMCN cuw vamaAnK means A [garment of the kind called] ksAC made of eight fleeces. (T.) tuqobilu biOarobaEK watudobiru bivamaAnK [She advances with four and goes back with eight] is a saying of one of the muxan-avuwn of El-Medeeneh; meaning, with four creases (Eukan) of the belly, and with eight extremities thereof; each crease having two extremities, towards the two sides of the woman spoken of. (Mgh in art. hyt.) The saying Alv-awobu saboEN fiI vamaAnK should properly be fiI vamaAniyapK, (Ṣ,) which means, The garment, or piece of cloth, is seven cubits in length by eight spans in breadth; (Mṣb;) because the length is measured by the ciraAE, which is fem., and the breadth by the Xibor, which is masc.; but they use the fem. when they do not mention things; as when they say, SumonaA mina AlX-ahori xamosFA [We fasted, of the month, five], though meaning days: (Ṣ:) or because crAE is fem. in most instances, and Xbr is masc. (Mṣb.) [But it is said that when vmAnyp means the things numbered, not the amount of the number, it is imperfectly decl., being regarded as a proper name: thus] you say, tisoEapu Oakovaru mino vamaAniyapa [Nine things are more than eight things]. (TA voce tisoEapN, q. v.) [See also sit-apN.]

When you make it a compound [with the number ten], you say, EinodaI vamaAniyapa EaXara rajulFA [I have with me eighteen men]: and in the case of the fem., you may either make the I to be with fet-ḥ or make it quiescent, saying, EinodiI mina Aln-isaMCi vamaAniIa EaXorapa QmoraOapF or vamaAniIoEaXorapa [I have with me, of women, eighteen women]; but the former is the more chaste; and in one dial., the I is elided, on the condition of [saying vamaAna EaXorapa,] making the n to be with fet-ḥ; (Mṣb;) or in this case you say vamaAni EaXorapa, with kesr. (T.) A poet says, (T, Ṣ,) namely, El-Aạshà, (Ḳ,)
falaOaXoraban-a vamaAniyFA wavamaAniyFA
wavamaAni EaXorapa waQvonatayoni waOarobaEaA
[And I will assuredly drink eight cups of wine, ( a pl. of kaOos, which is fem., being understood,) and eight more, and eighteen, and two, and four]: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ: but in the Ṣ and Ḳ, walaqado Xaribotu; and in the Ḳ, and in one copy of the Ṣ, wavamaAna:) he should properly have said vamaAniIa EaXorapa or vamaAniIo EaXorapa, (accord. to different copies of the T and Ṣ and Ḳ,) but he elides the I after the dial. of him who says TiwaAlu AlOayodi [for AlOayodiI], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and he makes the n to be with kesr in order to indicate the I. (T.)

The dim. of vamaAniyapN may be formed either by suppressing the A, which is the preferable way, so that you say vumayoniyapN↓, or by suppressing the I, saying vumay-inapN↓, changing the A into I and incorporating into it the I that is the characteristic of the dim.; and you may compensate for both [of these suppressed letters by saying vumayoniy-apN↓ and vumay-iynapN↓]. (Ṣ.)
Alv-amaAniI is also the name of A certain plant. (Aṣ, T, Ḳ.)

vamaAnuwna a well-known noun of number; [meaning Eighty;] sometimes used as an epithet: El-Aạshà says,
laYino kunota fiI jub-K vamaAniyna qaAmapF
waruq-iyta OasobaAba Als-imaMCi bisul-ami
[Assuredly if thou wert in a well eighty fathoms deep, and wert made to ascend the tracts of heaven by a ladder]: he uses it thus as meaning deep. (TA. [But in this verse, as cited in the present art in the TA, OabowaAba is put in the place of AsbAb, which is the reading commonly known, and given in the Ṣ and TA in art. sb, and in the TA in art rqI-])
OaHomaqu mino SaAHabi DaOonK vamaAniyna [More stupid than an owner of eighty sheep], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or mino raAEiI DaOonK vamaAniyna [than a pastor of eighty sheep], as in some of the copies of the Ṣ, or, as in the Proverbs of Aboo-ʼObeyd, mino TaAlibi DaOonK vamaAniyna [than a demander of eighty sheep], (TA,) is a saying that originated from the fact that an Arab of the desert announced to Kisrà an event that rejoiced him, whereupon he said, “Ask of me what thou wilt;” and he asked of him eighty sheep. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[It also signifies Eightieth.]
vumayoniyapN and vumay-inapN and vumayoniy-apN and vumay-aynapN: see vamaAniyapN, last sentence but one.
vaAminN [Eighth: fem. with p {vaAminapN}]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
[vaAmina EaXara and vaAminapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Eighteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., explained in art. vlv, q. v.]
UibilN vawaAminu, [the latter word pl. of vaAminapN,] Camels that come to water on the eighth night [after the next preceding watering]: from vimonN. (TA.)
Oavomanu Of more [and of most] price or value. (Ṣ.)
muvomanN Sold for a price: (Mṣb:) or having a price named for it, and assigned to it. (Mgh.) [See also vamiynN.]
muvominN: see vamiynN
mivomanapN A mixolaAp [or nose-bag]: (IAạr, T:) or the like thereof. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: muvam-anN Octangular. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A verse composed of eight feet. (TA.)
Collected together. (T, TA.)
Poisoned; syn. masomuwmN. (Ḳ.)
Fevered; syn. maHomuwmN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. vn-n He (a horse) lifted his vun-ap [or fetlock] so that it did not touch the ground in his running, by reason of his briskness, or lightness: (M:) [or] his vun-ap touched the ground in consequence of his being ridden by a heavy person. (T.)
4. Avn- He (a weak old man) became wasted and worn out. (Ḳ.)
5. tvn-n He pastured, or fed, upon vin- [q. v.]. (T.)

vin-N Dry herbage: (Ṣ:) or dry herbage when it lies heaped together, one part upon another: (T:) or dry herbage, (Ḳ,) or what has become dried up of HaliI- and buhomaI and HamoD, (M,) when it is much in quantity, and lies heaped together, one part upon another: or what has become black of any branches, or twigs; not consisting of baqol nor of EuXob: (M, Ḳ:) or dry herbage broken in pieces: (IDrd, M:) or [simply] herbage, or pasture: (Th, M:) or herbage that is weak, and soft, or easily broken. (IJ.)

vun-apN, of a human being, (Lth, T,) The part below the navel, (Lth, T, M,) above, (Lth, T,) or extending to, (M,) the hair of the pubes, (Lth, T, M,) in the lower part of the belly; (Lth, T;) the part between the navel and the hair of the pubes: (Ṣ:) or the thin skin (murayoTaMC) between the navel and the hair of the pubes: (M, Ḳ:) or the hair of the pubes, (T, M, Ḳ,) itself. (M.)

And, of a horse (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and the like, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) The fetlock; i. e. the hairs on the hinder part of the pastern-joint, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) hanging down (Ṣ, M) over the part called Oum-u AlqirodaAn so as nearly to reach the ground: (Ṣ:) pl. vunanN. (Ṣ, M.)

kun-aA fiI vun-apK mina AlkalaAmi wagun-apK ‡ [app. meaning We were engaged in light and confused talk] is a metaphorical saying, borrowed from the vun-ap of the horse and the singing [or humming or buzzing of the flies and other insects] of the meadow or garden. (A, TA.)
vinaAnN Numerous, or abundant, and tangled, or luxuriant, plants or herbage. (T, Ḳ.)
vinotaAni fem. of AivonaAni, which see in art. vnI.
vunoduwapN and vanoduwapN and vunoduWapN and vanoduWapN: see art. vdO.

dictScrap.title: vanowaI / vunowaI / vanawiI-N / vanawiy-apN / AivonawiI-N / mavonawiI-N / mavonawiy-apN

entry.sense: vanowaI and vunowaI: vanawiI-N and vanawiy-apN: AivonawiI-N: mavonawiI-N: mavonawiy-apN: see art. vnI.

1. vanaAhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said in the Ḳ to be like saEaI, implying that the aor. is _a, but this is a mistake, (MF, TA,) [for it is well known that] the aor. is _i, (Mṣb,) inf. n. vanoIN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, &c.,) He doubled it, or folded it; (T;) he turned one part of it upon another; (M, Ḳ;) he bent it; (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) he drew, or contracted, one of its two extremities to [or towards] the other; or joined, or adjoined, one of them to the other; thus bending it; (Mgh;) namely, a stick, or branch, or twig, (Mgh,) or a thing, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of any kind. (T.) One says of a man with the mention of whom one begins, in relation to an honourable or a praiseworthy quality, or in relation to science or knowledge, bihi tuvonaI AlxanaASiru, (T,) meaning With [the mention of] him, (T, and Mṣb in art. xSr,) among others of his class, (Mṣb ib.,) the little fingers are bent. (T, and Mṣb ubi suprá. [For the Arabs, in counting with the fingers, first bend the tip of the little finger down to the palm of the hand; then, the tip of the next; and so on; bending the thumb down upon the other fingers for five; and then continue by extending the fingers, one after another, again commencing with the little finger.]) And a poet says,
faUino Eud-a majodN Oawo qadiymN limaEoXarK
faqawomiI bihimo tuvonaI hunaAka lOaSaAbiEu
[And if glory, or any old ground of pretension to honour, be reckoned as belonging to a body of men, it is my people, with the mention of them, in that case, the fingers are bent]; meaning that they are reckoned as the best; (IAạr, M;) for the best are not many. (M.) One says also, vanaI warikahu fanazala [lit. He bent his hip, and alighted], meaning he alighted from his beast. (T.) And vanaI rijolahu Eano daAb-atihi, meaning He drew up his leg to his thigh, and alighted. (M.) But qabola Oano yavoniIa rijolahu, occurring in a trad., means Before he turned his leg from the position in which it was in the pronouncing of the testimony of the faith. (IAth.) vanaI Sadorahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, [lit. He folded his breast, or bosom,] means † he concealed enmity in his breast, or bosom: or he folded up what was in it, in concealment. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xi. 5], OalaA Uin-ahumo yavonawna Suduwrahumo, meaning [Now surely] they infold and conceal [in their bosoms] enmity and hatred: (Fr, T:) or they bend their breasts, or bosoms, and fold up, and conceal, what is therein: (Zj, T:) I’Ab read, tavonawoniI↓ Suduwruhumo: you say, AivonawonaI Sadoruhu EalaI AlbagoDaMCi, meaning his breast, or bosom, infolded, or concealed, vehement hatred: (T:) or the phrase in the Ḳur, accord. to the former reading, means they bend, or turn, their breasts, or bosoms, from the truth; they turn themselves away therefrom: or they incline their breasts, or bosoms, to unbelief, and enmity to the Prophet: or they turn their backs: (Bḍ:) [for]

vanaAhu, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., (T, Mṣb, TA,) also signifies He turned him, or it, away or back. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.) Also He turned him, or turned him away or back, (Lth, T, Ṣ,) from the course that he desired to pursue, (Lth, T,) or from the object of his want: (Ṣ:) or you say, vanaAhu Eano wajohihi, (Mgh,) and Eano HaAjatihi, (TA,) and Eano muraAdihi, (Mṣb,) he turned him, or turned him away or back, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) from his course, (Mgh,) and from the object of his want, (TA,) and from the object of his desire. (Mṣb.) One says also, fulaAnN laA yuvonaI Eano qironihi walaA Eano wajohihi [Such a one will not be turned, or turned away or back, from his antagonist, nor from his course]. (T.)

Also He tied it; or tied it in a knot or knots; or tied it firmly, fast, or strongly. (TA.) You say, vanayotu AlbaEiyra bivinaAyayoni, meaning, accord. to Aṣ, as related by AʼObeyd, I bound both the fore legs of the camel with two bonds: but correctly, I bound the two fore legs of the camel with the two ends of a rope; the last word meaning a single rope: (T:) Eaqalotuhu bivanoyayoni means I bound one of his fore shanks to the arm with two ties, or tyings. (T, M.)
vanoIN [as inf. n. of vanaI] also signifies The act of drawing, or joining, or adjoining, one [thing] to another; (Lth, T, Mgh;) and so tavoniyapN↓ [inf. n. of vn-I]. (Mgh.)

[As valavahumo signifies “he took the third of their property,” and “he made them, with himself, three,” and other verbs of number are used in similar senses, so] vanaAhu signifies He took the half of their property: or he drew, or adjoined, to him what became with him two: (TA:)
or vanayotuhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) signifies I became (Ṣ, Mṣb) to him, (Ṣ,) or with him, (Mṣb,) a second; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or I was a second to him, or it: (Er-Rághib:) or one should not say thus, but that AZ says, (M,) huwa waAHidN faQvonihi (M, Ḳ [but in the latter, hecaA in the place of huwa, and in the CK, fOavonih↓,]) he is one, and be thou a second to him. (M, Ḳ.)
vanaI, aor. as above, also signifies He made eleven to be twelve. (T in art. vlv.)

vanaI AlOaroDa, inf. n. as above, He turned over the land, or ground, twice for sowing, or cultivating: (Mgh, and A * and TA * in art. vlv:) and tavoniyapN↓ [inf. n. of vn-I] and vunuyaAnN [app. another inf. n. of vanaI, and app. correctly written vunoyaAnN] are often used by [the Imám] Moḥammad in the sense of vanoIN: he who explains tavoniyapN as signifying the turning over [the land, or ground,] for sowing, or cultivating, after the harvest, or as signifying the restoring land to its owner turned over for sowing, or cultivating, commits an inadvertence. (Mgh.)

faQvoniniI, occurring in a poem of Kutheiyir 'Azzeh, is explained as meaning Then give thou to me a second time: (M, TA:) but this is strange: (TA:) [ISd says,] I have not seen it in any other instance. (M.)
laA yavoniI walaA yavolivu, (a phrase mentioned by IAạr, M,) or laA yuvan-iI↓ walaA yuval-ivu, or laA yuvoniI↓ walaA yuvolivu: see 1 in art. vlv.

hom.sense:
2. vn-Ahu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tavoniyapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made it two; or called it two. (Ṣ, M, MṢ b, Ḳ.) [Hence,] van-aI means also He counted two; whence the saying, fulaAnN yuvan-iI walaA yuval-ivu; see art. vlv: (A and TA in art. vlv:) [and so, app., Aiv-anaI↓; for] a poet says,
badaA biOabiI vum-a Qv-anaI biOabiI OabiI [which seems plainly to mean He began with my father; then counted two with the father of my father]. (M.)
[He dualized it, namely, a word; made it to have a dual.]
[He marked it with two points, namely, a t or a I.]
He repeated it; iterated it. (Mgh.) See 1, in three places.
vn-I liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained two nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sab-aEa.)
vn-I biAlOamori He did the thing immediately after another thing. (T.)

tavoniyapN also signifies A man's requesting others [who are playing with him at the game called Almayosir] to return, for [a chance of] the stakes, his arrow, when it has been successful, and he has been secure, and has won. (Lḥ, M.)
See also 4.
4. Oavonato, or Aivotanato↓, She brought forth her second offspring. (TA in art. bkr.)
See also 1, in two places.

AvnI, (inf. n. UivonaMCN, TA,) He shed his tooth called the vaniy-ap; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) he became what is termed vuniI-; said of a camel [&c.]: (M, Ḳ:) he shed his rawaADiE [pl. of raADiEap which is the same, in this case, as vaniy-ap]; said of a horse [&c.]. (IAạr, T.)

AvnI Ealayohi, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UivonaMCN; (T;) and vn-I↓, inf. n. tavoniyapN, accord. to the Ḳ, but this is a mistake for vb-I↓, inf. n. tavobiyapN; (TA;) He praised, eulogized, commended, or spoke well of, him: and he dispraised, censured, discommended, or spoke ill of, him: (T,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the object is either God or a man: (T:) or it has the former meaning only: (M, Ḳ;) or the former meaning is the more common: (Mṣb:) accord. to IAạr, AvnI signifies he spoke, or said, well, or good; and ill, or evil; and AnvI, “he defamed,” or “did so in the absence of the object;” and “he disdained, scorned, shunned, disliked, or hated,” a thing: (T:) and you say, AvnI Ealayohi xayorFA [He spoke, or said, well, or good, of him]; (Ṣ, and TA from a trad.;) and Xar-FA [ill, or evil], also. (TA from the same trad.) One says also, Oavonayotu fiEolahu [I praised his deed]; meaning EalaI fiEolihi; or because OavonaI means madaHa. (Ḥam p. 696.)

entry.sense: 5. tvn-I: see 7.

Also He affected an inclining of his body, or a bending, or he inclined his body, or bent, from side to side; syn. tamaAyala: (Ḥar pp. 269 and 271:) and he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; or with a twisting of the back, and with extended steps; syn. tabaxotara. (Idem p. 271.) You say, tvn-I fiI miXoyatihi (Ṣ, and Ḥar p. 269) He affected an inclining of his body, or a bending, or he inclined his body, or bent, from side to side, in his gait. (Ḥar ib.) [And in like manner, and more commonly, one says of a woman.]

7. AnvnI, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and tvn-I↓, and Aiv-anaI↓, of the measure AifotaEala, (M, Ḳ,) originally AivotanaI, (M,) and AivonawonaI↓, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure AifoEawoEala, (T, Ṣ,) It was, or became, doubled, or folded; (T;) it had one part turned upon another; (M, Ḳ;) it was, or became, bent. (T, Ṣ.)
[Hence,] AnvnI signifies also He turned, or turned away or back, (Ḥar pp. 44 and 120,) Eano OamorK from an affair, after having determined to do it. (Lth in TA art. zmE.)
8: see 7, and 4:
and see also 2.

10. AstvnAhu He set it aside as excluded; or he excluded it, or excepted it; mino XaIoCK from a thing; syn. HaAXaAhu: (M:) or he set it aside, or apart, for himself: and in the conventional language of the grammarians, [he excepted it; i. e.] he excluded it from the predicament in which another thing was included, or in which other things were included: (Mgh:) AlQisotivonaMCu [in grammar] is the turning away the agent from reaching the object of the AisotivonaMC: (Mṣb:) in the case of an oath [and the like], it means the saying Uino XaMCa Qll-ehu [If God will]. (Mgh.) [See vunoyaA.]

hom.sense: vinoIN A duplication, or doubling, of a thing: (T,* Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. OavonaMCN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or the sing. may be vanFI↓. (Mṣb.)

A folding: so in the saying, Oanofacotu kacaA vinoIa kitaAbiI, (Ṣ, TA,) or fiI vinoIi kitaAbiIi (so in a copy of the Ṣ,) i. e., fiI Tay-ihi [lit. I sent, or transmitted, such a thing within the folding of my writing, or letter; meaning infolded, or enclosed, in it; and included in it]. (Ṣ, TA.)

A duplicature, or fold, of a garment, or piece of cloth: (TA:) or what is turned back of the extremities thereof: (T:) pl. as above: whence, in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, kaAna yavoniyhi Ealayohi OavonaMCF mino saEatihi [He used to fold it upon him in folds by reason of its width]; meaning the garment. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] wakaAna celika fiI OavonaMCi kacaA, i. e., fI guDuwnihi [lit And that was in the folds, meaning, in the midst, of such a thing, or such an affair, or event]. (TA.) And jaAWuwA fiI OavonaMCi AlOamori They came in the midst of the affair, or event. (Mṣb.) [And hence, app.,] maDaI vinoIN mina All-ayol An hour, or a period, or a short portion, of the night passed; (M, Ḳ;*) syn. saAEapN, (Th, M, Ḳ,) or waqotN. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ.) [See also what is said below respecting its pl. in relation to a night.]

Also sing. of OavonaMCN meaning The parts of a thing that are laid together like the strands of a rope, or that are laid one upon another as layers or strata, or side by side as the things that compose a bundle; (quwaAhu, and TaAqaAtuhu; [rendered by Freytag “virtutes, facultates rei;”]) and mavaAnK↓, of which the sing. is mavonaApN↓ and mivonaApN↓, signifies the same. (M, Ḳ.)

Also A bending of the neck of a sheep, or goat, not in consequence of disease: (Ḳ: but in the M, vanoIN [inf. n. of 1]:) and a serpent's bending, or folding, of itself: (M, Ḳ:) and also (thus in the M, but in the Ḳ “or”) a curved part of a serpent that has folded itself; (M, Ḳ;) pl. OavonaMCN, (M,) i. e. the folds of a coiled serpent. (T.) The pl. is used metaphorically [as though meaning ‡ The turns] of a night. (M.) [But see explanations of the sing. as used in relation to a night in what precedes.]

A part that is bent, or folded, or doubled, of a wiXaAH [q. v.]; (TA;) pl. as above: (T, TA:) and so of a rope: (Ṣ:) or a portion of the extremity of a rope folded, or doubled, [so as to form a loop,] for binding therewith the pastern of the fore leg of a beast, to serve as a tether. (T.) Tarafeh says,
laEamoruka Uin-a Almawota maA OaxoTaOa AlfataI
lakaAlT-iwali AlmuroxaI wavinoyaAhu biAloyadi
[By thy life, death, while missing the strong young man, is like the tether that is slackened while the two folded extremities thereof are upon the fore leg, or in the hand: see TiwalN]: (T, Ṣ:) he means that the young man must inevitably die, though his term of life be protracted; like as the beast, though his tether be lengthened and slackened, cannot escape, being withheld by its two extremities: (so in a copy of the T:) or by vnyAh he means its extremity; using the dual form because it is folded, or doubled, upon the pastern, and tied with a double tie: (so in another copy of the T:) or he means, while its two extremities are in the hand of its owner: (EM p. 91:) by mA AxTO, he means fiI UixoTaAYihi, (Ṣ in art. Twl,) or mud-apa UixoTaAYihi: and the l [prefixed to the k of comparison] is for corroboration. (EM ubi suprá.) You say also, rab-aqa OavonaMCa AlHaboli, meaning He made loops in the middle of the rope to put upon the necks of the young lambs or kids. (T.)

Also A bend, or place of bending, of a valley, (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ,) and of a mountain: (Ṣ:) pl. as above: (M, Ḳ:)
and mavaAnK↓ [likewise] signifies the bends of a valley. (T, Ḳ.)

A she-camel that has brought forth twice, (Ṣ,) or two, (M,) or a second time: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, that has brought forth once: but the former is more analogical: (M:) one does not say vilovN [as meaning “that has brought forth thrice”], nor use any similar epithet above this: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. vunaMCN, like ZuWaArN pl. of ZiYorN, accord. to Sb, (M, TA,) and OavonaMCN accord. to others: (TA:) in like manner it is applied to a woman, (Ṣ, M,) metaphorically: (M:) and to the she-camel's second young one: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) accord. to Aṣ, as related by AʼObeyd, a she-camel that has brought forth once: also that has brought forth twice: [so says Az, but he adds,] but what I have heard from the Arabs is this; that they term a she-camel that has brought forth her first young one bikor; and her first young one, her bikor; and when she brought forth a second, she is termed vinoIN; and her young one, her vinoI: and this is what is correct. (T.) [Hence the saying,] maA hecaA AlOamoru minoka bikorFA walaA vinoyFA ‡ This thing, or affair, is not thy first nor thy second. (A and TA in art. bkr.)
See also vunoyaAnN.

entry.sense: vanFI: see vinoIN, first sentence.
vunFI: see vinFI:
and see also vunoyaAnN:
and AivonaAni.

vinFI The repetition of a thing; doing it one time after another: (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA:) or a thing, or an affair, done twice: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) and vunFI↓ signifies the same. (IB, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA vinaI fiI AlS-adaqapi There shall be no repetition in the taking of the poor-rate; (IAth, TA;) [i. e.] the poor-rate shall not be taken twice in one year: (Aṣ, Ks, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ:) or two she-camels shall not be taken in the place of one for the poor-rate: (M, IAth, Ḳ:*) or there shall be no retracting of an alms; or no revoking it: (Mgh, Ḳ,* TA:) this last is the meaning accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, (Mgh, TA,) i. e. Ed-Dareeree, (Mgh,) who, in explaining this trad., as relating to the giving an alms to a man and then desiring to take it back, says he does not deny that vinFI has the meaning first assigned to it above in this paragraph. (TA.)
See also vunoyAnN:
and AivonaAni.
vanowaI and vunowaI: see vunoyaA, in four places.
vunoyapN: see vunoyaA, in three places.
vinoyapN The lowest, most ignoble, or meanest, of the people of his house; applied to a man. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also pl. of vunoyaAnN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

vunoyaA a subst. from AisotivonaMCN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also vanowaI↓; the former with damm, and the latter with fet-ḥ: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) both are syn. with AisotivonaMCN [used as a subst., meaning An exception]; (T;) as also vaniy-apN↓, (T, Ḳ,) or vunoyapN↓, (accord. to one copy of the T,) and mavonawiy-apN↓: (T:) so in the saying, Halafa yamiynFA layosa fiyhaA vunoyaA and vunowaI↓ and vaniy-apN↓ or vunoyapN↓ and mavonawiy-apN↓ [he swore an oath in which there was not an exception]; for when the swearer says, “By God I will not do such and such things unless God will otherwise,” he reverses what he [first] says by God's willing otherwise: (T: [see 10:]) [and so in the saying,] HalofapN gayoru caAti mavonawiy-apK↓ a swearing not made lawful [by an exception]: (M:) [so too in the saying,] bayoEN maA fiyhi mavonawiy-apN↓ [and vunoyaA, &c.] (Ḳ in art. lHj) a sale in which there is not an exception: (TA in that art.:) or vunoyaA signifies a thing excepted, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) whatever it be; (Ḳ) as also vanowaI↓, (M, Ḳ,) with w substituted for I, (M,) or vunowaI↓, (so in the TA, [but probably through inadvertence,]) and vaniy-apN↓, (M, Ḳ,) or vunoyapN↓. (TA.) In a sale, it is unlawful when it is the exception of a thing unknown; and when one sells a slaughtered camel for a certain price and excepts the head and extremities: (T, TA:) or when an exception is made from things sold without measuring or weighting or numbering: and in a contract with another for labour upon land on the condition of sharing the produce, it is when one excepts a certain measure after the half or the third. (IAth, TA.) The saying of Moḥammad, mani QsotavonaI falahu vunoyaAhu means Whoso maketh an exception, his shall be what he excepteth: (M, TA:*) as, for instance, when one says, “I divorce her thrice, save once:” or “I emancipate them, except such a one.” (TA.)

It also means particularly The head and legs of a slaughtered camel; (T, M,* Ḳ;) because the seller of the camel used, in the Time of Ignorance, to except them; (T;) and IF adds, but incorrectly, the back-bone: (Ṣgh, TA:) whence, applied to a she-camel, mucak-arapu Alv-unoyaA, (T, M,) meaning Resembling the make of the male in [the largeness of] her head and legs; (Th, M;) or jumaAliy-apu Alv-unoyaA, having thick legs, like those of the male camel in thickness. (T.) [Also, app., The exception, or omission, of a day, in irrigation: see 3 in art. vlv, and vilovN in the same art.] And vaniy-apN↓ signifies also A palm-tree that is excepted from a bargain. (M, Ḳ.) And The martyrs whom God has excepted from those who shall fall down dead or swooning: (M, Ḳ:) these, accord. to Kaab, are vaniy-pu↓ Qll-ehi fiI AlOaroDi [those whom God has excepted on the earth]; (T, M;) alluded to in the Ḳur [xxxix. 68], where it is said, “And the horn shall be blown, and those who are in the heavens and those on the earth shall fall down dead, or swooning, except those whom God shall please [to except].” (T.)

hom.sense: vunoyaAnN The second chief; the person who comes second as a chief; (AʼObeyd, T;) the person who is [next] below the say-id, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, [in some copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, syl,]) in rank; (Ṣ;) as also vinFI↓ (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and vunFI↓ (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and vinoIN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. (of the first, Ṣ) vinoyapN [which is also a sing., mentioned above]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce badoCN.]
A man having no judgment nor intelligence, or understanding. (M, Ḳ.)
Applied to judgment, or an opinion, (M, Ḳ,) ‡ Wrong, or having a wrong tendency; (M;) bad, corrupt, unsound, or wrong. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also a pl. of vaniI-N [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, &c.)

entry.sense: vanawiI-N rel. n. of AivonaAni, and of AivonaA EaXara, when either or these is used as the proper name of a man; as also AivoniI-N↓ [with Q when connected with a preceding word]; like binawiI-N and AiboniI-N as rel. ns. of AibonN. (Ṣ.)
And Alv-anawiy-apu [The Dualists;] the sect who assert the doctrine of Dualism [AlQivonayoniy-ap]. (TA.)

vanaMCN, [and accord. to the CK, vaniy-apN, but this is a mistranscription for tavoniyap, inf. n. of van-aI, and tavoniyap is a mistake for tavobiyap, inf. n. of vab-aI, (see 4,)] Praise, eulogy, or commendation, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a man, (T, M,) and of God: (T:) and dispraise, censure, or discommendation, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a man: (T, M:) or the former only: (M, Ḳ:) or more frequently the former: (Mṣb:) so termed because it is repeated: (Ḥam p. 696:) that it relates to good speech and evil is asserted by many. (TA.)
vunaMCu and vunaMCa: see mavonaI.

hom.sense: vinaMCN The cord, or rope, with which a camel's fore shank and his arm are bound together; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and the like; consisting of a folded, or doubled, cord, or rope: each of the folds, or duplicatures, thereof would be thus termed if the word were used in the sing. form: (Ṣ:) Ibn-Es-Seed [in the CK, erroneously, Ibn-Es-Seedeh] allows it; and therefore it is given as on his authority in the Ḳ: (TA:) and Lth allows it; but in this instance he allows what the Arabs do not allow: (T:) you say, Eaqalotu AlbaEiyra bivinaAyayoni, meaning I bound together the fore shanks and the arms of the camel with a rope, (Ṣ,) or with two ropes, (M, [but this is probably a mistake of a copyist,]) or with the two ends of a rope; (AZ, T, Ṣ, M;) without C because the word has no sing.: (Kh, Sb, T, Ṣ:) Lth allows one's saying bivinaMCayoni also; but the Basrees and Koofees [in general] agree that it is without C: (T:) IB says that it has no sing. because it is a single rope, with one end of which one fore leg is bound, and with the other end the other leg; and IAth says the like: (TA:) this rope is also called vinaAyapN↓; but a single rope for binding one fore shank and arm is not thus called. (T.) See also vinaAyapN.
And see vaAnK.

The finaMC [or court, or open or wide space, in front, or extending from the sides,] (M, Ḳ,) of a house: (M:) [in the CK, AlginACu is erroneously put for AlfinACu:] accord. to IJ, from vanaI, aor. yavoniI, because there one is turned back, by its limits, from expatiating; but AʼObeyd holds the v to be a substitute for f. (M.)

entry.sense:
vaniI-N Shedding his tooth called the vaniy-ap [q. v.]: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) or that has shed the tooth so called: (T, Mgh:) applied to a camel, &c., as follows: (T, Ṣ, M, &c.:) or, as some say, to any animal that has shed that tooth, except man: (M:) fem. with p {vaniy-apN}: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a camel in the sixth year; (T, Ṣ, M, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the least age at which he may be sacrificed: (T:)
and a horse in the fourth year; (IAạr, T, Mgh, Ḳ;) or in the third year: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and a cloven-hoofed animal, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or a sheep or goat and an animal of the bovine kind, [respecting which last see EaDobN,] (T, IAth, Ḳ,) in the third year: (T, Ṣ, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a sheep and a goat, (M,) the latter accord. to the persuasion of Aḥmad [Ibn-Hambal], (TA,) in the second year: (M:) and a gazelle after the age at which he is termed jacaEN: (M: [see XaSarN:]) in all cases, after what is termed jacaEN and before what is termed rabaAEK: (Mgh:) pl. (masc., Ṣ, TA) vunoyaAnN and vinaMCN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb) and vunaMCN, and, accord. to Sb, vunK; (M;) and pl. fem. vaniy-aAtN. (Ṣ.)
Alv-unaI-u, or Alv-uniI-u: see AivonaAni.

hom.sense: vaniy-apN I. q. EaqabapN: (AA, M, Mgh, Ḳ:) or the latter means a long mountain that lies across the road, and which the road traverses; and the former, any such mountain that is traversed: (T:) so called because it lies before the road, and crosses it; or because it turns away him who traverses it: (Mgh:) or the road of what is termed Eaqabap: (Ṣ; and so in copies of the Ḳ:) or a high road of what is thus termed: (Ḳ accord. to the TA:) or a road in, or upon, a mountain, (M, Ḳ,) like that which is termed naqobN [q. v.]: (M:) or a road to a mountain: (M, Ḳ:) or a mountain (M, Ḳ) itself: (M:) or a part of a mountain that requires one, in traversing it, to ascend and descend; as though it turned the course of journeying: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. vanaAyaA: (T, Ṣ:) which signifies also [such roads as are termed] madaArij. (T.) Hence the phrase, fulaAnN Tal-aAEu Alv-anaAyaA Such a one rises to eminences, or to lofty things or circumstances, or to the means of attaining such things; like the phrase Tal-aAEu OanojudK [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) or, like the latter phrase, is accustomed to embark in, or undertake, or to surmount, or master, lofty and difficult things: (Mgh:) or is hardy, strong, or sturdy; one who embarks in, or undertakes, great affairs. (TA. [See an ex. under the heading of Aibonu jalaA, in art. jlw: and see also art. TlE.])

Also, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) pl. vanaAyaA (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) and vaniy-aAtN, (Mṣb,) One of certain teeth, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the foremost in the mouth, (M,) [namely, the central incisors,] four in number, (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb,) to man, and to the camel, (T, M, &c.,) and to the wild beast, (M,) in the fore part of the mouth, (T, Mgh, Ḳ,) two above and two below: (T, M, Mgh, Ḳ:) so called as being likened to the vaniy-ap of a mountain, in form and hardness; (TA;) or because each of them is placed next to its fellow. (Mgh.)
Also fem. of vaniI-N [q. v.]. (T, Ṣ, M, &c.)
See also vunoyaA, in five places.

entry.sense:
vinaAyapN A cord, or rope, of goats' hair (XaEar), or of wool, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of other material; (Ḳ;) as also vinaMCN↓ (Ḳ) and mivonaApN↓ and mavonaApN↓; (M, Ḳ;) which last is explained by IAạr as signifying [simply] a cord, or rope: (M:) [or] the first has the meaning assigned to it above, voce vinaMCN; syn. with vinaAyaAni: and signifies also a long rope; whence the saying of Zuheyr, describing the [she-camel termed] saAniyap,
tamoTuw Alr-iXaMCa watujoriI fiI vinaAyatihaA
mina AlmaHaAlapi qab-FA raAYidFA qaliqaA , (T,) meaning [She draws the well-rope, and causes to run,] with her vnAyp upon her, (ISk, T,) [a wabbling, unsteady, sheave (?) of the large pulley;] the vnAyp here being a rope of which the two ends are tied to the saddle (qatab) of the sAnyp; the [upper] end of the well-rope being tied to its mivonaAp↓ [which here means the folded middle part]: (T:) but Aboo-Saʼeed says that it [here] means a piece of wood by which are connected the two extremities of the cheeks, or side-pieces, (TrfA Almylyn, [the latter of which words I here render conjecturally, supposing it to be similar in meaning to AlqaEowi or AlqaEowayoni,]) above the mHAlp, and a similar piece below; the mHAlp and [qu. or] the sheave turning between the tow pieces thus called. (T, in a later portion of the art.)
vunaAYiI-N [a rel. n. from AivonaAni, anomalously formed, but analogous with other rel. ns. from ns. of number, as rubaAEiI-N vulaAviI-N, &c., Of, or relating to, two things].
kalimapN vunaAYiy-apN A word comprising, or composed of, two letters; as yadN, and dumo [or damN?]. (TA.)
vinotaAni a fem of AivonaAni, q. v.

vaAnK [act. part. n. of 1; Doubling, or folding;, &c.]. Hence, huwa vaAnK rijolahu While he was bending his leg before rising, or standing up. (TA from a trad.) [And jaMCa vaAniIa EiTofihi: see art. ETf.] One says of a horseman who has bent the neck of his beast on the occasion of his vehement running, jaMCa vaAniIa AlEinaAni [He came bending the bridlerein by pulling it with both hands a little apart]: (T:) or jaMCa vaAniyFA mino EinaAnihi [he came bending a part of his bridlerein]. (Ṣ.) And of the horse himself, one says, jaMCa saAbiqFA vaAniyFA, i. e. He came outstripping, with bent neck, by reason of briskness; because when he is fatigued, he stretches out his neck; and when he is not fatigued nor jaded by running, but comes in his first run, he bends his neck: and hence the saying of the poet,
wamano yafoxaro bimivoli OabiI wajad-iI
yajiYo qabola Als-awaAbiqi wahuwa vaAniI
i. e. [And he who glories in the like of my father and my grandfather, let him come before the mares that outstrip,] he being like the horse that outstrips [all others], with bent neck; or it may mean, he bending the neck of his horse which has outstripped the others. (T.) [Hence also,] XaApN vaAniyapN A sheep, or goat, bending the neck, not in consequence of disease. (M, Ḳ.)

[Also Second; the ordinal of two: fem. with p {vaAnapK}.] You say, hecaA vaAniI hecaA [This is the second of this]; i. e. this is what has made this a pair, or couple: (M:) and fulaAnN (T) or hecaA (Ṣ) vaAniI Qvonayoni, (T, Ṣ,) i. e. Such a one, or this, is [the second of two, or] one of the two; (T, Ṣ;) like as you say vaAlitu valaAvapK; and so on to EaXarap: but not with tenween: (Ṣ:) [i. e.,] you may not say vAnK Qvonayoni: (T: [see vaAlivN:]) but if the two [terms] disagree, you may use either mode; (Ṣ;) you may say, hecaA (Ṣ) or huwa (Mgh) vaAniI waAHidK and vaAnK waAHidFA, (Ṣ, Mgh,) i. e. This has become a second to one, (Ṣ,) [or rather, becomes, &c. (i. e. yavoniI rather than vanaI),] or he, or it, makes one, with himself, or itself, to be two. (Mgh.) vinaMC↓ also signifies the same in a trad. respecting the office of commander, or governor, or prince; where it is said, Oaw-aluhaA malaAmapN wavinaAWuhaA nadaAmapN wavilaAvuhaA EacAbu yawomi AlqiyaAmapi Uil-aA mano Eadala, i. e. [The first result thereof is blame, and] the second [is regret, and] the third [is the punishment of the day of resurrection, except in the case of him who acts equitably]: so says Sh. (T.)
And Alv-awaAniI [pl. of Alv-aAniyapu] signifies [The second horns;] the horns that are [next] after the OawaAYil. (M.)
[vaAniIa EaXara and vaAniyapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Twelfth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., explained in art. vlv.]
OavonaMCN pl. of vinoIN and of AivonaAni: and also syn. with this latter, q. v.
AivoniI-N: see vanawiI-N.

AivonaAni a noun of number; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) applied to the dual number; (Mṣb;) meaning [Two;] the double of waAHidN; (M, Ḳ;) with a conjunctive A [when not immediately preceded by a quiescence, written QvonaAni]; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb;) but this is sometimes made disjunctive when connected with a preceding word by poetic license: (T, Ṣ:) of the masc. gender: (Ṣ:) fem. AivonataAni, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) in which, also, the A is conjunctive; (T, Mṣb;) and vinotaAni↓; (T Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the latter sometimes used, (T,) [much less frequently than the former, though the only fem. form mentioned in the M and Ḳ,] and of the dial. of Temeem; (Mṣb;) like as one says, hiIa Qbonapu fulaAnK and hiIa binotuhu: (T:) the t in the dual is a substitute for the final radical, I, (M, TA,) as it is in OasonatuwA, the only other instance of this substitution except in words of the measure AifotaEala: (Sb, M, TA:) in AivonaAni, the final radical, I is suppressed: (Mṣb:) it has no sing.: (Lth, T:) if it were allowable to assign to it a sing., it would be AivonN [for the masc.] and AivonapN [for the fem.], like AibonN and AibonapN: (Ṣ:) accord. to some, (Mṣb,) it is originally vinoIN; (T, Mṣb, CK;) and hence the dual vinotaAni: (Mṣb:) or it is originally vanaIN, (M, Mṣb, and so in a copy of the Ḳ,) the conjunctive A being then substituted for the I whence the dual QvonaAni, like QbonaAni: (Mṣb:) this is shown by the form of its pl., which is OavonaMCN, (M, Ḳ,) like OabonaMCN [pl. of QbonN, which is originally banaIN or banawN,] and MxaMCN [pl. of OaxN, which is originally OaxawN]. (M.) In the saying in the Ḳur [xvi. 53], laA tat-axicuwA Uielhayoni Qvonayoni [Take not to yourselves two gods], the last word is added as a corroborative. (M.) The phrase vinotaA HanoZalK occurs, by poetic license, for AivonataAni mino HanoZalK, meaning HanoZalataAni [Two colocynths]. (Ṣ.)
You say also, Xaribotu OavonaMCa↓ AlqadaHi, and Xaribotu QvonaIo hecaA AlqadaHi, meaning [I drank] twice as much as the bowl, and as this bowl: and in like manner, Xaribotu QvonaIo mud-i AlbaSorapi and Qvonayoni bimud-i AlbaSorapi [I drank twice the quantity of the mud- of El-Basrah]. (M.) And a poet says,
famaA Hulibato Uil-aA Alv-alaAvapa waAlv-unaI↓
walaA quy-ilato Uil-aA qariybFA maqaAluhaA
meaning [And she was not milked save] three vessels and two, [nor was she given her middaydrink save when her midday-resting was near.] (IAạr, M.)

Hence, (Mṣb,) yawomu AlQivonayoni, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or AlQivonaAni alone, (M, Ḳ,) One of the days of the week; [the second; namely, Monday;] because the first, with the Arabs, is AlOaHadu; (M;) as also Alv-inaI↓, like UilaI; (Ḳ;) so in the copies of the Ḳ; [or,] accord. to some, Alv-uniI-u↓, [originally Alv-unuwIu,] of the measure fuEuwl, like vudiI-N [pl. of vadoIN], is used in this sense; (TA;) or Alyawomu Alv-unaI-u↓, [so in the M, accord. to the TT,] mentioned by Sb, on the authority of certain of the Arabs: (M:) the pl. is OavonaMCN and OavaAniynu, (M, Ḳ,) the latter mentioned on the authority of Th: but it has no dual: and those who say OavonaMCN form this pl. from AlQivonu, although this has not been in use: (M:) or it has neither dual nor pl., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) being itself a dual; (Ṣ;) but if you would form a pl. from it, you would regard it as itself a sing., and make its pl. OavaAniynu: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) IB says that OavaAniynu has not been heard [from the Arabs], and is only mentioned by Fr, on the ground of analogy; that it is far-fetched in respect of analogy; and that the pl. heard is OavonaMCN: Seer and others mention, as heard from the Arabs, Uin-ahu layaSuwmu AlOavonaMCa [Verily he fasts on the Mondays]. (TA.) Alvnyn in ywm Alvnyn has no dim. (Sb, Ṣ in art. Ams.) IJ says that the article Al in Alvnyn is not redundant, though the word is not an epithet: Abu-l-ʼAbbás says that the prefixing of the article in this case is allowable because the virtual meaning is Alyawomu Alv-aAniI [the second day]. (M.) The saying Alyawomu AlQivonaAni means The name of to-day [is AlAvnAn]; and is like the saying Alyawomu yawomaAni [to-day is two days] and Alyawomu xamosapa EaXara mina AlX-ahori [to-day is fifteen of the month]. (Sb, M.) Sometimes, yawomu Qvonayoni, without the article Al, occurs in poetry. (M, Ḳ.) When a pronoun refers to AlAvnAn [as meaning Monday], this word may be treated in two ways, [as a sing. and as a dual,] but the more chaste way is to treat it as a sing., as meaning the day: (Mṣb:) [thus,] Aboo-Ziyád used to say, maDaI AlQivonaAni bimaA fiyhi [Monday passed with what occurred in it]; making it sing. and masc.; and thus he did in the case of every day of the week, except that he made AljumoEap fem.: Abu-I-Jarráh used to say, maDaI AlQivonaAni bimaA fiyhimaA, treating the word as a numeral; and thus he treated the third and fourth and fifth days, saying in each of these cases bimaA fiyhin-a. (M.)

[AivonaA EaXara, fem. AivonataA EaXorapa; respectively, in a case of nasb and khafd, AivonaIo EaXara and AivonataIo EaXorapa; and with Q when not immediately preceded by a quiescence; mean Twelve: see EaXarapN.]
AivonawiI-N, [with Q when not immediately preceded by a quiescence, in the CK erroneously written AavonawiI-,] One who fasts alone on the second day of the week. (IAạr, Th, M, Ḳ.)
AlQivonayoniy-apu [The doctrine of dualism: see vanawiI-N]. (TA.)

mavonaI (Ṣ, Mgh) and vunaMCu↓ (T, Ṣ) [Two and two; two and two together; or two at a time and two at a time]: they are imperfectly decl., in like manner as [mavolavu and] vulaAvu, as explained in art. vlv; (Ṣ, TA;) [because] changed from the original form of AivonaAni QvonaAni; (T, Mgh, TA;) or because of their having the quality of epithets and deviating from the original form of AivonaAni; (Sb, Ṣ in art. vlv, q. v.;) or because they deviate from their original as to the letter and the meaning; the original word being changed as above stated, and the meaning being changed to AivonaAni QvonaAni. (Ṣ ibid.) You say, jaAWuwA mavonaI and vunaMCa↓ (M, Ḳ) or mavonaI mavonaI, (Ṣ,) but this is a repetition of the word only, not of the meaning, (Mgh,) and in like manner one says of women, (M, Ḳ,*) i. e. They came two [and] two. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) And it is said in a trad., SalaApu All-ayoli mavonaI mavonaI, i. e. The prayer of night is two rek'ahs [and] two rek'ahs (rakoEataAni rakoEataAni). (TA.) [See also other exs. voce vulaAvu.]

mavonaI AlOayaAdiI The repeating a benefit, or benefaction; or reiterating it; conferring it twice, or thrice; (Aṣ, T, Ḳ;) or twice, or more than twice: (Ḳ:) or the shares remaining of the slaughtered camel (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) in the game called Almayosir, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which shares a bountiful man used to purchase, and give for food to the OaboraAm, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) i. e., those who took no part in the game, not contributing: (M:) or the taking a portion time after time. (AA, T, Ṣ, M.)
mavaAnK [is pl. of mavonFI as signifying A place of doubling, or folding, &c.: and hence means]
The knees and elbows of a horse or similar beast. (T, Ḳ.)
And The bends of a valley. (T, Ḳ. See vinoIN.)

And, as pl. of mavonFI, The chords of the lute that are after the first: (M, Ḳ:) or mvnI signifies a chord [of a lute] composed of two twists: or, as some say, the second chord. (Ḥar p. 244: See mavolavN.)
mavonFI also signifies The zimaAm [or noserein] of a she-camel: and Er-Rághib says that the mvnAp [i. e. mavonaAp↓ or mivonaAp↓] is the doubled, or folded, part of the extremity of the zimaAm. (TA.)

AlmavaAniI as relating to the Ḳur-án is pl. of mavonFI, (Mgh,) or of mavonaApN↓: (AHeyth, T, Mgh:) it has three applications, accord. to AʼObeyd: (T, Mgh:) it signifies The Ḳur-án altogether; (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) so in the Ḳur xxxix 24; (AʼObeyd, T, Mgh;) meaning that the mention of reward and punishment is repeated, or reiterated, in it; (Fr, T;) or so called because the verse of mercy is conjoined with that of punishment; (Ṣ;) or because narratives and promises and threats are repeated in it; or because one peruses it repeatedly without being wearied: (Mgh:) or it signifies, (M, Ḳ,) or signifies also, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, Mgh,) [the first chapter, called] the faAtiHap, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh,) or AlHamodu, (Ḳ,) which means the same; (TA;) so in the Ḳur xv. 87; (AʼObeyd, T, Mgh;) because it is repeated, or recited twice, in every [act of prayer termed a] rakoEap, (Fr, Zj, AHeyth, T, Ṣ,) or with every chapter, (Th, M,) or in every prayer; (Mgh;) or because containing praise of God: (Zj, T, Mgh:) [but see Als-aboEu AlmavaAniI voce saboEapN:] or it signifies, (M, Ḳ,) or signifies also, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, Mgh,) the chapters that are less than those containing a hundred verses, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,) or that are less than the long ones (AlT-uwal, q. v.), and less than those containing a hundred verses, (AʼObeyd, T, Ḳ, but in [most of] the copies of the Ḳ duwna AlmiOatayoni is put in the place of duwna AlmiYiyna, which is the right reading, TA,) and more than [those of the portion called] the mufaS-al, (AʼObeyd, T, Mgh, Ḳ,) as is related on the authority of the Prophet by Ibn-Mesʼood and ʼOthmán and Ibn-ʼAbbás; (AHeyth, T;) because, (Mgh,) or as though, (T,) occupying the second place after those containing a hundred verses: (T, Mgh:) or the chapters, (T, Ḳ,) six and twenty in number, (T,) entitled AlHaj- and AlqaSaS and Aln-amol and Aln-uwr and AlOanofaAl and maroyam and AlEanokabuwt and Alr-uwm and yaAsiyn and AlfuroqaAn and AlHijor and Alr-aEod and sabaA and AlmalaAYikap and UiboraAhiym and SaAd and muHam-ad and luqomen and Alguraf and AlmuWomin and Alz-uxoruf and Als-ajodap and AlOaHoqaAf and AljaAviyap and Ald-uxaAn (T, Ḳ) and AlOaHozaAb, (Ḳ,) which last has been omitted by the copyists of the T: (TA:) or the chapters of which the first is the baqarap, and the last is baraMCap: or what is repeated, of the Ḳur-án, time after time. (M, Ḳ.)
mavonaApN; pl. mavaAnK: see vinoIN: and vinaAyapN: and mavonFI; the last in two places.

It is said in a trad. that one of the signs of the resurrection will be the public reading, or reciting, of the mavonaAp, (T, Ṣ,) which means That which has been desired to be transcribed from a source other than the Book of God: (T:) or a certain book, (T, Ḳ,) [the Mishna,] which the learned men, and the recluses, of the Children of Israel, after Moses, composed after their own desire, from a source other than the Book of God, as AʼObeyd says on the authority of a man learned in the books of the earlier times, (T,) containing the histories of the Children of Israel after Moses, in which they allowed and disallowed what they pleased: (Ḳ:) or what is sung: (Ḳ:) or what is called in Persian duw bayotiI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which means two verses, each composed of a pair of hemistichs; (TA;) i. e. what is sung; but AʼObeyd explains it otherwise than thus: (Ṣ:) it is what is known among the 'Ajam by the term mavonawiI-N↓, as though this were a rel. n. from mavonaApN: the vulgar say [erroneously] cuw bayot, with the pointed c. (TA.)
mivonaApN; pl. mavaAnK: see vinoIN: and vinaAyapN; the latter in two places: and see also mavonFI.
muvan-FI [pass. part. n. of 2.]
[Dualized: a dual.]

[muvan-aApN fawoqiy-apN Marked with two points above: an epithet added to tMC to prevent its being mistaken for bMC or vMC or yMC. And muvan-aApN taHotiy-apN Marked with two points below: an epithet added to yMC to prevent its being mistaken for bMC or tMC or vMC.]
AlT-awylu Almuvan-aI † That which passes away [out of sight, or disappears,] by length; mostly used of a thing that is long without breadth. (TA.)
mavoniI-N [pass. part. n. of 1; Doubled or folded, &c.]
OaroDN mavoniy-apN Land, or ground, turned over twice for sowing, or cultivating. (Mgh, and A and TA in art. vlv.)
mavonawiI-N: see mavonaApN.
mavonawiy-apN: see vunoyaA, in four places.

vuw-apN [mentioned in the M under the head of vw, as the radical letters, but in the T and Ḳ in art. vwI,] sing. of vuwFI, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) which latter, (IAạr, T,) or the former, (Ḳ,) signifies The goods, or utensils and furniture, of a house or tent: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) or the former, pieces of rag made in the form of a ball of thread or string, upon a peg, or stake, upon which the skin of milk is agitated to make butter, lest it should become lacerated; as also vuwiI-N↓; (M, Ḳ;) which latter we hold to be from vww because syn. with vuw-apN, like quw-apN: (ISd in the M:) or a piece of rag, which is moistened, and put upon the skin of milk when it is agitated to make butter, lest it should become lacerated: (T:) or it signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (M,) a piece of rag, (M, Ḳ,) or some wool wound upon the head of a peg, or stake, (IB, TA,) put beneath the skin of milk when it is agitated to make butter, in order to preserve it from being injured by the ground; (M, IB, Ḳ;) pl. vuwFI: (IB, TA:) or it signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (M,) an elevated and a rugged spot, upon which, sometimes, stones are set up in order that one may be directed thereby to the right way; (M, Ḳ;) like Suw-apN. (M. See also vaAyapN, in art. vwI.)
vuwiI-N: see above.

4. OavaOotuhu bisahomK, (Ṣ in art. vO, [incorrectly there mentioned, as is said by IB and others and in the Ḳ,] and Ḳ in the present art. and in art. AvO,) inf. n. UivaMCapN, (Ṣ,) I shot him, or shot at him, with an arrow; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) so says AA, and Ks says the like; (Ṣ;) as also Oavawotuhu, and, accord. to Aṣ, Oavayotuhu, (TA in art. vO,) which is a strange word. (TA in the present art.) It is mentioned in the present art. by Ṣgh; (Ḳ in art. AvO;) and this is its proper place; (TA in the present art.;) the verb, accord. to him, being like OaqaAma: (TA in art. AvO:) AʼObeyd has mentioned it in art. AvO, (Ḳ in that art.,) as also Az; holding the verb to be like SanaEa; and so IḲṭṭ and IḲooṭ assert it to be. (TA.)

hom.sense: vaMCN The name of the letter v, q. v.; as also vaA: pl. [of the former,] vaMCaAtN; and [of the latter,] OavowaMCN and OavoyaMCN. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np.)
It also stands for vanaMCN, and vawaAbN, and the like. (Idem ubi suprà.)
Also The best of anything; as, for instance, of wheat, and of flesh-meat, and of sugar. (Kh, TA ubi suprà.)

entry.sense: vaAYiI-N and vaAwiI-N rel. ns. of vaMCN and vaA, the names of the letter v; as also vayawiI-N. (TA ubi suprà.)

1. vaAba, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. yavuwbu, (Ṣ, Mgh, &c.,) inf. n. vawobN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vawabaAnN (Ṣ) and vuWuwbN, (M, Ḳ,) He, or it, (a thing, M,) returned; (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also vw-b↓, inf. n. tavowiybN: (M, Ḳ:) he returned to a place to which he had come before; or it returned, &c.: (T:) he (a man) returned, after he had gone away. (Ṣ.) You say, tafar-aquwA vum-a vaAbuwA i. e. [They became separated, or dispersed: then] they returned. (A.)
vAb UilaI Qll-ehi, like taAba, † He returned [from disobedience] to obedience to God; he repented; as also OanaAba. (T.)
vAb also signifies † He returned to a state of advertency, or vigilance; or he had his attention roused. (Th, T.)

Also † He returned to a state of health, or soundness: (TA, from a trad.:) he became convalescent, and fat, after leanness. (Mgh.) And vAb jisomuhu, (M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. vawabaAnN; (M, Ḳ;) and AvAb↓ jisomuhu; (IḲt, M;) and vAb Uilayohi jisomuhu; (T, M, A;) and AvAb↓, alone; (Ṣ, M, A;) ‡ He became fat, after leanness; (A;) his good state of body returned to him; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;*) his condition of body became good, after extenuation; and health, or soundness, thereof returned to him. (T.)
vAb Uilayohi Eaqoluhu ‡ [His reason, or intellect, returned to him]: and Hilomuhu [his forbearance, or clemency]. (A.)

vAb AlmaMCu † The water of a well returned, or collected again: (T:) the water attained again its former state after some had been drawn: (M:) the water collected [again] in a wateringtrough, or tank. (Ṣ.)

vAb Aln-aAsu † The people collected themselves together, and came. (Ṣ.) And vAb Alqawomu † The company of men came following one another: the verb is not used in this sense in speaking of one person. (M.)
vAb said of a man's property, ‡ It became abundant, and collected. (A.)
Said of dust, ‡ It rose, or spread, or diffused itself, and became abundant. (A.)
Said of a watering-trough, or tank, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. vawobN (AZ, T, M, Ḳ) and vawabaAnN (AZ, T) and vuWuwbN, (M, Ḳ,) ‡ It became full: (AZ, T, M, A, Ḳ:) or nearly full. (AZ, T, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2. vw-ib, inf. n. tavowiybN: see 1, first sentence.
vwab baEoda xaSaASapK ‡ [He returned to a state of richness, or competence, after poverty, or straitness, or being in an evil condition]. (A, TA.)

tavowiybN meaning The calling, or summoning, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) to prayer, (M, Ḳ,) and to other things, (M,) is said to be from vawobN “a garment,” (Mgh,) because a man, when he comes crying out for aid, makes a sign with his garment, (M, Mgh,) moving it about, raising his hand with it, in order that he to whom he calls may see it, (Mgh,) and this action is like a calling, or summoning, (M, Mgh,) and an announcing, to him; so the calling, or summoning, by reason to frequent usage of this word [as meaning the making a sign with a garment], came to be thus called; and one said of the caller, or summoner, vwab: (Mgh:) or it means the calling, or summoning, twice; (M, Ḳ;) or the repeating a call or summons; from vAb “he returned:” (Mgh:) you say, vw-b, inf. n. as above, (T, Mṣb,) meaning he called, or summoned, one time after another; (T;) he repeated his call, or cry: (Mṣb:) and hence tvwyb in the OacaAn; (T, Mṣb;) i. e., the saying of the muWac-in, after having, by the AcAn, called the people to prayer, AlS-alaAho raHimakumu Qll-ehu AlS-alaAho [Prayer: may God have mercy on you! Prayer!]; thus calling to it a second time: (T:) or his saying, (Ṣ, TA,) in the morning call to prayer, (Ṣ,) AlS-alaApu xayorN mina Aln-awomN [Prayer is better than sleep]; (Ṣ, TA;) for he resumes his call by saying this after he has said, HaI-a EalaI AlS-alaAho [and HaI-a EalaI AlfalaAHN]; desiring the people to hasten to prayer: (TA:) or his saying, in the morning call to prayer, AlSlAp xyrmn Alnwm twice, (T, Ḳ,) after having said, HaI- ElI AlSlAh HI- Ely AlflAH: (T:) or the old tvwyb was the saying of the muWac-in, in the morning call to prayer, AlSlAp xyr mn Alnwm: and the modern, AlS-alaAho AlS-alaAho; or qaAmato qaAmato. (Mgh.) It also signifies The UiqaAmap; (Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) [meaning, the chanting, by the mubal-iguwn, in a mosque, not by the muWac-in, the common words of the OacaAn, with the addition of qado qaAmati AlS-alaAho (The time of prayer has come), pronounced twice after HI- ElI AlflAH;] i. e. the AqAmp of prayer: (IAth, TA:) and this is what is meant by the phrase, in a trad., UicaA vuw-iba biAlS-alaApi [When the words of the AqAmp are chanted]. (IAth, Mgh, TA.) And The praying after the prayer divinely ordained. (Yoo, T, Ḳ.) You say, vw-b, meaning He performed a supererogatory prayer after the prescribed; tvwyb being only after the prescribed; being the praying after praying: (T:) and tvw-b↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ.) And v-wb birakoEatayoni He performed two rek'ahs as a supererogatory act. (A.) But this and the similar significations are said to be post-classical. (MF.)
See also 4, in four places.

vay-abato, (T, Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. tavoyiybN; (T, Mgh;) formed from vay-ibN, upon supposition [that the medial radical letter of this word is I, whereas many hold that letter to be w]; (Mgh;) or tavay-abato↓; (Ḳ in art. vyb; [the author of which seems to have supposed that, for vay-abato, one should read vuy-ibato; and therefore he gives muvay-abN as syn. with vay-ibN;]) She (a woman) became what is termed vay-ib. (T, Mgh, Ḳ.)
[Accord. to my copy of the Mgh, it also signifies She (a camel) became what is termed naAb: but I think that, in this instance, it is a mistranscription, for nay-abato.]
[See also the last sentence of the second paragraph {2} of art. vrb; and compare, with what is there said by SM, meanings assigned below to mavaAbN and mavaAbapN.]

entry.sense: 3. AlxuT-aAbu yuvaAwibuwnahaA The suitors return to her (namely, a woman such as is termed vay-ib,) time after time. (A, Mgh.)

hom.sense: 4. AvAb: see 1, in two places.
It may also mean † It (a valley, or a well,) had a return of water after a stoppage thereof. (Ḥam p. 598.)
AvAb Qll-ehu jisomahu ‡ God restored him to fatness, after leanness; (A;) restored his body to a good state, or condition. (TA.)

Uin-a Eamuwda Ald-iyni laA yuvaAbu biAln-isaMCa Uino maAla † Verily the column of the religion cannot be set upright again by women, if it incline: said by Umm-Selemeh to ʼÁïsheh, when the latter desired to go forth to El-Basrah. (T, L.)

AvAbhu Qll-ehu, (T, Ṣ,* M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UivaAbapN; (Mgh;) and Oavowabahu [dev. from rule]; (M, Ḳ;) and vw-bhu↓, (T, A,) inf. n. tvowiybN; (T, Mgh;) God recompensed, compensated, requited, or rewarded, him: (T, Ṣ,* M, A, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ:) said in relation to good and to evil. (T.) And AvAbhu, (Lḥ, M,) and Oavowabahu, (T,) mavuwbapF HasanapF, (Lḥ, T, M,) and mavowabapF, (Lḥ, M,) He (God) gave him a good recompense, compensation,, &c. (M.) And vw-bhu↓ mavuwbatahu He gave him his recompense,, &c. (M, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., OaviybuwA OaxaAkumo, i. e. Recompense ye your brother for his good deed. (TA.) And in the Ḳur [lxxxiii. last verse], halo vuw-iba↓ Alkuf-aAru maA kaAnuwA yafoEaluwna Have the unbelievers been recompensed for what they did? (T, Ṣ, M.) And one says also, AvAbhu mino hibatihi, meaning He gave him a substitute, something instead or in exchange, or a compensation, for his gift. (Mgh,* and TA in art. jnb.) And vw-bhu↓ mino kacaA, (M,) inf. n. tavowiybN, (Ḳ,) He gave him a substitute,, &c., for such a thing. (M, Ḳ.*)

AvAb Alv-awoba, inf. n. UivaAbapN, He sewed the garment, or piece of cloth, the second time: when one sews it the first time, [in a slight manner,] you say of him mal-ahu [and Xal-ahu, i. e. “he sewed it in the manner termed ‘ running ’”]. (T.)
AvAb AlHawoDa ‡ He filled the watering-trough, or tank: (Ḳ, TA:) or nearly filled it. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tvw-b: and tavay-abato: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph.
The former also signifies He gained, or earned, a vawaAb [or recompense,, &c.]. (Ḳ.) But this is said to be post-classical. (MF.)
6. tvAwb: see vuYiba, in art. vOb.

10. AstvAb maAlFA He restored to himself, or repossessed himself of, property; syn. AisotarojaEahu; (T, A, Ḳ;) his property having gone away. (T, A.) And Aisotavabotu bimaAlika I restored to myself, or repossessed myself of, property, by means of that which thou gavest me; my property having gone away. (A.) El-Kumeyt says,
Uin-a AlEaXiyrapa tasotaviybu bimaAlihi
fayugiyru wahowa muwaf-irN OamowaAlahaA
[Verily the tribe restore to themselves wealth by means of his property; and he makes incursions into hostile territories at his own expense, making their property abundant by the spoil that they gain with him]. (T, TA.)
AstvAbhu He asked him to recompense, compensate, requite, or reward, him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

vawobN A garment, (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or piece of cloth or stuff,] that is worn by men, composed of linen, cotton, wool, fur, xaz- [q. v.], (Mgh, Mṣb,) silk, or the like; (Mṣb;) but [properly] not what is cut out of several pieces, such as the shirt, and trousers, or drawers, &c.; (Mgh;) [though often applied to a shirt or shift (qamiyS or diroE) and to a jub-ap, &c.:] it seems to be so called because the wearer returns to it, or it to the wearer, time after time: (Mgh:) [also a garment worn by women and girls over the shift; (see OuSodapN;) app., as in the present day, a long gown, reaching to the feet, with very wide sleeves:] pl. viyaAbN [the pl. of mult.] (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OavowaAbN [a pl. of pauc.] (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OavowubN and OavoWubN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the last two being pls. of pauc., and the latter of them being thus pronounced with C by some of the Arabs because the ḍammeh immediately after w is deemed difficult of utterance; for which reason they substitute C for w in all instances like this. (Ṣ.)

Curtains, and the like, are not [properly] called viyaAb; but OamotiEapu Albayoti: (Mgh, Mṣb:) though Es-Sarakhsee uses the phrase viyaAbu Albayoti. (Mgh.) taEal-aqa biviyaAbi Qll-ehi ‡ [He clung to the curtains of the House of God], i. e., to the curtains of the Kaabeh, is a tropical expression. (A.)

Sometimes, vawobN is used metonymically to signify ‡ A thing [of any kind] that veils, covers, or protects: as in the saying of a poet,
kavawobi Qboni biyDK waqaAhumo bihi
fasad-a EalaI Als-aAlikiyna Als-abiylaA
[Like the means of protection adopted by Ibn-Beed: he protected them by it, and closed the way against the passengers]. (TA.) Ibn-Beed was a wealthy merchant of the tribe of 'Ád, who hamstrung his she-camel upon a mountain-road, and stopped the way [to his abode] with it. (Ḳ in art. byD.)
In the same manner, also, viyaAbN is used to signify ‡ Weapons. (Ḥam p. 63.)

And OavowaAbN is sometimes employed to signify † The wearers of garments; the wearers' bodies. (R, TA.) Esh-Shemmákh says, (T,) or Leylà, describing camels, (TA,)
wamawohaA biOavowaAbK xifaAfK falaA taraI
lahaA XabahFA Uil-aA Aln-aEaAma Almunaf-araA
i. e. They mounted them, namely, the travellingcamels, (T,) with their [light, or agile,] bodies: [and thou seest not anything like them, except ostriches scared away.] (T, TA.) And in like manner, also, the dual is employed to signify † The wearer's body, or self; or what the garments infold: and viyaAb is employed in the same manner. (TA.) You say, lil-hi vawobaAhu, i. e. ‡ To God be he [meaning his excellence] attributed! [for nothing but what is excellent is to be attributed to God:] (A:) or it means lil-hi dar-uhu [To God be attributed the good that hath proceeded from him! or his good deed!, &c.: see arts. Alh and dr]. (Ḳ.) And fiI vawobaIo OabiI Oano Oafiyahu meaning ‡ [On me and on my father it rests, or lies, or be it, that I pay it: or] fiIcim-atiI wacim-apiOabiI [on my responsibility and the responsibility of my father]. (Ḳ, TA.) And Ausolulo viyaAbaka mino viyaAbiI ‡ Withdraw, or separate, thyself from me. (A.)
[The following exs. are mostly, or all, tropical.]

Uin-i Almay-ita layuboEavu fiI viyaAbihi Al-atiI yamuwtu fiyhaA, (Ḳ,* TA,) a saying of Moḥammad, repeated by Aboo-Saʼeed El-Khudree, when, being about to die, he had called for new garments, and put them on: (TA:) it means Verily the dead will be raised in his garments in which he dies; accord. to some; and was used in this sense by Aboo-Saʼeed: (El-Khattábee, MF, TA:) or † [agreeably with] his works (Ḳ, TA) with which his life is closed: (TA:) or † in the state in which he dies, according as it is good or evil. (TA.)

waviyaAbaka faTah-iro, in the Ḳur [lxxiv. 4], means And purify thy garments: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, T:) or shorten thy garments; for the shortening them is a means of purity: (T:) or † put not on thy garments in a state of disobedience or unrighteousness: (I’Ab, T:) or † be not perfidious; for [figuratively speaking,] he who is so pollutes his garments: (Fr, T:) or, as some say, † purify thy heart: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, T, Ḳ:) or † purify thyself (IḲt, T, TA) from sins, or offences: (IḲt, TA:) or † rectify thine actions, or thy conduct. (TA.)

You say, fulaAno naqiI-u Alv-awobi, meaning ‡ Such a one is free from vice, or fault: (A:) and TaAhiru Alv-awobi ‡ [the same; or pure in heart, or conduct, or reputation]. (TA in art. nSH.) And danisu Alv-iyaAbi ‡ Vicious, or faulty: (A:) or perfidious: (Fr, T:) or foul, or evil, in reputation, (T, TA,) in conduct, or actions, and in the way that he follows [with respect to religion and morality]. (TA.)
kalaAbisi vawobaIo zuwrK: see mutaXab-iEN.
OaEoraDa vawobu Almalobasi and Almilobasi, &c.: see EaruDa.
vawobu AlmaMCi † [The membrane called] Als-alaI and Algirosu. (Ḳ. See these two words.)
viybN: see vaAYibN, in two places.

vubapN The place where the water collects in a valley or low ground; so called because the water returns to it: (Aboo-Kheyreh, T:) and the middle of a watering-trough or tank, (T, Ṣ, M,) to which the water returns when it has been emptied, (Ṣ,) or to which what remains of the water returns; (T;) as also mavaAbN↓: (Ṣ:) the p is a substitute for the w, the medial radical, which is suppressed; (Ṣ, L;) the word being from vaAba, aor. yavuwbu: (L:) Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ infers that this is the case from its having for its dim. vuwayobapN↓: but it may be from vab-ayotu “I collected together:” (M:) it is mentioned in the Ḳ in art. vbI or vbw, and not here. (TA.) See also art. vbw or vbI.

Also A company of men; (T, M, L;) and so Ouvobiy-apN: (M:) or a company of men in a state of separation or dispersion; (T;) a distinct body, or company, of people: (Yoo, T:) and a troop of horsemen: (M:) pl. vubaAtN and vubuwna (T, M) and vibuwna: (Ṣ and M in art. vbI, and M in art. vbw also:) accord. to some, from vaAba, being originally vuwbapN; and its dim. is vuwayobapN↓: accord. to others, it is originally vuboyapN; (T, L;) and its pl. is vubFI. (L.) Hence, in the Ḳur [iv. 73], faQnofiruwA vubaAtK, i. e. [And go ye forth to to war against the unbelievers] in troops, (Fr, T,) or in distinct bodies. (Yoo, T.) See, again, art. vbw or vbI.
vuwabaMCu: see vuWabaMCu, in art. vOb.

vawaAbN (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mavaAbapN↓ (T, Mṣb) and mavuwbapN↓ (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and mavowabapN↓, (EtTemeemee, T, M, Ḳ,) the last anomalous, (M,) and unknown to the Kilábees, who knew the second of these words, (T,) A recompense, compensation, requital, or reward, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of obedience [to God]: (Ṣ:) or absolutely; for good and for evil; as appears from the words of the Ḳur, halo vuw-iba Alkuf-aAru [cited above, see 4]; but more especially and frequently, for good. (IAth, L, MF, TA.)

vawaAbN is also used as a quasi-inf. n., in the sense of UivaAbapN; and in this case, accord to the Koofees and Baghdádees, it may govern as a verb, [like the inf. n.,] as in the saying,
liUan-a vawaAba Qll-hi kul-a muwaH-idK
jinaAnN mina Alfirodawosi fiyhaA yuxal-adu
[For God's rewarding every believer in his unity will be the giving gardens of Paradise, wherein he will be made to abide for ever]. (Expos. of the Shudhoor edh-Dhahab.)
It signifies also ‡ Honey; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. (TA) the good that proceeds from bees. (A, TA.)
And in like manner, ‡ [Rain; i. e.] the good that results from the winds. (A, TA. [See vaAYibN.])
And † Bees; (M, Ḳ;) because they return [to their hives]. (M.)

vay-ibN, [like say-idN; originally vawiybN, or vayowibN; i. e.] of the measure faEiylN, (Mgh,) or fayoEilN; (Mṣb;) A woman who has become separated from her husband (Lth, T, M, Mgh, Ḳ) in any manner: (Lth, T, M, Mgh:) or a woman whose husband has died, or who has been divorced, and has then returned to the marriage-state: (AHeyth, TA:) or one that is not a virgin: (IAth, TA:) or a woman to whom a man has gone in; and a man who has gone in to a woman: (Ks, ISk, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or a person who has married: (Mṣb:) applied to a man and to a woman; (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) like bikorN and Oay-imN: (Mgh, Mṣb:) from vaAba; (IAth, Mgh, Mṣb;) because they generally return time after time to the marriage-state: (Mgh:) but mostly applied to a woman; because she returns to her family in a manner different from the first [state]; (Mṣb;) or because the suitors return to her time after time: (Mgh:) or it is not applied to a man (Lth, El-ʼEyn, T, M, Mgh, Ḳ) except in the dual form, as when one says waladu Alv-ay-ibayoni: (Lth, El-ʼEyn, T, M, Ḳ:) and a woman is also termed muvay-ibN↓; (M;) or muvay-abN↓, like muEaZamN: (Ḳ: [but see 2, last sentence but two:]) the pl. of vayibN applied to a woman is vay-ibaAtN, (T, Mgh, Mṣb,) and the post-classical writers say vuy-abN, which has not been heard as genuine Arabic: (Mgh,* Mṣb:) its pl. if applied to a man is vuy-ibuwna. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., Alv-ay-ibaAni yurojamaAni waAlbikoraAni yujoladaAni wayugar-abaAni [The two persons of whom each has previously had carnal intercourse in marriage with one of the other sex shall be stoned if they commit adultery together; and the two who have previously had no connubial intercourse with others shall be flogged and banished if they commit fornication together]. (T.)
It is also applied to † A woman who has attained the age of puberty, though a a virgin; tropically, and by extension of its proper signification. (IAth, TA.)

This word is mentioned in the Ḳ [and M] in art. vyb; and its mention in art. vwb is said by the author of the Ḳ to be wrong: but IAth and many others decisively assert that it is from vaAba, aor. yavuwbu, “he returned.” (MF, TA.)
vuwayobapN: see vubapN, in two places.
viyAbapN and vuyuwbapN, as meaning The state of being a vay-ib, are not of the genuine language of the Arabs. (Mgh.)
viyaAbiI-N One who takes care of the clothes in the bath. (Ḳ.) [A post-classical word.]

hom.sense: vaw-aMbN i. q. taw-aAbN [One who repents, or returns from disobedience to obedience to God, much or often]. (T.)
A seller of garments, or pieces of cloth: (AZ, T, L, Ḳ:) and a possessor thereof. (Sb, Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: biYorN lahaA vaAYibN ‡ A well into which water returns after one has drawn from it; (A, TA;) see mavaAbN; and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense in the second of the following phrases,] biYirN lahaA viybN↓, and ciAtu viybK↓ waEiybK [in which wEyb is an epithet]: (T, L, TA:) or the first of these three phrases means a well of which the water stops sometimes, and then returns. (Ḥam p. 598.) You say of a well (bYr), maA OasoraEa vaAYibahaA † How quick is its returning supply of water! (T.)
vaAYibu AlbaHori † The water of the sea when it flows after ebbing. (Ḳ.) Hence, kalaON mivolu vaAYibi AlbaHori † Fresh, sappy, [green,] herbage. (T, L.)
qawomN lahumo vaAYibN ‡ A people, or number of men, who come company after company. (A, TA.)
vaAYibN also signifies ‡ A violent wind that blows at the beginning of rain. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
mavaAbN: see mavaAbapN, in four places:
and see vubipN.
Also † The place from which the water returns [to supply the place of that which has been drawn, in a well]: whence biYorN lahaA vaAYibN↓ [see vaAYibN]. (TA.)

And † The station of the water-drawer, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) above the EuruwX [which means the pieces of wood upon which he stands], (AʼObeyd, T,) or at the brink, where is the EaroX [sing. of EuruwX], (Ṣ,) or which forms part of the EuruwX, (M,) of a well: (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or the middle of a well: (Ḳ:) or it has this meaning also: (M:) pl. mavaAbaAtN. (T, M.) [See also mavaAbpN.]
And † The construction, or casing, of stones (TI-u AlHijaArapi) that succeed one another from top to bottom [round the interior of a well]. (IAạr.) [See again mavaAbapN.]

hom.sense: And, sometimes, The place where the hunter, or fowler, puts his snare. (Ṣ.)

mavaAbapN AlbiYori ‡ The place where the water of the well collects: (A, TA:) or the place reached by the water of the well when it returns and collects after one has drawn from it. (M, Ḳ.) [Hence,] jam-ato mavaAbapu jaholihi ‡ His ignorance became confirmed. (A, TA.) And kaAna yasotajim-u mavaAbapa safahihi ‡ [He used to wait for his lightwittedness, or silliness, to attain its full degree]: a metaphorical phrase, occurring in a trad. (Ḥar p. 68.)

Also † The stones that project, or overhang, around the well, (M, Ḳ,) upon which the man sometimes stands in order that the bucket (dalow or garob) may not strike against the side of the well: (M:) or the place where it is walled round within (mawoDiEu Tay-ihaA): (Ḳ:) or, accord. to IAạr, it means TaI-u AlbiYori; but [ISd says,] I know not whether he mean thereby mawoDiEu Tay-ihaA, or the building it [or walling it round within] with stones; though it is rarely that a word of the measure mafaEalapN [like mvAbp] is an inf. n. (M.) [See mavaAbN: and see what is said of tavowiybN in the last sentence of the second paragraph {2} of art. vrb.]
mavaAbaAtN [the pl.] also signifies † The foundations of a house. (IAạr, T.)
See also vawaAbN.

entry.sense: mavuwabapN: see vawaAbN.

hom.sense: mavowabapN: see mavaAbapN, in two places:
and see also vawaAbN.

entry.sense: muvay-ibN and muvay-ibN: see vay-ibN.
musotavaAbaAtu Alr-iyaAHi ‡ Winds that are attended by prosperity and blessing; from which one hopes for a good result [i. e. rain]. (A, TA.)

1. vaAxa and saAxa both signify He, or it, sank into the ground; and Yaạḳoob asserts that the v in the former is a substitute for the s in the latter. (L, TA.) You say, vaAxato qadamuhu biAlwaHoli, (Ṣ,) or fiI AlwaHoli, (L,) aor. tavuwxu and taviyxu, His foot sank, or entered, into the mire. (Ṣ, L.) And vaAxati AlUiSobaEu, aor. as above, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. vawoxN, (L,) The finger entered, or sank, into a swollen, or tumid, or a soft, or yielding, substance; (L, Ḳ;) as also saAxat, (L,) and taAxat: (Lth:) but this last is disapproved by IDrd, and J and others do not mention it. (TA in art. twx.)

1. vaAra, aor. yavuwru, (M,) inf. n. vaworN and vuWuwrN and vawaraAnN, (M, Ḳ,) It (a thing, M) became raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked; syn. haAja; (M;) syn. of the inf. n. hayajaAnN: (Ḳ:) as also tvw-r↓. (M, Ḳ.)

Said of dust, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and of smoke, (M, A,) and of other things, (M, TA,) inf. n. vaworN and vuWuwrN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vawaraAnN, (Ḳ,) ‡ It became raised, or stirred up; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and spread: (Mgh:) or rose, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and appeared; (M;) as also tvw-r↓: (Ḳ:) also said of the redness in the sky after sunset, inf. n. vaworN and vawaraAnN, ‡ it spread upon the horizon, and rose: (TA: [see vaworN:]) and vAr, said of anything, means † it appeared and spread. (Mgh.)
Said of a camel lying upon his breast, He became roused, or put in motion or action; as also tvw-r↓. (TA.)

Said of the bird called AlqaT-A, (M, A,) inf. ns. as first mentioned above, (Ḳ,) or vaworN and vawaraAnN, (M,) It rose (M, A, Ḳ) from the place where it lay; (M, A;) as also tvw-r↓: (Ḳ:) and of a swarm of locusts, it rose; (M, Ḳ;) as also tvw-r↓: (Ḳ:) or appeared; as also AnvAr↓. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, M,) inf. ns. as first mentioned above, (M, Ḳ,) He leaped, or sprang; (M, Ḳ;) as also tvw-r↓. (Ḳ.) You say, vAr Uilayohi He leaped, or sprang, to, or towards, him, or it. (M.) And vArbihi Aln-aAsu The people leaped, or sprang, upon him. (Ṣ.) And vAr UilaI AlX-ar-i He rose, or hastened, to do evil, or mischief. (Mṣb.)
vAr AlmaMCu The water flowed forth with force; gushed forth. (TA.)

vArt bihi AlHaSobapu, (Ṣ, M, A,) inf. n. vaworN and vuWuwrN and vawaArN [or vuwaArN?] and vawaraAnN, (M,) ‡ The measles spread [or broke out] in him: (M:) and in like manner one says of anything that appears: (M:) one says, vAr, inf. n. vaworN and vawaraAnN, meaning † it appeared. (T.) And accord. to Lḥ, one says, vAr Alr-ajulu, inf. n. vawaraAnN, meaning ‡ The man had the measles appearing in him. (M.)
vAr biAlmaHomuwmi Alv-aworu ‡ Pimples, or small pustules, breaking out in the mouth, appeared in the fevered man. (A.)
vArt AlHum-aI † [The fever rose, or became excited]. (TA from a trad.)
