vArt nafosuhu ‡ His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. jaXaOatN, (T, Ṣ,) i. e. AirotafaEato; (T;) or jaAXato, (TA,) i. e. faAratN. (T.)

vAr AlgaDabu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. vaworN, (M,) † [Anger became roused, or excited, or inflamed: or became roused, or excited in the utmost degree: or boiled: or spread: (see vaAYrN, below:) or] became sharp. (M, Mṣb.)
vArt bayonahumo fitonapN waXar-N (A, Mṣb *) ‡ Discord, or dissension, or the like, and evil, or mischief, became excited among them, or between them. (Mṣb.)
2: see 4, in three places.

You say also, vw-r AlOamora, inf. n. tavowiyrN, † He searched, or sought, for, or after, the thing, or affair; inquired, or sought information, respecting it; searched, or inquired, into it; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it. (M.) And vw-r AlquroMna † He searched after a knowledge of the Ḳur-án, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or its meanings: (M:) or he read it, and inquired of, or examined, diligently, those skilled in it, respecting its interpretation and meanings: (Sh:) or he scrutinized it, and meditated upon its meanings, and its interpretation, and the reading of it. (TA.)

3. vAwrhu, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. muvaAwarapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and viwaArN, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) He leaped, or sprang, upon him, or at him; he assaulted, or assailed, him; syn. waAvabahu, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and saAwarahu. (T, A.)

4. AvArhu, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and Oavarahu, and havarahu, (Ḳ,) [but in the M, I find Oavarotuhu and havarotuhu, (in the latter of which the h is substituted for the O of the former, as in haraAqa for OaraAqa,) and it is evident that the author of the Ḳ erroneously supposed them to be from Oavara and havara, whereas they are from OavaAra and havaAra, and are originally Oavowarutuhu and havowarotuhu, but, for Oavarahu, SM appears to have read Mvarahu, for he says that it is formed by transposition,] inf. n. UivaArapN and UivaArN; (Lḥ, M;) and vw-rhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) and AstvArhu↓; (T, M, A, Ḳ;) He raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked, him or it; (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) [as, for instance,] an object of the chase or the like, (T, M, A,) a beast of prey, (T,) a lion, (M, A,) † dust, (M, Mgh,) † smoke, and any other thing: (M:) or he drew it forth: (M:) AstvArhu↓ is [often used in this last sense, or as meaning he disinterred it, exhumed it, or dug it up or out,] said of a thing buried. (Ḳ in art. swE.) You say, AvAr fulaAnFA He roused such a one for an affair. (T.) And AvAr AlbaEiyra He roused the camel lying upon his breast, or put him in motion or action. (T.) And vw-r↓ Albaroka, and AstvArhA↓, He roused the camels lying upon their breasts, and made them to rise. (Ṣ.)
AvAr Alt-uraAba biqawaAYimihi He [a beast] scraped up the earth, or dust, with his legs. (T, M.)

AvAr AlOaroDa, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) and OavowarahaA, (M,) He tilled the ground, or land; cultivated it by ploughing and sowing: (Mgh, Mṣb:) he turned the ground over upon the grain after it had been once opened: (M, TA:) he ploughed and sowed the land, and educed its increase, and the increase of its seed. (TA.) And OavaArati AlOaroDa [She (a cow) tilled the ground]. (TA.)

AvAr Alfitonapa ‡ He (an enemy) excited discord, or dissension, or the like. (Mṣb.) And vw-r↓ Ealayohimu AlX-ar-a (inf. n. tavowiyrN, Mṣb) ‡ He excited evil, or mischief, against them, (T, Ṣ, A,* Mṣb,*) and manifested it. (Ṣ.)
5: see 1, in seven places.
7: see 1, in two places.
10: see 14, in three places.
vaArN: see vaOorN.

hom.sense: vaworN A bull: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and vaworapN↓ a cow: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc] OavowaArN (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and viyorapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and [of mult.] viyraAnN and viyarapN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and viwarapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and viyaArN (M, Ḳ) and viyaArapN; (M, TA:) Sb says of the pl. viyarapN that w in it is changed into I because of the kesreh before it, though this is not accordant to general rule: (Ṣ:) accord. to Mbr, they said viyarapN to distinguish it from the viwarap of OaqT, and that it was originally of the measure fiEolapN: (Ṣ, M:* *) accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee, it is a contraction of viyaArapN. (M.) [Hence,] Alv-aworu ‡ [The constellation Taurus;] one of the signs of the Zodiac. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
† A lord, master, or chief, (M, A, Ḳ,) of a people. (A.) ʼOthmán is called, in a trad., Alv-aworu AlOaboyaDu; the epithet AlAbyD being added because he was hoary; or it may denote celebrity. (M.)
† Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (T, Ḳ:) a stupid, dull man, of little understanding. (T.)

† Possessed by a devil, or insane, or mad; syn. majonuwnN; so in copies of the Ḳ; but in some copies, [and in the CK,] junuwn [diabolical possession, or insanity, or madness]. (TA; and thus in Ḥar p. 415.)

A piece, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or large piece, (M, Ḳ,) of OaqiT, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. milk which [has been churned and cooked and then left until it] has become congealed and hard like stone: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] viwarapN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OavowaArN. (M, Ḳ.)

The green substance that overspreads stale water; (T, M, Ḳ;) this is called vaworu AlmaMCi; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) syn. TuHolubN, (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and EaromaDN, and galofaqN; (M;) and the like thereof: (T, M:) and small rubbish, or broken particles of things, (Mṣb, TA,) or anything, (Ḳ,) upon the surface of water, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) which the pastor beats to make the water clear for the bulls or cows. (Mṣb.) Accord. to some, it has the first of these meanings in the following verse of Anas Ibn-Mudrik El-Khath'amee:
Uin-iI waqatoliI sulayokFA vum-a OaEoqiluhu
kaAlv-awori yuDorabu lam-aA EaAfati Albaqaru
[Verily I, with respect to my slaying Suleyk and then paying the price of his blood, am like the green substance upon the surface of stale water, that is beaten when the cows loathe the water]: but accord. to others, by Alvwr the poet means the bull; for the cows follow him: (M, TA:) the cows are not beaten, because they have milk; but the bull is beaten that they may be frightened and therefore drink. (Ṣ.) [See a slightly-different reading, and remarks thereon, in Ḥam p. 416: and see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 330. The latter hemistich is used as a prov., applied to him who is punished for the offence of another.]
† Pimples, or small pustules, breaking out in the mouth, in a person who is fevered. (A.)

‡ The redness shining, (naAYirapN, Ḳ,) or spreading and rising, (vaAYirapN, M,) in the faint light that is seen above the horizon between sunset and nightfall: (M, Ḳ:) or vaworu AlX-afaqi the spreading appearance of the redness above the horizon after sunset. (Ṣ, A, Mgh.) You say, saqaTa vaworu AlX-afaqi [The spreading appearance of the redness above the horizon after sunset sank down, or set]. (Ṣ, A.) With its suquwT commences the time of the prayer of nightfall. (TA.)
† The whiteness in the lower part of the nail (M, Ḳ) of a man. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: viyrN A covering of [or film over] the eye. (Ḳ.) One says, EalaI Eayonhi viyrN Upon his eye is a covering [or film]. (TḲ.)

hom.sense: vaworapN: see vaworN.
† An excitement: so in the saying, AinotaZiro Hat-aI tasokuna hecihi Alv-aworapu [Wait thou until this excitement become stilled]. (Ṣ.)
† Many; a great number; much; or a large quantity; of men; (T, M, Ḳ;) and of wealth, or of camels or the like; (T, Ḳ;) like varowapN: (T, M:) or not of wealth; for of this one says vrwp only. (M.)

entry.sense: vaw-aArapN The [part of the body called the] xaworaAn [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
dabFI vaAYirN [Locusts before they have wings] just coming forth from the dust, or earth. (T, Ṣ.)
vaAYiru Alr-aOosi ‡ Having the hair of his head spreading out in disorder, and standing up: (Aṣ, T,* Ṣ,* TA:) or shaggy, or dishevelled. (T, A.)
raOayotuhu vaAYirFAfariySu raqabatihi ‡ [I saw him with his external jugular veins, or with the sinews and veins of his neck, swelling by reason of anger]. (A.)
vaAYirN also signifies † Angry. (T.)

And ‡ Anger: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) [or an ebullition of anger, rage, or passion: whence the phrase,] vaAra vaAYiruhu, (T, Ṣ, M, A,) like faAra faAYiruhu, (T, A,) ‡ He was angry: (T:) or his anger became roused, or excited, (Ṣ, M,) or inflamed: (A:) or became roused, or excited, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or boiled: (Ṣ in art. fwr:) or spread. (TA in that art.)
OaroDN muvaArapN Land ploughed up. (T.)
OaroDN mavowarapN A land abounding with bulls [and cows]. (Th, M, Ḳ.)
muviyrapN A cow that tills the ground; (Mgh, Ḳ;) and in like manner applied to bulls (vyarapN). (T.)

hom.sense: 1. vaAla, (T, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) aor. yavuwlu, inf. n. vawolN, (T,) He (a man, T) was, or became, stupid, foolish, or disordered in his intellect: (Ḳ:) or he was, or became, affected with incipient madness or demoniacal possession, not such as had become confirmed. (T, Ṣgh, Ḳ.) You say to a man, when you order him to be stupid and ignorant, vulo vulo. (IAạr, Th, T.)

And vawila, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yavowalu, (T,) inf. n. vawalN, (T, M,) He (a man, and any animal,) was, or became, affected with confirmed madness or demoniacal possession: (T:) he (a sheep or goat) was, or became, affected with what is termed vawalN, explained below; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also, accord. to Sb, Avwl↓; (so in the TT, as from the M;) or Aivowal-a↓, inf. n. AivowilaAlN. (Ḳ.)
vAl AlwiEaMCa, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) aor. yavuwlu, inf. n. vawolN, (TA,) He poured forth what was in the receptacle. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
5. tvw-lt Aln-aHolu The bees collected themselves together, and became dense. (M, Ḳ.) See also 7.
tvw-l Ealayohi He, (a man, TA,) or they, (a company of men, Ṣ, M,) assailed him, or overcame him, with reviling (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and beating (Ṣ, M) and oppressive conduct; (M, Ḳ;) as also AnvAl↓. (M.)
7. AnvAl It poured forth: (Ḳ:) or it poured forth at once. (Mṣb.) AnvAl Ealayohi Alt-uraAbu The dust, or earth, poured forth upon him. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] AnvAl Ealayohi Aln-aAsu mino kul-i wajohK The people poured forth upon him, or against him, from every quarter: (Ṣ, TA:) or collected themselves together against him: (Mṣb:) [for] AnvAlwA also signifies they collected themselves together; and so tvw-lwA↓. (TA. [See also 7 in art. vl.])
See also 5.
AnvAl Ealayohi Alqawolu † Speech suggested itself to him uninterruptedly and abundantly, so that he knew not with what to begin. (M, Ḳ.)
9: see 1.

A number, or collection, or swarm, of bees: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or simply bees: (IAạr, Th, T:) a word having no proper sing.; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and of the fem. gender: (M:) or the male bee; (M, Ḳ;) thus Lth explains it; but the right explanation is the first, that of Aṣ. (T.)
And A company of men. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
Also The kind of trees called HamoD. (M, Ḳ.)
vuwlN a dial. var. of viylN, meaning The sheath of the penis of the camel. (Nh, TA.)

vawalN Madness, or demoniacal possession: (IAạr, Th, T:) or madness, (Ṣ,) or an affection like madness, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ,) [i. e.] a certain disease resembling madness, (Mṣb,) that befalls a sheep or goat, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) in consequence of which the animal will not follow the other sheep or goats, but turns, or goes, round in his place of pasturage: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or a laxness in the limbs of a sheep or goat; (M, Ḳ;) a certain disease that attacks a sheep or goat, occasioning a laxness in the limbs. (IF, Mṣb.)
vuwluwlN: see vuWoluwlN, in art. vOl.

vuwiylp A company, or an assemblage, of men come from detached, or scattered, houses or tents; (Ṣ, Ḳ;* [in Ḥar p. 261, written vuwayolp; but in the TA, said to be like safiynapN, as written in the Ṣ and Ḳ;]) and of boys, or children; and of camels or the like (mAl): mentioned by Yaạḳoob, on the authority of Aboo-Sá'id. (Ṣ.)
Also A place in which fresh herbage is, or becomes, collected together. (Th, M, Ḳ.)
vaw-aAlapN A swarm, or large number, of locusts; (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ;) a subst., like jab-aAnapN (M, Ḳ) and jam-aAlapN: (M:) or an assemblage of locusts, and of men. (IAạr, Th, T.)

Oavowalu Mad, or possessed: and stupid, foolish, or disordered in intellect: (M, Ḳ:) and, applied to a ram (M, Mṣb) or he-goat, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) affected by what is termed vawal, explained above; fem. vawolaMCu, applied to a ewe (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) or she-goat; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or this, applied to a ewe or she-goat, &c., signifies mad: (Mgh:) pl. vuwlN. (Mṣb.)

Also Slow in aiding, or in aiding against an enemy: and slow in doing good, and in acting: and slow in running: pl. as above. (Ḳ.) And OavaAwlapN↓, applied to old men, Slow (Ḳ, TA) in doing good, or in acting, or in running. (TA.)
OavaAwilapN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: vuwmN [Garlic; the allium sativum of Linn.;] a kind of baqol, (AḤn, M,) well known, (Ṣ,) abundant in the country of the Arabs; (AḤn, M;) of two sorts; wild, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) and growing in the cultivated tracts, (AḤn, M,) or in gardens: (Ḳ:) the former sort is called vuwmu AlHay-api, and is the stronger, (Ḳ,) and is brought from Syria: (TA:) each of them is heating, expels flatulence and worms, and is strongly diuretic; and this is the most excellent [property] that is therein: it is good for obliviousness, and asthma, and chronic cough, and [pain in] the spleen and the flank, and colic, and sciatica,, &c.: (Ḳ: [in which are added many other supposed uses:]) n. un. with p {vuwmapN}. (AḤn, M, Ḳ.)
Hence, as being likened thereto, (M,) vuwmapN signifies also ‡ The pommel of a sword. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) Whence, Oum-u vuwomapa, said to be the name of a certain woman, may mean ‡ A sword. (M.)
[Hence, also,] vuwomapu cakari rajulK † [The glans of a man's penis]. (Az, in TA voce TurovuwvN.)
Alv-uwmapu also signifies The channel [or oblong depression] between the two mustaches, against the partition between the two nostrils; (IAạr, TA;) i. q. AlxunoEubapu, &c. (TA in art. xnEb.)
vuwmN is also a dial. var. of fuwmN, meaning Wheat. (Lḥ, T, M.) And the latter is used in the [ordinary] sense of the former. (T.)

1. vawaI (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) biAlmakaAni, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and fiyhi, (Mṣb,) and vawaI AlmakaAna, (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yavowiIu} (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,)
inf. n. vawaMCu (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and vuwiI-N (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ) and mavowFI; (T, M;) and AvwI↓ (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) bAlmkAn, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or fyh; (so in the CK;) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) in the place: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) or he remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, long (Lth, T, M, Ḳ) therein: (M, Ḳ:) or he alighted, or alighted and abode, in the place: (Ḳ:) or vawaI signifies also he alighted, or alighted and abode, (M,) or he settled, (TA,) bAlmkAn in the place. (M.) Hence, Uin-aA nuTiylu Alv-uwiI-a fiI d-Ari AlHarobi [Verily we prolong the stay in the seat of war]. (Mgh.) [You say also, vawaI UilaI AlmaroOapi He betook himself to the woman to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, with her: see vawiy-apN.]

[Hence,] vawaI, (T, M, IB, TA,) aor. _i {yavowiIu}; in the Ḳ, incorrectly, vw-I↓, inf. n. tavowiyapN; (TA;) signifies also He was slain, (T, M,) and remained where he was: (M:) or he remained in his grave: (IB, TA:) or, as the latter verb is explained in the Ḳ, he died. (TA.) [See a verse cited in art. Hsb, conj. 2.]
vuwiIa He was buried: (M, Ḳ:) because there is no longer dwelling than that of him who is buried. (M.)
2: see 4:
and see also 1.
4. AvwI: see 1.

AvwAhu He made him to remain, stay, dwell, or abide; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or to remain,, &c., long; (M, Ḳ;) in a place; (M, Ḳ;) and vw-Ahu↓, (Kr, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tavowiyapN, (Ṣ,) signifies the same. (Kr, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) [In the CK, vawayotuhu is erroneously put for vaw-ayotuhu.]
And He lodged him; made him his guest; or entertained him as a guest. (M, Ḳ.) You say, OanozalaniI faOavowaAniI vawaMCF HasanFA [He lodged me, and entertained me well as a guest]. (T.)

entry.sense: 5. tvw-Ahu He became his guest. (TA.)
vaMCN [mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ, as “A certain letter of the alphabet,” namely, v]: see art. vwO: ISd holds its A to be originally w. (TA.)
vaAIN: see what next follows.
vaAwapN: see what next follows.

vaAyapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) without C, (Ṣ,) formed by permutation from vwyp, though the author of the Kitáb [i. e. Sb] holds the A to be originally I, (M,) The lodging-place, or nightly resting-place, of camels, (ISk, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and of sheep or goats, (ISk, Ṣ,) when they have gone away to a distance in the pasture, or around the tents or houses; (ISk, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also vawiy-apN↓ and vaAwapN↓: (Ḳ:) or the first and second, (AZ, T, Ṣ, M,) and the third also, (M,) signify the lodging-place, or nightly resting-place, of sheep or goats, (AZ, T, Ṣ, M,) and of oxen, or bulls and cows; (M;) and the last is app. formed by permutation from the first. (M.)
Also A combination of two or three trees, upon which is thrown a piece of cloth, used for shade, or shelter from the sun. (IAạr, M. [And in like manner vaOoyapN is explained in the T, in art. vOI.])

Also, (AZ, T, Ṣ, M,) and vawiy-apN↓, (M,) Stones elevated for a sign of the way to direct the pastor when he returns by night: (AZ, T, Ṣ, M:) and the former, or latter, (M,) or both, and vuw-apN↓, (Ḳ,) with damm, (TA, [in the CK vaw-ap,]) the lowest sign of the way, of the height of a man in a sitting posture. (M, Ḳ.)
Also The part which is the place of stabbing of a slaughtered camel. (TA.)
The pl. of vAyp is vaAIN↓: (Lḥ, M:) [or rather the latter is a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.]
vuw-apN: see art. vw: and see vaAyapN in the present art., above.

hom.sense: vawiI-N A guest: (IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) the vulgar erroneously pronounce it tiwiI-N. (TA. [See also mavowFI.])
Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding; as also tawiI-N; but the former is better known in this sense. (M in art. twI.)
One who abides (mujaAwirN [generally meaning for the purpose of study]) in either of the two sacred cities or territories [of Mekkeh and El-Medeeneh]. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)
One who is very patient in military and predatory expeditions, who is detained in the territory of the enemy, or on the frontier of the enemies' country. (IAạr, T.)
A captive. (Th, M, Ḳ.)
A chamber, or house, or tent, prepared for a guest: (T, M, Ḳ:) and, (M,) accord. to Lth, (T,) a chamber within a chamber. (T, M.)
vuwiI-N: see art. vw.
Also an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, &c.)
vawiy-apN: see vaAyapN, above, in two places.
Also A woman (Ḳ, TA) to whom one betakes himself to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, with her (yuvowaI UilayohaA). (TA.)

entry.sense: vaAwK part. n. of 1; (Mṣb;) [Remaining,, &c.: or remaining,, &c., long:] a stranger remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding, in a country, or town: (T:) or vaAwiI balodapK a stranger who keeps to a country, or town. (M.)
A man remaining in his grave. (IB, TA.)
vaAwiI-u: see vaAYiI-N, in art. vwO. You say qaAfiyapN vaAwiy-apN [in the CK, erroneously, vAwiyapN] A rhyme of which the characteristic is v. (Ḳ,* TA.)

mavowFI A place where one remains, stays, dwells, or abides; (T;) a place of alighting or abode, an abode, or a dwelling, (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb,) of a man: (T:) pl. mavaAwK (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence, Oabuw AlmavowaI The master (M, Ḳ) of the house or tent, (M,) or of the place where one alights or abides, or of the abode or dwelling. (Ḳ.) And Oum-u AlmavowaI The mistress of the house or tent. (M.) And Oabuw mavowaI Alr-ajuli The master of the place of alighting, or of the abode, of the man: (Ṣ:) the host who entertains the man; to whom he betakes himself for lodging, and at whose abode he stays: (Ḥar p. 595:) and the guest whom the man entertains. (M, Ḳ.* [See also vawiI-N.]) And Oum-u mavowaI Alr-ajuli The mistress of the place of alighting, or of the abode, of the man: (Ṣ:) the mistress of the man's place of alighting, or abode, in which he passes the night; occurring in this sense in a trad., not meaning his wife. (TA.)
It is also an inf. n. of vawaI. (T, M.)
2. vay-ayotu vaMCN HasanapF and HasanFA [I made, or wrote, a beautiful v]. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np.)

viy-apN The lodging-place, or nightly resting-place, of sheep or goats [when they have gone away to a distance in the pasture, or around the tents or houses]; (IB, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of vaAyapN [q. v. in art. vwI]. (IB, TA.)
vaAIN: see art vwI.
vayawiI-N: see vaAYiI-N, in art. vwO.

entry.sense: vayotala: see art. vtl.
vayotalN: see art. vtl.
1. vaAxa, aor. yaviyxu: see art. vwx.
vayolN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: viylN The sheath of the penis of a camel (Lth,* AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ), &c.; (Ḳ;) [i. e.,] of a he-goat also, and of a bull: (M:) or the penis itself: (Lth, T, M, Ḳ:) sometimes also used in relation to a man: (M:) and vayolN↓ signifies the same; (Ḳ;) mentioned by Ibn-ʼAbbád; and IAth adds vuwlN. (TA.) Hence the prov., Oaxolafu mino viyli Aljamali [More contrary to what is usual than the sheath of the penis, or than the penis, of the camel]: for the camel, like the lion, is a retromingent. (TA.)

A kind of plant; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also vay-ilN↓: (Ḳ:) a certain plant having a root and stem; when short, called najomN: and a certain herb, or, as some say, a plant, that is found on the banks, or sides, of rivers, in meadows: and, some say, a species of the [plants, or trees, called] janobap, which grows in the territory of [the tribe of] Temeem, and becomes large, so that the sheep, or goats, lie in its shelter: (M:) AḤn says, (M,) in the “Book of Plants,” (Mgh,) the viyl, (M,) or vay-il↓, (Mgh,) [both appellations now applied to triticum repens, or dog's grass,] is the najomap; called in Persian ryzwPAdlh [?]; (Mgh;) its leaves are like those of wheat, but shorter, and it spreads upon the face of the ground, extending far, and becoming complicated, or tangled, so as to be like felt (M, Mgh) upon the ground; (M;)
it has many joints, or knots, and short internodal portions; and scarcely, or never, grows anywhere but over water, or in a place beneath which is water; (M, Mgh;) and it is one of the plants that are regarded as indicative of the existence of water: n. un. with p {viylapN}: (M:) Lth says that the viyl is a certain plant that tangles upon the ground: Th, on the authority of IAạr, says that it is a kind of plant said to be that called liHoyapu Alt-ayosi: and Sh says that the viylap is a green small tree [or plant] resembling the first shoots that come forth from grain. (T.)

entry.sense: vay-ilN: see viylN, in two places.
Oavoyalu A camel large in the viyl; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) wide therein: (M:) pl. viylN. (Ḳ.)
maviylap A place in which is the kind of plant called viyl. (Mgh.)
